GAME: Cosmic Encounter
RANK: 99
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
(bought)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I first played Cosmic Encounter sometime in the 80’s. My recollection is that it was ok but not really my type of game – a bit light, too chaotic and random. Twenty years later, having now played the FF version my conclusion is that the game is a bit light, too chaotic and random. However, the variety in the alien powers do make it interesting and worth the occasional spin
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.7
Achieves what Diplomacy fails to achieve : bluff and backstabs with no hard feelings and a lot of laughter.

Really awsome game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 1
Never before have I played a game where so little of the game created a narrative/story, I had so little choice in what I could do, yet was dumped on so much (and still won). I often found myself having cards leeched out of my hands by others, but no opportunity to draw new cards, participate in encounters, or even the simple consolation prize of choosing who to target for retribution when it was my turn. There is nothing that would make me play this again.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I can't get enough.  I ALWAYS want to play CE.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I really enjoy this game, and it hits most of my hot buttons in a board game: loads of player interaction, zero downtime, endless variety. The only problem is that it doesn't work as a 2 player game, and really best when it's 5 (or more, if you have the expansions), so that limits how often this hits the table.

UPDATED 6-16-14: Bumped to a 10, and I'm not sure why it took me this long to do so. There is nothing I dislike about this game, I always am up to play it, and there are few in our gaming group who aren't just as excited to play this anytime we get a chance.


UPDATED 7-13-16: Dropped to a 9. I still love it, but I can just never get it to the table anymore. Is it still a 10 if no one will play it with you?
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
One of my new favourite games, this has so many interesting and involved mechanisms that just drag me into this world and want to play with the bluffing and alliance-making of Cosmic.

The aliens are all highly varied, and have a load of interesting ways to play and changes to existing rules, which really do stop games getting dull.

100% recommendation!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
What a fantastic game! It's one of those games where you attack with your dudes to take your opponents' spaces, but you cannot specifically choose the person you can attack or negotiate with on your turn, and each player has a totally game-breaking special power. Really fun game; some of its best elements are:
-It plays in about an hour.
-Easy rules; anybody can learn it.
-Every game will be totally different with the large variety in player powers and flares.
-Interaction between players is the heart and soul of the game.
-Really crazy stuff that seems broken, but surprises you with the ways it can be both used and countered by creative players.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
Always different, always chaotic, always fun... even for the kids. Our eight year-old here recently went on an eight-game undefeated streak... in spite of everyone's best intentions to "bring him down." He still won. ;)

Stuff like that makes any game an instant win for me.

UPDATE: This game gets better every time I play it, regardless of the outcome. CC is simply "awesome" in a box.

RATING: 10
Favorite game hands down.  Has all the elements to make player interaction hilarious, cut throat without being too mean, bluffing, laughing, crazy rule breaking.. without being imbalanced. Seriously, every game we think there is a guy who is going to win b/c his power is so overpowered, but it never works that way.. some sneaky person will work their way to a victory through subterfuge.    We pull this game out almost every other play group session.. With over 40 games that I absolutely love to play that is saying a ton! The most replay-ability of any game, add a rule, variant etc and the game still works.

RATING: 10
With the abudnance of alien races, flares and card combinations truly anything is possible in this game. The offensive/defensive alliances always creates a fun competative atmosphere for trash talking. I love that an 'encounter' is forced every turn with the destiny deck, it keep the pace of the game going. While "unbalanced" doesn't even begin to describe this game, it forces you to ally with others and use your cards as best as you can to make up for it, it is a super well polished and fun game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
First played in the 1980's. It's a classic for a reason, simply epic fun. In space, everyone will hear you laugh!
People say you must have the "right group" but that is basically true with any game right? BUT!!! What I think they mean is that the "10" out of this game is when you have a group of players that really get into what this game is all about: negotiation and variable player powers. One of the player can be an alien race that seems to have a power FAR better than everyone else's in the game, so it's up to everyone else to negotiate their way into victory and overcome the challenge of the other alien powers.... then again that's the cool thing... that's EVERY game. Every game is you and your alien power(s) trying to out negotiate and maneuver everyone else so that you can be the first to gain 5 foreign colonies. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This game is 3/5's bluffing, 1/5's negotiation, and 1/5's random number generator.  Which doesn't sound so bad, but I've seen a few games where a player's opening hand was so poor, that he had no chance of winning.  

Cosmic Encounter is still entertaining with all the posturing and the ingenious tie-breaker solution, but the mechanisms can definitely feel contrived at times.

I own 4/5 expansions as of 2014.

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
No two games are ever the same. Seriously. Never. Make alliances, break alliances, fake alliances - it is just so easy to enjoy this game. So much of what makes CE great is the fact that strategies and mechanics abound, yet they feel so organic and are never pushed upon the players. You can have all of the RPG fun of being a character, complete with lawful, chaotic, and neutral, good, evil, and true, without the game spelling it all out for you. Be who you want to be! Play how you want to play! Every player will have a chance to compete and win, whether you like battle, negotiating, or trickery. Quite possibly the best game ever, but not a perfect game; sometimes the chaos can be a bit much and create unnecessarily long or frustrating games. However, the highs outweigh the lows and no other board game is quite as thrilling.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Includes Cosmic Incursion Expansion

RATING: 8.5

De los mejores de puteo y de la categoría "Pierde amigos" jejeje Consigue con tu raza alienígena colonias en los plantetas de las otras razas de los otros jugadores. Es un juego muy sencillo pero muy muuuuy variado, pues tienes alienígenas, cada uno con su poder especial que rompe las reglas básicas del juego, y hay muchísimos, yo recomiendo la variante que en cada turno que te toque de nuevo, escoger una nueva raza y elegir si quedarte con ella o con la que ya tenías. Con las expansiones pueden jugar hasta 6 o 7, y meten más variedad que ya es decir

También edición de Avalon Hill del 2000.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.8
Still too early to pass judgement on this one, except to say a few things.

First, it's easy to see why this is a timeless classic;  I won't say it's a great game yet, but it's definitely fun.  

Second, it's claimed several of our favorite gaming moments so far.  My 5-yo got some alien power that allowed him to swap attack cards.  This became TERRIFIC fun because at first everyone realized he was always going to swap. About half-way thru the game, though, he got wise to this and stopped swapping altogether.  By the end of the game, you just couldn't tell whether he was going to swap or not, and the outcome of the game came down to me guessing whether he would.  We were all laughing hysterically.  

That's what gaming is all about.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I've played Cosmic since the Mayfair edition and just keep coming back for more.  The chance to play a power I've never played before (or at least a combination I haven't seen) is compelling.  The game itself is simple and easy to teach, the aliens create all the complexity and you'll only see 4-5 in each game.  This game will never get stale.

I recommend the expansions for the additional alien powers, but Incursion is really the only must have.  The defense deck is just too great an addition to pass up.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

I've never played a game where losing made me laugh out loud as much as this game.

But it needs to be played with the right folks, with similar outlook, and similar levels of humour.

I prefer less expansions as they simply add to the chaos without bringing more fun.

RATING: 8.5
good fun.  interesting powers.  I like that the rules are relatively basic, but all the powers break the rules, so it becomes more a game to out play / negotiate the other players.


I thought about it some more on why this is a much better game than say something like munchkin or any get to x amount of points, scramble to the top style game.


Although the main core game is the same, the alien power interaction makes each game unique.  There's some potential for a dud experience but generally the way the different combination play out will blow your mind.

Where as the other games tend to always be the same.

RATING: 9.4
Unique negotiation / area control game. 
Nearly infinite replayability since each game plays very different depending on which aliens are in play. 
The asymmetric player powers are very fun to play. Overpowered aliens lead to an interesting meta game between players!

Player: 3-5 (up to 8 with expansions) (Best: 4-5)
Time: 60-120m

RATING: N/A
Very interesting and wildly swingy (not like that, this isn't the 70's) gameplay.  Definitely not a serious game due to the sheer chaos that ensues, but it was a fun experience.  A bit too long, though, with 3 players, unless you just let someone win when the novelty wears off.

RATING: 10
This game is purely based off player interaction.  If you think the mechanics carry games, this is not for you.  If you love playing with friends and they are the reason games are fun, this is for you!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
A good game that is amazing in the fact that the balance between the luck aspect of the draw and the strategy seems really tight. That being said the different race's powers and the subsequent player interactions due to it is where the game is at and they seem balanced. They create such unique conversations and even ones where you might want to lose to win or just say that to betray someone. 
Downside is the lucky draw of encounter and destiny cards can win someone the game (A more rare situation than you might think, as everyone can be involved in fights) and if all are playing the game straight up without lying, it will not live up to its potential of fun. That being said overall, I can't think of a game that is similar to a collection like Cosmic Encounter. I would def. seek out a copy if it were not for the fact everyone I play with has a copy with expansions.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
OH WOW!  I've played it only once, so I cannot yet say I will always want to play it.  However, between the base game and everything people have added to it, I know I have only just scratched the surface (any more variety, and I'd say this game crosses the line to becoming a game system).  I have not had this much fun interacting with other game players in a very long time, and I am confident it can only get better.  This sets the bar for all other variable strength games in my book.  I recommend you read the reviews of more experienced players for all the reasons this is such a good game.  The FF bits, BTW, are a hair's breath from perfection.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
This is my favorite game of all time.  It's not my most played game, it's not the most complex game I've ever played (nor the simplest), it doesn't have the most expansions or varieties, it is not the first board game I liked or got addicted to, it's not in my favorite game genre, and I don't even own it (because several others in my board game group do).  However, this game just does it right.  There's a great mix of luck and skill and it is one of those games that always gets everybody talking and excited.  Different races have different strategies (sometimes completely opposite one another), there's a small hint of hidden role in the beginning because races are not revealed immediately which makes for some fun, and the game can be incredibly fast or fairly long (I have had a game end in under 10 minutes and a game that lasted over 2 hours).  The scoring system almost always allows everyone to see who is winning and work together to level the playing field and the races are very well balanced despite having crazy powers that change the game a ton.  Additionally, multiple people can win a single game.  Only one person has won almost every time I have played and only occasionally do two players win and even more rarely do three (or more) players share their victory though technically everyone can win.  Maybe I still do need a copy for myself...you know, just in case.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
Gets kind of dull after a couple of games in a row. Some of the alien powers seem too fiddly for what this game is. The game lasts longer than it feels like it should. Losing your power sucks and I'm surprised something like that is in a modern edition.

The fun part of this game is seeing how your power works and you get that out of the way in the first two turns. Lots of the decisions feel automatic, because they are. 

Criticisms of the imbalance and randomness of this game are often countered by claiming it's a negotiation game. The card variance destroys this argument. You can call all the allies you want to help you fight the person with the perceived best power, or with the best board position, and then that person plays the 40. It's a hand management game with very few hand management mechanisms. If you collude with other players to take colonies with each other or otherwise use Negotiates to mutual benefit, then whichever one of you draws a better hand will win. If that's you, great. If it's the other player, you're a sucker. Cosmic Encounter is really a gambling game, making deals with other players in the hopes that the random number generator will spit you a favorable result. It is much like Monopoly in this regard.

With a non-batshit deck distribution, more hand management mechanics, and a shorter playtime this might be a good game.

A major factor contributing to the excessive playtime is the bash-the-leader syndrome that plagues so many designs. 

Basically if this were filler I'd enjoy it but it's too long for how random and dull it can be. I actually like the card+ships resolution mechanism but the deck distribution is pretty stupid.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
EXTREMELY wacky and fun.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10

My gamegroup have played A LOT of rounds of this, but I could play this 7 days a week. 

A great competetive game with enough combos of aliens and cards to make each round unique.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Motto: The rules are not the game

A strange game indeed, as a simple numerical superiority game (ships + card values) gets turned into a melting pot of powers, backstabbing and leader bashing by the addition of no less than 50 available aliens whose powers break the rules in fundamental ways.

The best thing is seeing how they interact (Virus vs Antimatter, anyone?) and the feeling of bluffing your opponents into helping you to a victory.

I can't see myself ever getting bored of it.

12/2017

I was right - I have never got bored. We play every Lobstercon and while my copy has not even been open for years, the love has not died away.
I still miss playing without flares occasionally as sometimes the "bullshit" level increases over my tolerance threshold.

RATING: 10
Pros
- Crazy amount of alien combinations
- Simultaneous action, negotiation, lying, direct interaction, bluffing, double bluffing, etc. 
- Shared wins is a crazy concept and changes the game
- Stealing cards from other people
- Customize the game to however you want to play it
- Great moments and laughter
- Expansions do not complexity, but variety
- The Anti-Multi Player Solitare

Cons
- Need at least 4 players
- Some aliens/flares have a lot of text to read, but once you get it, it becomes easy
- Some nuances have to be learned, but nothing major

RATING: 8
3 to 5 players
60 minutes
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
For a light game this is almost disgustingly deep. The brilliance is in its simplicity, but that simple structure gets perverted in some very interesting ways.

My group specializes in medium-to-heavy weight euros, and most Ameritrash titles (especially older titles) sink like lead upon introduction. Though it took a game or two for people to get their heads around it, Cosmic won everybody over by our second play. People were laughing and threatening, losing powers and backstabbing as the hours just flew by. 

My only criticism is the core game-play definitely shows its age (and the math can be tricky after a few beers, especially with some of the more calculation heavy aliens). However, these criticisms are relatively minor and wouldn't affect my desire to ever play the game. 

The mere fact that the game includes 50 aliens and (essentially) 100 types of flares makes for some insane replayability (rivaled only by such laudable titles as Agricola). What's even better is that the game isn't even made by the powers *but rather the   interaction of all the powers present at the table.* This subtle distinction makes every game, even games where you replay aliens, very unique. This also is chiefly why it is getting a 10 and I'd always be up for a game. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5

RATING: 9

However, people who don't like chaotic (and loud) games should avoid this one, for this definitely is chaotic.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.6
This game focuses more on fun and presenting different interactions every time you play. You should not consider this game if you have players unwilling to let their win or lose be determined by luck. There is no strategy in this game, since the end game outcome is luck based. There is tactics and pulling combos, negotiations, and surprising each other out in battles. The journey is good, the end destination is bad if you like skill to matter.

This game always ends in either one player getting bored and sabotaging the whole experience for everyone or most players stacking to 4 then allying with the attacker for a joint win. You should only consider buying and playing this game if everyone is on board with those requirements.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
Funny game with lots of Chrome. Feels like a mix of Munchkin and a war game, but I don't mind.

It removes two of the standard flaws of war games by: 1) Not letting you chose who to attack (cards will decide that) 2) Making it possible for your opponent to win territory without you losing it.

Best game of 2009 so far (June 2009).

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Cosmic Encounter is a fantastic game of diplomacy and asset management. The main game loop is simple to understand. New players can start the game after a 25 minute introduction. The aliens, however, give each game a distinct feeling and that is where the game shines. Even using only the base game aliens, there are lots of special powers and flare cards to explore and interactions to experience between players.

Players will need a certain amount of luck regarding card draw, but almost every bad situation and terrible hand in Cosmic Encounter could be manipulated and turned into an advantage with smart play. Social skills are also a necessity, as you've to talk your friends into supporting you and not your opponent. This game is not for people who doesn't like table talk in board games.

If you like big games with social aspects, if you commonly have a 5-6 player table at your game nights, if you always play a game at least a few times before judging randomness factors in it, this might be the go-to game for your gaming group.

The cornerstone of my collection.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
A chaotic game which actively demands and evokes player interaction.  

Has an easy to understand rulebook along with some very functional and clearly labeled components which further aid in smoothing game play along.

Play is comprised of both hand management and negotiation.  And while card draws may be lucky and random, winning and advancing is usually resolved through the clever use of special abilities and out-thinking one's opponents.  

Overall a great sci-fi themed game whose random nature blends together well and works to create a fun, fresh, and memorable game experience through each play.

RATING: 9

Even if it's not your turn, there's plenty of opportunity to get engaged.  A wonderful game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Saying "may the best player win!" prior to a game of CE makes about as much sense as building a wood-burning stove out of paper.  

The outcome of the game is totally irrelevant, but getting there is a zany thrill ride with LOTS of hilarious moments and unexpected upsets, and this type of emergent humor never gets old (unlike, for example, Munchkin gags, etc).  Some of our group's wildest and fondest gaming stories have came from CE.

RATING: 9
This game is simple, but very layered. The variance of aliens is very awesome. Even without expansions, this is a very substantial game. The components are awesome. =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This game is absolutely fantastic, but I've realized that it really is a gamer's game. More specifically, it's the kind of game that fans of studying game design will get a kick out of as every single alien species breaks the rules and reshapes them for an entirely new experience.

The game is absurd and takes itself only as seriously as the players feel like taking it. There's MANY expansions and variants ensuring that every play is a drastically different experience while still building on the core mechanics of negotiation and bluffing.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
11/2517:  Not a lot of meaningful decisions, but at least it's not munchkin.  Not a game that I'd suggest, but less painful than some other games.  And when you have 5 or 6 light gamers, this is definitely an alternative.

08/16/14: Finally played a game of this that I enjoyed.  It's one of the games that you play for the experience, without regard to whether or not you're going to win.  One of the games to be considered when playing with a large number of players.

12/16/2010: Plays in a surprisingly short time, about 1 hour per game.  Maybe this will change as I get more experience with the game, but it feels very tactical, maybe a little too much for my personal style.  I think this may be my way of saying that this isn't my style of game.  However the unique powers and how they interact are a hoot.

Very nice bits, probably the best so far.  A game obviously destined for (multiple) expansions.  One of my friends who has had experience with the Mayfair and Avalon Hill versions of this game said that he prefers the Mayfair edition, at least until the expansions come out.

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
This game gets a few point for the utter chaos it can be. Dozens of card and race powers and each and every one of them looks "too strong" if you look it solitarily. Also, the ship moving and alliances are fun if you just ignore the fact the encounters are mostly defined by the luck of the draw.

But: Unless you play with very, very experienced players or a small group, the game probably ends before some players get more than two or three turns. And that is in two hours. Yes, there is some minor interaction with alliances, but in the end, if you get unlucky, you never get to actually *play* this. My guess is to remove the inverse play order cards to help this a bit, but it is an inherent problem of the game for which I can't see any solution.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
The best game. It's fun to teach - a walkthrough of a round of the game is pretty much what players need to know, and guiding through that is almost like playing the game!

I like how it's a game of player diplomacy, game-breaking alien powers, *and* the central importance of managing your hand to win encounters that matter. Almost every game I play ends in some type of shared victory, and with the people I play with, that's a pretty significant plus.

This game is a great example of strategic thought mixed with a dose of healthy chaos.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Cards sleeved.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
I think this game has a lot of potential - it's fairly easy and seems to have some pretty deep strategy, but I think a big point that it fails on is that it has a hidden curve for beginners... that is, a beginner doesn't know what all the powers do, so can't guard for every eventuality, or even know what might be good or bad plays to begin with. 

Other than that, my limited exposure to the game makes it SEEM a bit too simplistic for my tastes, but that's why I've got it's score where it is. I've heard such great things about it, it must be good... I just haven't seen it yet.

I'll definitely play it again and give it a few more chances.

----

After playing it a second time, it gets a full 7... The second game was just too enjoyable with too much backstabbing and excitement to keep it in the 5 range. Will definitely be playing this again!

----

Given my entire lack of excitement for playing it any time it comes out, moving this back to 5. It's decidedly average, and will play when I'm in the mood.

RATING: 7.5
Must be played with the right people. It has a bit of luck involved (drawing cards) and lots of chaos (diferent interactions between players powers). Allying with someone is almost always a risk, but also an easy way to get more colonies, still you can mitigate the luck by watching how many cards a player is holding, because that will limit (almost always) their playing, and if you have reinforcement cards or artifact cards you can even change the outcome of the encounter.
The alien's interactions are a blast! 50 aliens in the base set, plus more 60 or so with 3 more expansions.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Nagyon különleges játék, vannak részei, amik semmihez se hasonlítanak az eddig próbáltak közül! Egyhuzamban játszottunk 5 partit... A 4-5-diknél kezdtem érezni, hogy ez valami nagyon élvezetes, nagyon eredeti dolog. 30+ éves játék (mármint az eredeti) és ma is megállja bőven a helyét szerintem! 
A szabály maga egyszerű: Mindenki 5 bolygóval indul, és a többiek bolygóin kell megtelepedni. Minden körben csatázunk. A támadó és a védő a két főszereplő, de hogy őket éppen ki támogatja az adott körben, az hektikusan változik. A szövetségesek is bele tudnak szólni a csata alakulásába. Ami zseniális, az a viszonylag egyszerű keretrendszer. 7 lépésből áll egy encounter, és ezek láncolatából áll a játék. A lépések pillanatok alatt megjegyezhetők. Ami az egészet feldobja, az a fajokban rejlő óriási variancia: 50 faj van az alapjátékban, alig került elő 5 játék alatt kétszer ugyanaz. Hihetetlenül változatosak, ötletesek a fajok, teljesen eltérő játékokat generálnak (pl. van amelyik a támadókártyák számait megfordítja, van amelyik mindenkinek megmondja ki legyen a célpont, stb.)! Minden parti elején, amikor ismerkedtünk az új fajunkkal, mindenki úgy állt neki, hogy na ez milyen erős, ezt győzzétek le! És a játékban az a szuper, hogy mindig mindenre van valami ellenszer, és ha a játékosok következetesek, és a legjobbat ütik mindig, akkor elképesztően izgalmas tud lenni a vége. Simán előfordulhat, hogy egy parti során mindenki legalább egyszer nyerés-közelbe kerül, sokszor nüanszokon múlik, hogy a többiek ezt kivédik ... Nem nagyon fordul elő, hogy valaki hosszú időn át teljesen esélytelen a végső győzelemre. 
A kártyákról még nem szóltam: ezek rengeteg finomságot hoznak a játékba, főleg az N és az M betű, de a támadás kártyák nagyságai is nagyon jól el vannak találva (30, 40-es kártya nagyon menő, de bizonyos esetben még egy 00 is jól jöhet). A fajspecifikus kártyák is ötletesek (a képessége változik attól függően, hogy kinél van), és az egyéb spéci kártyák is. Az a pakli is ötletes, ami a célpontot mutatja meg... A játék alapvetése, hogy SOSE MEHETSZ TUTIRA, mindig lehet egy közbeiktatott kártya:)
Ami nem tetszett, az a technológia kártyapakli, szerintem nem sok színt hoz a játékba. A titkos fajok variánst viszont ajánlom mindenkinek!
Elképesztő hogy még 4 kieg is van (én legalábbis ennyiről tudok), ha valaki mindet megveszi, akkor összesen 110 féle faj van a játékban.
Az alapjátékkal átlagosan nekünk bő 2 óra volt egy parti. Nagyon nyelvfüggő játék. Látszólag brutál szerencsefüggő, játszva mégis kiegyensúlyozottnak éreztük, épp azért, mert mindenre van ellenszer.
Még egy pozitív dolog: holtidő nulla!!

RATING: 8
I love playing this game any chance I get (which, unfortunately isn't all that often). So far I haven't been able to figure out a fast way to teach it to new players so the explaining gets a little long but once things get going they really get going. To anyone who complains that the game is too mean-spirited, or that it can wreck friendships, you're playing it wrong. As with Diplomacy, these games challenge the player to pull off aggressive moves WITHOUT pissing anyone off. That's what makes these games so difficult. I'll even go so far as to say this game is educational. Getting good at Cosmic Encounter prepares you for all kinds of socially delicate situations.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
My overall favorite gaming experiences have occurred while playing this game. Cosmic Encounter has everything that I look for in a board game: Strategy, Negotiation, Bluffing, Combat, Special Powers, Epic Moments and enough luck to keep things from getting Scientific.

I know naysayers claim the game offers little strategic depth and that it's basically a luck based game.  However, I think this really depends on how you play the game.  Good bluffers, negotiators, and those who are effective at hand management will most likely find there is a lot of strategy to this game.  I have seen people win an encounter with a negative value attack card just by bluffing the other player into thinking they couldn't possibly win the match (and thus their opponent threw the match with a negotiate card).  

The possibilities are endless, and the powers really make every game different.  What a gem of a game. Hats off to Tom Vasel for being the motivating force for me buying this game!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
7/17/2015 - (Owned the game for more than four years and have played it through more than 50 times.)

The best game ever! 

In Cosmic Encounter, each player takes on the role of an alien race and competes to establish foreign colonies in other players' systems of planets. Instead of complete domination, a player only needs to establish five foreign colonies to achieve victory.

Each alien race grants a player a unique power which will likely play a part in helping them win the game.

Players take turns invading one another's planets attempting to establish foreign colonies. Players must attack whichever alien race is drawn from the destiny deck. This helps prevent many long term or overpowered alliances between players. However, short term alliances between players will allow them to gain a foreign colony as an offensive ally, or receive cards or space ships as a defensive ally. This mechanic allows for a high level of competitive interaction unlike any game I have ever played!

Cosmic encounter has limitless replayability in that the base game alone comes with 50 different alien races (each with their own flare cards (aka: super/wild alien powers that can be used by whoever has the flare card in their hand regardless of their alien race), the destiny deck, and a deck of cosmic cards full of cool artifacts, lethal attacks, and tactical negotiations. Also, Cosmic Encounter comes with many variant rules such as the technology deck, filled with its investment driven/researchable technologies!

"Cosmic Encounter: The Game of Infinite Possibilities!"

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Such a great game BUT it's not for everyone. The game isn't very intuitive despite being rules-light. Valuing what cards are worth and when best to play them, when to ally, etc is not easy for new players. I've found this game plays the best when you don't take it that seriously and just have fun with it. It's got quite a bit of strategy but it's not obvious to new players. Because of the way some aliens appear so powerful (and some really kind of are) and how certain cards are clearly better than others, the game appears to be a huge luck-fest and for a game that takes 1-2 hours that won't be fun for some people. Being put in a conflict where you have little or no hope of winning (which happens often) isn't fun either. There is a factor of luck but it's not nearly as high as it appears. The biggest overlooked factor of the game is the ally system and convincing others to invite you so that you can get an easy foreign colony or get some more cards in your hand. There is so much room for negotiation and backstabbing that is makes the game go from good to great. I can't not mention the true crux of this game which is the alien powers. The sheer amount of variability and variety within the aliens means that no two games will ever play the same and that's just awesome.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

There is nothing about Cosmic Encounter that speaks to me. Wow, was I ever wrong. Brilliant game, and quickly into my Top 10.

RATING: 8

The artifact cards, tech, and flare cards take this game from "high card wins" to convincing you that the vitality of an entire race is on the line. Very good stuff.

I think enjoyment of this game has a lot to do with the people you play it with.  Sure Cosmic is chaotic, but the chaos makes for some hilarious moments; the chaos in Cosmic also keeps the game exciting. I can see myself enjoying Cosmic Encounter for many years to come.

RATING: 7
Lok: BHKJ020403

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
This seems like a very hit-or-miss game. The mechanisms are very simple, but the complexity comes in the form of special powers and flare cards. Thankfully you can leave out the flares if you want a more simplified game. Surprisingly this game worked just fine with my family, because they also rank the complexity of the abilities so I could insure that we only use ones they can handle. The problem comes when this game starts to drag. If people start failing consistently on their attacks the game can get way too long, and since each turn is just a rote series of steps the game starts to feel repetitive. I'm sure it's up to the players to keep the game short, but if you aren't winning it's just natural to try holding on so you might have a shot at victory. I'd play again, but I don't know if I'll ever suggest it.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
Normally I write a not so brief rules summary, but I don't think that's possible... I don't know the game well enough as I've only played it three times and the last time was more then a year from when I am typing this. 

It's funny, I am noticing I only comment on games I don't own when I really dislike them. This is not going to be an exception. Both of my plays have been pretty meh, and the second game ended with me having a blow up which I will explain later and writing this game off for dead.

My third, and last ever play took 90-120 minutes and ended with two players sharing a tie. It was like watching a TV show about paint drying. The player who's turn it was flipped up another players card that also had four planets and they just openly agreed to share victory. The rest of the table was helpless and just had to watch it happen. WHY THE HELL DID I JUST WASTE TWO HOURS OF MY LIFE!?! My friend that loves the game, and brought his expansion filled copy over, went to the game's defense;(paraphrased as it's been over a year.)
"You could of played a zap card(I don't remember the actual type he said) which would have let you stop their play."
"So for me to stay in this game I have to hope I draw that specific card?" 
"Well, there are a couple of them, and they could zap your zap."
"So... even if I get lucky enough to draw the card to stop it I still couldn't stop it?" 
"It's possible. But also, one of them could have secretly played an attack card which would have been hilarious."
"But the two players were timid like deers in headlights. Even if one mustered the courage to pull that play out of their bag of trick I played a two hour game to see a moment that'll be funny for two minutes then brand the person that did it burnt for any other negotiations in future games of that?"
"The game is awesome! You have no taste."

There seem to be a thousand expansion, all adding more and more alien factions for you to play as, which you think would be cool, but I just found as tedious. Each one changed game play for that character, but keeping track of who did what, and what helped who, just made what was suppose to be a negotiation game feel like it was being cross bred with a tax form.

Bottomline; I know it's a sacred cow, but it's just a colossal waste of time. It's Munchkin's in space, with neater bits to make people forget how little this "game" has going for it.

RATING: 8.5
It took me a while to appreciate this game for what it is, in part because I was hung up on how some alien powers were just "better" than others, or how luck of the draw could give you a sucky hand, etc. What I didn't realize at the time was how important negotiation, trickery, and careful cardplay was to this game--especially the first of those.

That said, luck of the draw can be very bad, both with filling your hand and with the destiny deck. Not a perfect game, but one I'll never turn down.

RATING: 8
A game all about the interactions you have with other players. Different race cards dramatically affect gameplay and change the game up every time.

How fun this game is really depends on the group you get. I almost dislike games with new players- it ruins the flow, requires re-explaining the rules every combat, and limits the complexity of race cards and interactions. Playing with experienced players and with advanced races completely changes how fun the game is.

RATING: 10
Very fun medium-weight game (and easy to teach). Tons of alien powers to play with making it a different game every single time. This game has gotten tons of plays with many of my friends. 
Plays best around 5 players. 

One downside (not a game design flaw), is that sometimes players freely allow for everyone to ally with them which can really speed up the game. several times games have ended without a full rotation of players (in my 7 player games). On the other hand, game can be dull with too serious of players looking for indepth strategy. Have a good time, but try to backstab too!

RATING: 8.5
This game is a hoot. The powers are all over the place, but the rules themselves are really simple. As a result, I've found this actually makes for a fantastic introductory game, as the rules only take a few minutes, plus another few minutes for explaining each race in play.

I'm always up for a game of this, although the sheer chaos seems to be a turn off for some people.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
It's a cliche' to say, but this one depends on your group. If your gaming group is assembled only for that purpose and you wouldn't have a good time with each other anyway, this is not the game for you. However, if your gaming group is genuinely a group of friends, this game will invite you into a rule system which will create a terrific amount of fun. The situations the powers and cards put you in are unpredictable and generate temporary alliances, bluffs, betrayals and triumphant victories. When this hit my usually skeptical game group it produced more laughter, loudness and post game discussion than any other. In truth, almost all of the fun that we had was produced by the emotion and humor we all put in, but no other game is as successful in bringing it out of all of us so well. This is a must have game for a gamer who games with friends.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4.5
I keep trying the game to see what the magic is supposed to be...cannot find it yet.  I feel like something is being done wrong.  I really wanted to like it.

The races are just so dang annoying at times.  Sometimes they are ultra powerful, and I find that the majority of the game we are ganging up against someone to try to eliminate the power.  Sometimes they are ultra ridiculous, in that the power they have could make them win any fight by choosing what type of numbers will win.

Then the flare cards may do the same things.  Sometimes a flare card is so powerful that I don't see any way a person could lose with the card, unless they get it zapped.  Sometimes the Wild part of a Flare is better than the actual race.

All in all, I see a game that seems intense that boils down to a random draw of who will get the last turn to get a planet without much of their own skillset having caused the win.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
You either love Cosmic Encounter, or you hate it.   If you love confrontation, special powers, sneaky moves, screwing your friends, etc, you should like Cosmic Encounter. 

The major aspect of this game that I adore is the pace.  Most players are engaged on every players turn.   Whether simply as a spectator watch an encounter unfold, as assistance in an encounter, or the main players in an encounter.   There is always lots going on here.  

The Fantasy Flight version of this game is highly produced with detailed ships, gorgeous alien artwork, and high quality boards.   

Cosmic Incursion, and Cosmic Dominion are highly recommended expansions.   The rewards deck is must have in my eyes.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

edit: it went over like a lead brick with my group. I liked it, but nobody else did.

RATING: 10
The basic mechanics of the game- confrontations with hidden strength along with alliances and possible promises and backstabbing are fun and I tend to like games that use them.  I like the destiny deck because it forces conflict, prevents ganging up and keeps it from becoming too nasty like diplomacy.  What obviously pushes the game over the top are the alien powers which make every game different and which also make this one the best experiences in all of board gaming.  The sheer amount of the material for this game is nearly overwhelming and makes it infinitely replayable.

RATING: 6
At first I thought I would love this, but I'm not thrilled about it anymore.

I like that you are not fully in control and that you cannot win on your own just by doing the right moves: you need to convince others to help you a bit here and there, and use bluffing or other tricks to get an advantage out of any deal. Or make an alliance and actually try to win as a team? This is one of the few games where I could actually see this happening. Although you need to accept the mindset where a shared victory is just as good as a solo victory - which doesn't sit well with some competitive minded players.

After some plays I have found that some alien races and some cards are just too dominant, and [i]having[/i] to gang up against them isn't really fun, and since you cannot choose who to attack, or cannot do much with a bad hand, it is often not even possible. A game can be over before some players get the chance to do anything significant.

The rules aren't always clear when it comes to interactions between the races.

[microbadge=30725][microbadge=29024][microbadge=21140]

# of players: [bgcolor=#99FFFF] 3 4 [/bgcolor][bgcolor=#00CC00] [b]5[/b] [/bgcolor]

RATING: 3
It was better than I expected...
...but it still is just negotiating for negotiating's sake. You don't have anything to offer since everybody wants to win without strengthening your enemies that they might be able to sneak victory away from you.
The second big turndown is the total luck dependance. If you draw bad cards? Well bad luck... If your opponents draw good or even mediocre cards, well then you're out. You won't win a fight, you won't be able to block anything from destroying you.
And the worst of all you don't have any chance to mitigate your luck of the draw.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I used to love this game.  (Well, the West End version I used to own.)  And it's pretty, and really a good game -- probably.  But I seem to always play with large groups, and multiple expansions, and double powers, and ... it just seems so bloated.  I'd enjoy playing the base game with 3 or 4, I think, and maybe single powers (although we always played double back in the day.)  I suspect it's just the Epic CE game that falls flat for me.  Maybe some day I'll get a chance to find out.

Update 9/30/2013: Oh boy.  Again with 6 players, double powers.  Two players got turns before the game was over.  The winner hadn't even had a turn.  I MIGHT try this again with single powers, but even a smaller group isn't going to do it for me any more.  I'm not yet revising my rating, because I haven't played a "standard" game, but I'm just not seeing the appeal.

One thing I miss in this version, which was present in the old West End version I used to play: if you drew your own color in the destiny pile/deck, and didn't want to attack your own system, you got to choose a target.  The new version has all sorts of different cards, but few of them allow you any choice, making the game SO chaotic that I sometimes feel it's playing me.  

In this last game, it was over before it began.  One player had Genius and Ethic.  The upshot of this is that he got cards -- lots of them -- all the time, and only needed 20 cards in his hand to win.  We had mostly inexperienced players as well.  Maybe we could have found a way to block him, but the game was over before we had a chance to figure it out.  

Maybe that's fun for someone who's an expert at the game, but it may have put me off for good.  Which makes me sad. I had a lot of fun playing my old version of this game back in the day, and I'm sorry I don't seem to be able to go back.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
In [b]Cosmic Encounter[/b], players play different alien races trying to establish colonies on each others' planets.  Each player has a unique special ability to aid them in their conquests.  Some abilities are very powerful, but your opponents may cooperate to prevent you establishing colonies.  Because players can cooperate, tied victories are very common.

I first discovered CE in the 90s.  It has been in print for nearly 40 years, and it is still one of my favourite games.

It is also very imbalanced at times, which is fine with me because when playing with the right group the imbalances seem to work themselves out (someone with a strong alien being ganged up on, talking your way out of a bad hand).

RATING: 7
This is the first game I have taken the time to rate on here.  There are many games that I enjoy but very few that last within the my gaming circle.  My rating of this game is derived from the quality of the components, the replay-ability of the game, the fun factor with my fellow gamers, and the length of time it takes to play a game.  This is a fun game, its easy to explain (other than a few of the alien races, particularly the ones that involve math, even though the math is far from complicated).  It also works well with a wide range of player number.  The most I have played it with at one time is 8 (using 4 planets each) and the games went fast.

2017 Update:  I still love the variation but there are other games that have lowered this one a bit.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
Updated 12/29/10.

I played Cosmic Encounter twice this month because it seemed to be one of those ubiquitous, oft-recommended classics that exists just far enough outside of my comfort zone to present a new and engaging challenge, while not so far as to be either completely foreign or an embodiment of the kind of games that I actively despise. The game is widely cited for producing a fun, social experience, which seemed to be what we were after on the day in question. 

In pracitce, the game was less-than-stellar. It presents a relatively simplistic hand management exercise marred by simultaneous action selection and too pronounced card variability. All of this happens in the thematic context of space conquest, but since players must attack on their turn and since targets are chosen at random, conquest is first-and-foremost about card play. By asking players to secretly and simultaneously select the cards to play, the game precludes players from properly valuing the cards in hand. If you're the sort of player who gets a kick out of making a decision in an information vacuum just to see how it turns out, this game might be for you. I'm not that kind of player. Moreover, the range of attack card strengths is too broad to make the decisions of what to play meaningful. That is, the span between the best card in the deck and the best card in your hand at any give moment is likely more than any strength advantage that you can gain through the commitment of ships.

The more intriguing mechanical element of the game mechanic is the alliance mechanism, but that's overshadowed by the ease of negotiations. Negotiations between attacker and defender cut off allies and benefit the negotiating players. In fact, both of my games ended with a negotiated shared victory, which is about as unsatisfactory as it gets. Just let that thought sink in for a second: Both of the games we played ended because the game allows two randomly paired players to decide that they both win. :soblue:
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
Sometimes I think this is a great game in search of a gaming group.

When we play with Patricia's cousins, they don't like to fight one another, so they go for negotiation and shared victory a lot. It really made the game dull.

We also had problems with the shortened play variant with four planets per player. The game ended after three players' turns - two players teamed up with one another for two encounters each, scoring four after the third player's turn.

I'm still sure there's a good game here, but I think we need a different group to play it. Maybe the guys up north would work.

RATING: 6
The tension seems to revolve mostly around being able to go from four to five colonies. People don't seem to fuss too much about those first four colonies, just that fifth one. Which to me, makes the beginning and end game less than fully exciting. Oh sure, in theory the tension should be all about the actual fighting, with everything else in the game there to support that, but the stakes always just seem so low on colonies one to four (unless you are about to lose your third home planet, that can be rough) and most of the time it's obvious who will win any particular battle.

The alien powers add something fun to the mix, most of the time, although some of them seem near useless or just very dull.

Now, based on what I said in the first sentence, the ending should be the best part of the game, but every game I've played, the winners have been two players who negotiated their way to a shared victory. A very anti-climactic ending.

RATING: 6.8
$45 at The Comic Hunter.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I got into CE by playing the Mayfair edition, where Flares were a one-time use. Having them go back into your hand after you've played them changes things SIGNIFICANTLY. I have mixed feelings about it.

On the one hand, I find it pretty fun to know that people have certain flares and to try to base your play around them. I also like that, with the 1 flare per turn rule, you're sometimes forced to make difficult decisions about which flare to play. Compared to Mayfair, flares have a much bigger impact on the game and your strategies overall.

On the other hand, it can be quite annoying if someone has a bunch of good flares they can use every turn and you're having a tough time forcing them to discard them.

Overall, though, FFG has done a great job at respecting CE. This is definitely the edition I would recommend any new players. The bits are great, the rules are clear without being overly lengthy, there's a ton of awesome powers, and having explanatory text (instead of symbols and reference cards) on cards such as the destiny deck and negotiation cards makes teaching and learning the game a lot smoother. Also color-coding aliens by complexity is sheer and utter genius and makes teaching this game way better.

Looking forward to more expansions (preferably moon/lucre-free.)

Side note: I can't imagine playing Eon after playing this - seems like keeping flares PLUS playing unlimited flares per turn would make for some really rigged combinations.

Edit: even though it's essentially the same game, I bumped this up and my beloved Mayfair edition down. You can play the flares whichever way you prefer, and the clarity of everything really makes this the definitive version.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
A seminal game design. Very fun if not taken too seriously and if everyone enjoys the good natured conflict.  Negotiations and card counting minimize the luck of the draw. More skill involved than meets the eye.  To me it seems that the skill/luck ratio is similar to poker.  In a one time shot, anyone can win but over time, skilled players win considerably more often.

RATING: 10
Cosmic Encounter is a great game that takes the right group of people playing it to make it fun. The mechanics of the game allow for very unbalanced races to play each other (on purpose) and left up to the players to balance it out via diplomacy. If you are playing with a mix of gamers and non-gamers, this game will lend itself to being pretty random and not alot of fun. BUT, with a group of people that normally play alot of board games and can identify the stronger players/races quick enough, this game can be incredibly fun. I did not play the versions of this game before this release, but I am glad I gave it a try.

RATING: 6.5
Chaotic and social driven. It can be fun - but only with the right people. 

This game is not for those who:

- are not confrontational (they will hate this game)
- don't like to scheme, upset friends, or break alliances (they will also hate this game)

The alien powers are intentionally unbalanced - although I am not clear if this is a good game mechanic or just laziness on the part of the designer.

With the right people (who don't hold grudges) this game is fun - and the social element holds everything together.

RATING: 10
Who doesn't love Cosmic Encounter?!?!?! Updated graphix and new expansion cards like tech and rewards and hazards and and and!!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This is it. This is my #1 favorite game. I could play this forever and not get tired of it. I probably will play this forever and not get tired of it. This is an intense game of yelling, backstabbing, and wonderfully varied alien powers. It can also be a game of surprising alliances and friendships. The rules are actually rather simple, but the key, the linchpin to this insane, wonderful thing is the destiny deck.

The destiny deck is a deck of cards with colors on them. You draw one at the start of your turn and this dictates who you attack (with a few exceptions). This initially rubbed me the wrong way when reading the rulebook, but it's actually genius, because the crux of the game isn't planning the perfect strategy. It's not having the right combination of attack or defense or "gotcha" cards in your hand. You can draw a terrible hand and have a weak alien power and still come out on top - if you know how to play people. How to get on their good sides, and how to stay there. How to recognize when to betray them and when not to. Not being able to choose your target is actually a boon, because grudges don't tend to happen this way. "It wasn't my choice," you say, as you throw everything you have at whoever the deck dictates. Or not. Maybe it's in your best interest to build up long-term friendships at the start of a game. Or maybe you'll let other people do the heavy lifting and tag along in battles, going for a mutual victory.

In one of my early games, I drew the alien called The Mind. The Mind's power is to be able to see what another player's hand is before battles start. It's an overwhelmingly powerful thing to have, and it went straight to my head. Before I knew it, everyone was ganging up on me because I was too quick to storm into fights and win almost every time. Everyone collectively saw what a threat I was, and in the end, I lost. It both humbled me and taught a lesson not to assume I could just win because I had something so strong that it nearly broke the game. But it didn't: the other players themselves were the balance.

This game has been around since 1977(!) and it's clear why: this is an absolute masterpiece of game design that all social negotiation games should strive to achieve.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Cosmic is a strange game, I read enough about it years ago to know that it wasn't my particular kind of game, and it really isn't, yet, it's a game that I can see enjoying once in a while with the right group, provided that people play it quickly and in the correct spirit.

The game itself is obviously chaos, you don't know what your opponent's attack capability is (because it's largely dictated by random cards), you don't get to choose your opponent (because that's also just randomized at the start of your turn), and you can end up being manoeuvred into a corner by other players who decide that you need to be knocked down a peg (because the combat, though random in terms of opponents, is not at all in terms of alliances, and leaders can have the whole table gang up against them). 

This is essentially the prototype for every American style take that game that I dislike. For some reason, Cosmic does this better though. It fits into a short time frame, has basic rules that are simple enough to make the system comprehensible once the alien powers and flares are added in, and really can be approached almost as Diplomacy with some randomness, because politicking seems to be the real place where the game is won and lost, which is something that I [i]do[/i] enjoy on occasion.

Absolutely nothing that I would want to play regularly, but with the right group I do think this has some enjoyable elements. Maybe I'm getting [i]less[/i] curmudgeonly in my old age! :laugh:
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
One of my favorite things to do in games is to try and set up ridiculous scenarios and seeing how they pan out. (Asking my friend to pick his ten least favorite cards to play with in Dominion and then playing with all of them in one game, for example)

Cosmic Encounter pretty much guarantees ridiculous stuff happening constantly, and that's my favorite thing about it. The amount of ridiculous alien combinations are endless, and pairing that with the fact that most of the aliens have ridiculous abilities anyway is what makes me love this game so much.

I also like how impersonal of a war-game (if you can even call it that) it is. Deciding who to attack is based completely on chance which only serves to make the game more interesting than less-strategic (which is what you think might be the case)

Really just something you should give a shot, it may not be EVERYONE'S game, but you're bound to have one or two good games with it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
There are few games that can actually say that it is a completely new experience every time you play, but Cosmic Encounter delivers. Every Alien power makes each player behave differently, and the discovery of crafty powers, tricky cards, bluffs, betrayals, and overwhelming forces makes this into a game that is constantly shifting, changing, and evolving. Fantasy Flight made a version of Cosmic Encounters that brings the game back to it's roots, back to the original game before it was ruined by other developers. This new version also adds clarity to some of the rules that had long been in question.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Some games are too random to be enjoyed but that's not the case, Cosmic encounter is not "random". A coin toss is what you call "random". Playing Cosmic Encounter is like tossing the coin but catching some unexpected nasty thing: a lizzard, a wet cat, a piano... This is not "random" because the outcomes are much beyond the initial scope.

With CE I feel like the pilot of a cosmic spacecraft flying to an unexplored galaxy. It will be a great surprise but still I feel like a pilot. And is immensely fun :-)

One of the major drawbacks of this game is that not every game is "great". Sometimes the game becomes blotched for unknown reasons. This is what makes a difference between CE and other "non cosmic spacecraft" games that I rate better.

Note: Is curious to note that from a structural poin of view this game is totaly equivalent to Munchkin.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8.9
More so than most games, Cosmic Encounter is all about the people you play with and the alliances and shenanigans that ensue. Everyone gets an overpowered alien, and the deck contains a significant number of powerful flares. You have to work together to stop the leader, and there is often more than one winner in a game. It's unique and a classic.

I know why they did it, but I don't like it. Now they just need to add lucre! Lastly, although I rate this edition a 10, the original Eon edition is still my favorite--I'd rate it an 11 if I could!

RATING: 8
After two four-player games, initial impression is good.  Played this with my kids though, and it's a bit mean spirited for players that age.

Passionate players may want to avoid this because it's very interactive and opportunistic.  You can ally with another player on one turn, and then turn around and attack them the next.

I am looking forward to playing this with adult groups (I think).

RATING: 7
Starting this out at a 7. There is certainly replayability built into the game, and it feels like it needs it! I think repeat play will get those who don't "get it" a little more involved. At first, without knowing how the game plays out, you see no point to inviting specific people and not others ... and the powers seem wildly unbalanced ... but the fact that the sneaky race (and not the powerful ones) won had the rest of the table flabbergasted.

Of course once people realized Peter drew a 40 and saved it for the final battle, there was grumblings about never seeing anything higher than a 12, etc.

Hopefully we can get this to the table a few times to see if it will move into the rotation.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Maybe negotiation games just aren't my style?  I'm not sure, but the format for this game just didn't click with me.

On the one hand I appreciate that the game isn't terribly complicated to teach (at least on the surface), and you don't directly choose who to attack (unless you draw a wild).  On the other hand it just felt like you were doing the same thing over and over.  Draw, try to recruit allies, lay down a card, resolve.  Wash, rinse, repeat.  I think it just drags too much for me.

Granted, our first play dragged on too long and most of us got frustrated.  And I did see glimmers of a good game at moments, like when you try to outsmart a player that can switch the attack cards.  But not enough I liked to make me want to slog through this again.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
First time when I heard about CE I thought "these will be my perfect game, tons of interaction, a space opera humorous theme, alliances and negotiation.. nice!"
After 2 games I started to feel a little disappointed, too chaotic, negotiation comes with nothing but two aspects of the game (colonies and cards).. So I decided to give the last chance and I´m glad of because the experience has changed completely.
It depends absolutely on the group but I recommend to play with the four planets variant and tech cards, the games start to flow and you will be able to play 4 times in a row with the same folks changing the alien powers, these is the way you will see the "infinite possibilities" of the game. And forget the random selection of alien powers! 
Thematic..................7
Components.............9 (FFG version)
Mechanic..................7
Replayable value.......9
Complexity level.......Low/Medium (it depends on the alien picked)
Luck factor...............High
Interaction...............Very High
Total........................8

RATING: 7
Phenomenally fun if you're willing to accept that game balance has been thrown out the window. This is not to say that the game doesn't have checks and balances against nearly any sort of overwhelming card / ability - it does - but that the luck of the draw [in both powers and cards] and table diplomacy play far more of a role in victory than skill. If anything, this game's skill is like that of [gameid=227], where knowing what's [i]possible[/i] is what's important.

Even more fun (and even less balanced) with two powers at once, particularly if you get to choose the combo from three.

RATING: 1
I recently had a disagreement with a friend about the quality of this game.  I feel it is mediocre at best and he really likes it.  I summed up my point stating that; if i was still 12, I would love this game.  He replied in turn "you know what?  The last time I played I was about 10."

If you are looking for a heavy/Euro game, or anything that requires strategy/tactics/thinking, this is not for you.  If you want a center piece to sit around while talking and joking with your friends, this can work, But do not mistake a conversation piece for a good game.  This could just as easily be replaced in function by a witty joke, interesting story from last weekend, or a Youtube video.

Initially gave this a 3, feeling I was being to harsh.  I could not help but change to a 1.  The BGG description of a 3 implied that I could be coerced into playing this thing again, which is just not true.

RATING: N/A
[q=https://boardgamegeek.com/thread/1524018/cosmic-encounter-review-rocky-start-my-favorite-ga]“CE is a game of negotiations based on the prisoner’s dilemma.” I gave a short explanation of the thought experiment and how it is used when making business decisions and in real-life high stakes negotiations. “The most important part of it is that there are something at stake. Without something to lose, the whole purpose of the game falls apart. I think we’ve been thinking about the shared victories incorrectly.” 

“Imagine we needed to ante into this game and ended up with a pot of $100. The winner of the game gets to keep the whole thing. If two people share the victory, they don’t both get $100 – they split the pot. The more people you share the victory with, the easier the game will be to win, but the less of the pot you get to take home. You should only share a victory under two conditions: you couldn’t possibly win without it or someone forced it on you with their powers or a card.”[/q]

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
There isn't a lot I can say about this game that hasn't already been said.  Perhaps the best classic tabletop game ever created and truly a game of infinite possibilities.
   At it's core it's a sci-fi game of diplomacy with deterministic combat (no dice-rolling) based on how many ships you're attacking or defending with and what combat card you play.  The 50 different aliens that come in the box  really are what make the game so interesting compared to other diplomatic strategy games and give it an infinite value for replays.  Watching all the crazy powers interact in strange ways make the game very different each time.
  Truly a game of infinite possibility and highly recommended.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
It was about time I played this classic, huh?

I can see how, when it was released, this game set a new standard and rediefined many aspects of the tabletop game. And it holds up very well.

A take-that game with some constraints that help make things feel too unfair (the destiny cards controlling ganging up pretty well, but also sometimes contributing to it- however, it doesn't feel too personal).

The game's theme serves as an OK framework by which you can remember the general point of tasks, but I wouldn't say the gameplay is truly affected by the theme. The underlying game and its mechanics are too streamlined and pointed for that. It's not really a space conquest game- it's a game about placing chips into other player's spaces more efficiently than other players. 

This simplicity is a good thing, as the complexity and fun come from the interpersonal play (deciding when to be an ally or not, and which person to invite as an ally), and the myriad special powers available via the alien races.

I see now, also, where many games, such as Munchkin, derived most of their DNA. This game does a better job than most of its descendents from what I can see, handling the various interesting aspects.

A game easy to explain to new players, yet with enough depth to separate good players from poor, so that it rewards choices. Somewhat light weight, so it has carved out its place well at the table.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Too much confrontation for Danni

Easy to learn, easy to play, endless variety and insanely fun.

RATING: 6
Not as bad as I thought it would be in terms of negotiation. Warrants more plays. Can get screwed by card draw more than the alliances as long as you aren't being ganged up on. The best part about the game is the simultaneous hidden combat card play but there's no way to predict what other bonus artifact cards people play so it is a lot of chance unless you have a special ability that gives you the upper hand in fights.

Card combat is mildly interesting.

The random opponent draw on the destiny deck helps prevent people from targeting the weakest player.

Similar mechanisms to the hated Munchkin game as well but what separates it is the unique player powers and being able to win are a bit different.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
Between the astronomic amount of randomness (your race, your cards, who you attack etc), the total lack of information on anything, the lack of clarity on the rules, the slapped-on theme (how is this a thematic game?) and the long playtime, I do not think of Cosmic Encounter as a good game.

The total lack of information doesn't make for a good bluffing game, the lack of options makes for a lousy strategy game and the often unclear rules, relatively long playtime and unnecessarily long and badly worded alien powers make for a mediocre casual game.

I am probably judging this harsher than I should, but I can't understand the popularity and praise this game gets. Obviously, the myriad of different alien races is it's main selling factor - but I for one think that the game doesn't really 'balance itself' (see: total randomness, the only thing you can really do is not 'invite' a player in the lead) whilst the race powers range from absurdly powerful to laughably irrelevant.

Rated 3 because I will never get this game out if there aren't a bunch of people asking to play it - and there never are.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
This game has been around a long while, and I had heard many good things about it, which is why I finally decided to jump in and give it a try.  This is such a unique board game experience, very different than most other games in my collection.  The game creates so much player interaction that it keeps everyone more engaged than most other games where you each take a "turn" and until your turn comes back, it's just downtime.  The constant shifting of alliances really helps keep "grudges" from forming, since most conflict is forced from the destiny deck.  The variety of alien powers is what most excites me about the game, because I love games that feel like a new experience each time, and with the large amount of alien races available to choose from (100 in my collection at this point) makes me confident that we will have a fresh gaming experience each time we play.  Love this game, instant favorite for me, and everyone I have played it with so far has ended the game saying they had a good time. . . and that's what board gaming is all about.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Sean
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Easily the best boardgame I've played.

Unlike so many other games, Cosmic never feels "samey", it never gets predictable, and it never grows old. I will be playing this game for years and years to come with absolutely zero chance of burning out and growing tired of it. The variety and the replay value are simply overwhelming.

Most importantly, Cosmic can never be solved. It can't be played on auto-pilot, and there are no "optimal plays". The only "correct opening move" in Cosmic is the one that your opponent failed to anticipate. Everything can be beaten, everything can be undermined, and everything can be predicted and punished.

The game system inherently defeats (almost) all attempts to break it, and all attempts to solve it. You can't win Cosmic Encounter by beating the game itself; you can only win by beating your opponents.

(There are a few combos of Alien Powers that can break the game when you start playing the unofficial Double or Triple Alien Power variants, but with the absurd variety of over-the-top powers in this game, it is impressive how truly few game-smashers there are given the ridiculous number of combinations that are possible.)

All of that, and I haven't even mentioned the social aspect yet. I could gush a bit more here, but I'll be brief: This game is all about the other players --the human beings, your friends and family, that have sat down to play with you. This game isn't about strategy guides, optimizing efficiency formulas, or referencing spreadsheets; it's about people.

Cosmic Encounter is, quite simply, endlessly replayable and endlessly fun. What more could you want?
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5.5
Very few meaningful decisions. Randomness is fine and the alien powers are great but there's really not all that much to this game.
