RATING: 8
2013 SS
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Price 2400฿
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
3-5

Doel: als eerste aanwezig zijn op 5 vreemde planeten.

Set up:

Het zwarte gat komt in het midden van de tafel. Elke speler plaatst zijn 4 ruimteschepen op elk van zijn 5 planeten. Elke speler trekt 1 identiteitskaart. Elke speler krijgt 7 kaarten uit het kaartendeck (met attack-, negotiate- en artefact-kaarten).

Speelbeurt:

1/ Je neemt 1 ruimteschip uit het zwarte gat en plaatst dit op een eigen kolonie (in een eigen planeet of vreemde planeet). 
2/ Je draait een kaart om. De kleur bepaalt de speler die je aanvalt. Wanneer je je eigen kleur trekt, trek je een nieuwe kaart.
3/ Je kiest 1 tot 4 eigen ruimteschepen en plaatst deze op de pijl. Je kiest zelf van welke planeten je je eigen schepen wegneemt. Wanneer je het laatste schip van een planeet wegneemt, is de planeet niet meer in jouw bezit.
4/ De pijl wijst een planeet aan in de juiste kleur.
5/ De offensieve speler mag bondgenoten zoeken. Hij noemt de kleuren van de spelers die hem mogen helpen. De andere spelers zeggen nog niets.
6/ De defensieve speler mag nu bondgenoten zoeken op dezelfde manier als de offensieve speler.
7/ In wijzerzin beslissen alle aangeduide spelers nu of ze de aanvaller/verdediger willen helpen. Als een speler alliantie biedt, neemt hij 1 tot 4 ruimteschepen en plaatst deze schepen bij de aanvaller/verdediger. 
8/ De aanvaller en verdediger spelen gedekt een strijdkaart. 
9/ De strijdkaarten worden tegelijkertijd opengedraaid. 
10/ Het strijdresultaat wordt bepaald:

A Beide spelers spelen een aanvalskaart: hoogste totaal wint (waarde op kaart + aantal eigen en geallieerde schepen).

A1 De aanvaller wint: 
+ schepen aanvaller + geallieerden gaan naar veroverde planeet.
+ schepen van verdediger en geallieerde schepen gaan naar het zwarte gat.

A2 De verdediger wint: 
+ schepen van verdediger blijven staan. 
+ schepen van de aanvaller en de geallieerde schepen gaan naar het zwarte gat.
+ geallieerde schepen van verdediger gaan terug naar eigen kolonies. Zij krijgen defensieve bonus: voor elk schip dat deelnam mag de speler 1 strijdkaart van de stapel of 1 jager recupereren uit het zwarte gat. Dit mag gecombineerd worden. 

B  Beide spelers spelen een onderhandelingskaart.
+ Alle geallieerden van beide kampen trekken terug naar hun eigen kolonies (zonder voordeel). 
+ De aanvaller en verdediger krijgen 1 minuut om een akkoord te bereiken (bijv. ruilen/geven van handkaarten en/of koloniseren van planeet). Geen akkoord binnen de minuut: zowel de aanvaller als verdediger verliezen 3 schepen die in het zwarte gat worden geplaatst.

C De spelers spelen een onderhandelings- en een aanvalskaart.
+ De aanvaller wint altijd. 
+ De schepen van de verliezer en de geallieerden gaan naar het zwarte gat. De verliezende speler trekt als compensatie evenveel kaarten uit de handkaarten van de winnende speler als hij eigen schepen (geen geallieerden) heeft. De geallieerden van de verliezer krijgen geen compensatie.

Als de eerste strijd wordt verloren, dan is de volgende speler aan de beurt. Als de strijd wordt gewonnen, dan mag de aanvaller beslissen om nog een tweede keer aan te vallen. Na deze tweede strijd eindigt zijn beurt sowieso.

Spelers trekken enkel 7 nieuwe kaarten wanneer men bij een strijd een kaart moet spelen en de speler op dat moment geen enkele kaart meer op handen heeft.
Wanneer een speler 3 (of meer) kolonies van een eigen planeet verspeelt, dan mag je de speciale gaven van je karakter niet meer gebruiken.

Op artefactkaarten staat aangeduid in welke fase je de kaarten mag spelen. Volgorde bij het spelen van artefacten en speciale effecten: eerst de speler links van de aanvaller, daarna de aanvaller zelf en vervolgens de verdediger.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
The FFG edition is the only way to go.  I previously owned the AH version, and it was terrible.  FFG has better components, more aliens, flare cards, technology cards, special destiny cards, and wonderful artifact cards.

This game is just simply fun.  You do have to play with the right crowd.  You can not take things personally in this game because it is best played completely cutthroat.  You have to be prepared for swings and people ganging up on you.  If you can not handle this, I suggest passing on this game.

RATING: 9
The basic rules are really simple, and anyone could play it (though I understand why some people don't want to play  a game where the skill is sooo mitigated by how political it is).
Then you get the alien races, and flares, and all this other stuff and makes it so each game is completely different. Everyone gets their own unique power that changes how the game plays, and all the politics that helped so much before, while still there, can't guarantee you anything now.

It says half an hour (I think?), but who knows. We've had games take 10 minutes and be over before someone got a turn, and have had games take 3 hours because of certain combinations of races and powers, all stopping the current player who's about to win from actually winning. It can get a little Munchkin-y in that regard, and isn't very engaging with expanded players counts from the expansions.

RATING: 8.8
December 2017 - 8.8
My last few games of Cosmic have been hampered by the game dragging a little, mostly due to confusion/debates over what cards and alien powers exactly do an how they interact. And despite being lengthy games, I've found myself only having a single turn on offense before the game ends. And when your alien power only works on offense, it's not as fun.

[April 2015 - 9.0]
Boom! In a month Cosmic moves up the charts on the basis of playing with the right people. If everyone is into it, it becomes a rowdy good time, especially toward the end where everyone is trying to keep the leaders in check and play catch up. I really love the unique aspect of several players winning at the same time. That adds to the wonderful team play this game fosters. It's a mix of King of Tokyo and Lifeboats, with the alien powers adding great replayability. Still some alien powers seem a little weak, but mostly it depends on what other powers are out. Excited to see what the expansions have in store for the game.

[March 2015 - 8.6]
Biggest thing about this game is that you have to play with the right people who are willing to have fun with the dynamics. I've played with some people who seem to try and go through the motions with this game, but it's more about the emotions, alliances and keeping leaders in check to extend the game. Definitely there are some alien power combinations that are more fun than others in a game. Four- and five-player games are where this game begins to get fun.

RATING: 10
Cosmic is quite possibly my favourite board game. It's an exercise in controlled chaos, with fascinating relationships between the alien powers - which will change as the game progresses, and dependant on the board position.

Cosmic tends to be well within playable time scales, and easily graspable by non-gamers. It's accessible fun and wonderful, and doesn't take itself too seriously.

If I'm in the mood for a deep involving game then I'll play a wargame or an abstract, for everything else there's Cosmic.

RATING: 7.5
Approached my first game of this expecting some form of in depth 4x strategy game (so successfully now realised by Eclipse) but it's not that type of game at all.

This is really 'Bang' in space - and played in this spirit is a fun blast. The new (2011) fanstay flight production is excellent quality (cards, bits, planets) with the exception of the box, which has great art but is slightly flimsy and difficult to open.

Update (Sept 2013): A second play of this and this play didn't quite live up to what I was expecting. The various alien powers produced a bit of a log-jam game and one in which I was almost completely stymied by my card draws. I also had a couple of false plays due to not fully grasping the timing/ability of some card plays. Also, despite the fact that the other players had played the game quite a bit, such is the variety and number of differing special effects, there was still a lot of 'what does that do?', 'when does it do it?' type queries. The game would therefore appear to be fiddly and remain fiddly despite repeated plays. 

So the jury is still out for me on this. Fiddly and can play quite long for what it is, given that the cards can screw you - where the latter is the case the game really needs to come in just over the hour mark.

UPDATE - another try of this, making sure that we played only with some simple (green) aliens created a much better game experience. I'm sure some of the more complex, game bending aliens are fun, once you have the games 'normal' rhythm fully understood, but when you don't they just bewilder and frustrate - definitely learn to walk before you run with this one. Will likely keep.

RATING: 8.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Crazy, chaotic Cosmic Encounter: probably the best concise description I can come up with for a game which defined the very idea of simple rules that are constantly broken by the player's powers and cards that they play. The goal of the game is simple: establish colonies on 5 of your opponent's planets using your 20 ships. Thing is, you don't get to pick (well, most of the time) who you target so you need to make the most out of your attacks. And also, you don't get to draw cards at the start/end of your turn, but only when you need them. And then there's the special powers of your alien race. I did mention that *all* of the different powers break the rules in different ways, right? And that the basic game comes with something like 40 or 50 of them? And that ultimately, they are not balanced? None of this matters as the game is incredibly fun and funny to play as long as you don't take it very seriously. While it may look like someone is running away with the win, the game actually has a habit of having wild swings, which usually means that it ends up much closer than it has any rights to be. Lots of fun and recommended.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I like the player interaction in this game. The game chooses which player you will attack but there is still a lot of negotiating in the game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I like sci-fi and I like how this game is so different from most of the other sci-fi games out there!  A lot of strategy and replayability in a 1-2 hr game.

I really enjoy the diplomacy aspect as well.  If one takes the lead they need to prepare for a "bring down the leader" attitude from the other players.  Most of the time you want to bide your time and just make sure you're keeping up with everyone, and then strike at the end when no one is suspecting your imminent victory!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Okay so the basic mechanics are great, going to other people's planets, fighting them, forming alliances and using special cards on it's own would be crazy fun and well worth the price tag. But where this game goes the real extra mile is with it's alien races. The special powers and huge number of them make the game almost endlessly replayable even without any expansions. Definitely a must-have.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This is *the* definitive edition for the modern era.  One of the seminal games in the hobby.  With re-usable flares, 50 aliens with awesome artwork, cool plastic UFOs, technology cards, this game feels like the older editions with a few new expansions already built in.  The variability of the alien powers in this game continues to astound me. Every game is completely different, completely unique. It can be wildly unbalanced at times, but the ever-shifting alliances compensate. There are no shortage of surprises and dynamic interactions.  The game is more interactive than just about anything else.  At it's heart, it is a hand management game, where the key is to get the maximum utility out of your worst cards, usually accomplished in some devious fashion by leveraging the alien powers in play.  A supreme classic, so far ahead of its time.   I would give it 11 if I could.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Random, back-stabbing, lying, deceit, trickery... That's what you'll get when you pick up this classic game. Be the first to colonize 5 planets and you win, BUT... You get to be one of the many, many aliens that literally break the game's rules!!! Always up for a game of Cosmic Encounter if I have the time.

RATING: 4
Chaotic nonsense.  Essentially its just a party game about playing diplomacy on others but with a slew of non-streamlined muddled rules thrown.  Some games last only 30 minutes, some 3+ hours.  Totally unpredictable since the game is a perpetual gang-up-on-the-leader that just prolongs the game more.  The ‘fun’ is supposed to come from the diplomacy, interaction and backstabbing that occurs, but for that, I would rather play Diplomacy (which has more streamlined rules/mechanics) or Game of Thrones (which at least feels like there is some sustainable strategy involved and overall just feels more like ‘a game’).  I keep calling this thing “Chaotic Encounter.”

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9


=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.75
Cosmic is a classic design that I really enjoy.  There are some things people don't like about this game.

The race powers are completely unbalanced, of course.  There are some that do nothing at all unless it's your encounter and you win, in which case you get a pretty marginal win-more bonus.  There are others that are always-on passive, useful things.  Some are very easy to understand, others highly technical.   But this variety is the game's strength.  It's up to the players to find the balance in their games, to prevent someone from running away with it.

Turn order, sadly, is the biggest real strike against it.  The game won't last usually more than a couple rounds through the table, so if you're to the right of the start player, you might only get a single turn before it's over.  This doubly sucks if you've got a power like the one above, which only works on offense, and triply if you lose your first encounter and never get to do anything positive at all.

With some groups, this just falls completely flat.  If you don't care enough to get into it, to wheel and deal at least a minimal amount, to care about who allies with who, and who ultimately wins, this will be awful.  Some are put off by the lack of control in the destiny deck, others by the simple highest-total-wins combat.  The bare-bones design is pretty random, and can be skewed into one-sided games.  There can also be rules interpretation questions, even with the new edition, and that's before you get into the complexities of the variants like technology.  But, if you can get a group interested, this game can be a  real winner.
Personally, I feel like Cosmic is a great game.  It's a game that transcends its simplicity and engages the player with simple, yet meaningful choices.  Who to ally with, and how much to commit?  Use a high card now, or save it for later on?  Is it worth burning that all-important cosmic/card zap for this situation?   It can overstay its welcome a little, if the play is slow, and (much as I love expansions) tossing in too many variants can slow that down even more.  But I'd still play this almost anytime.

Edition note: This new FFG release is quite slick, and has the phases printed out on the sheets and cards, telling you graphically exactly when the card/power can be used.  This, as well as precise wording and so on, heads off a lot of rules arguments.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
My opinion has not changed since the original.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
If they expand this with a few more powers, add Kickers and add Negative Attack cards this will be the best version of CE made. The art is fantastic, the timing system is dead on and the power complexity rating is a great idea. I really like the new and old powers in this base set. Also, not having a board but separate planet tiles works well.

I have one complaint, I don't like that the plague card has changed. But then I am not one to shy away from a house rule in CE.


I have not played with the technology cards (yet).

RATING: 9.5
My favourite game. The sheer variety of aliens, no two games are the same. There are some complaints that the game isn't balanced, but the other players in the game gang up on on the more powerful aliens, so it's self-balancing. 

Crazy and chaotic, the game is almost a 10. I would make it a 10 if a 6-7 player game didn't take so long. 

I have all of the currently available expansions. Each adds something different to the game, even if it's just more aliens, and all are worth getting. However, I have gone through and removed all of the aliens that I've found to be boring, or not fun, or just stupid. I think that accounted for around 25 aliens. Also the Entropy Beast Hazard card. That thing is just stupid.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
The best part about this game that I don't see too many people talking about is just figuring out how to win when dealt a terrible hand. For those who say there's not enough strategy or its just a negotiating game, being dealt a terrible hand and turning that hand into a winning game is the best feeling...yes, you're at the mercy of the deck, but you can still maneuver your way into a win with good timing. Love the game! Fun game to have some beers and play a fairly involved "party game."

Edit: To add some clarification to my rating, this 9 and the expansion "Cosmic Incursion" (10/10) are primarily due to the fact that this light hearted game provides a medium for good friends to have an entertaining time. If you're looking for a game with clever card play, or highly strategic game, this isn't it. But if you have a group of people that like to role play a bit, act out, but prefer a bit more challenging game...this may be right up your alley.

RATING: 7.41
I got this game because of Tom Vasel, and a recommendation from important member of my gaming group. Not tailored to my taste but this game brought so much fun every time we played it. It's a game of space area control, diplomacy, randomness, war and a lot of backstabbing. The beauty of this game is huuuge variety of wicked (sometimes hilarious) alien races and a game mechanic by which your opponent is decided by destiny rather than pure choice.
One of the oldest modern board games of 20th century which are going to be fun for many years to come.

[b]Update:[/b] Rating modified according to a custom rating system.

[b]Favorite mechanism:[/b] Amazing amount of different alien races to choose from with different game changing abilities and powers.

RATING: 9
ulitmate replayability, high tension, high player interaction. Close to the perfect game, but probably not my favourite game.

You have to accept its random nature. There is plenty of strategy in this game, plenty of room for manipulation. Having the best alien power isn't necessarily that important. Having a hand with several decent alien power cards is more useful. This is a game where someone can pull a card out and destroy you in one move. But if your cool with this, its is awesome fun.

RATING: 8
Negotiation Game w/ variable powers. Permanent member.
I love negotiation games, and this one is one of the best. Its strength may lie in the fact that your skill in diplomacy, once discovered, will not cause a gang-up in the next game; the perceived strength of the randomly distributed powers will.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I read somewhere in bgg that "you win at Cosmic Encounter because other people let you." Social interaction will                determine the outcome of this game, rather than tactics.

One word you're going to love if you play Cosmic Encounter is the word "except." 

You're given a series of rigidly defined rules. Then every player breaks the shit out of them. Turns the game upside down. 

Every player gets an alien power that allows them to break the rules in some way. And by "break" I mean smash, disregard and turn the rules upside down. One alien wins by losing. Another can't die. Yet another uses entire planets as weapons. In the base box, there are 50 unique aliens, and each of them is about as bullshit overpowered as the other.

And yet balance doesn't ever seem to be an issue, because of the fluidly defined alliances. 

Edit 16/12/2015
Downrated to 8.0
Game is highly group dependent. A couple of members of my regular gaming group refuses to play this because they dislike 1.) randomly selecting who to attack and 2.) the kingmaking element. Last time I played this the game stalled out at the 4 point mark, and it became a game of "counter each player in turn or lose the game." i.e. like Munchkin, which I despise.

RATING: 6
My impression of this game is a light chaotic game with combat and negotiation.  The best part of this game is the near infinite differing interactions of the players through the various Alien races, combined with flare cards and the many variants that can be added seamlessly.  I feel it was somewhat expensive for a light game such as this and if you're looking for an alternative due to the price, Shadow Hunters is a good choice but with less variety that replaces the negotiation with deduction. My only main issue with the game is that with so many powers and abilities that there are going to be many rules issues that will have to be house-ruled/voted on when encountered as well as the fact that you can have a situation where everyone but one person wins... even when that doesn't happen (which isn't often), there can be many joint victory situations. Pretty good.

RATING: 4
This game gets so much positive feedback, I felt I should try it.

It wasn't for me. In theory I like the idea of the game, but did not care for the execution. Most of the time I felt like I had few decisions to make (not being able to choose who one attacks or the fact that I was dealt a hand of 'number' encounter cards that I could only use on my turn), and kind of just waited for the game to end. Afterward, people explained that can happen in the game if you are dealt a bad hand or starting race.

Well call me crazy, but I enjoy a game were I succeed or fail based upon my gameplay and not the luck of the draw. Also the the small spread in score (you are at 0-4 or 5 which is win) felt pointless, "Ok blah blah person X is at 4 points, lets make sure he can't win.... a few turns later player Y is at 4 points, same thing.... fast forward till most of the players are about to win, and then finally one gets to 5." Well why not just start everyone at 4 points?

I dunno, it just rubbed me wrong.

RATING: 8

Fantasy Flight has done a great job of reprinting this game, and quality expansions keep coming out.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Pros
-Relatively simple game kept extremely varied by the huge array of unique races players must choose (over 200 with expansions)
-The combination and interaction of alien powers is different every game and refreshing
-The use of numbered cards in combat keeps players guessing and keeps it interesting
-Possibility for joint victories
-Chance to lose your power in game and the players working together are a key game balancing factor

Con
-Weak negotiation aspect of the game. It may vary on the gaming group but I found negotiation to be very weak as players often opted to just attack rather than help another player get closer to victory (there is very little things you can negotiate on, only two to three things, one of which helps someone you and your opponent closer to victory)
-Somewhat random way of deciding who you have to attack
-Depending on group, can get very competitive. In some cases, everyone except one person will win
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
What is there to say?  There's a reason this game has been in print more or less continuously for just shy of 40 years.  A true classic.  It feels like an interesting mix of euro and ameritrash, and I love it (even though I am clearly a die hard ameritrash gamer).  Very few games have this level of simplicity on the surface hiding infinite depths of strategy.  It's everything from a (very) light TI3 to Diplomacy, without the endless references to the rules.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.25
A chaotic game, with lots of random elements and pretty much everything that SHOULDN'T be done in a game, but yet it works very well and is lots of fun! Possibly the best example of Ameritrash I own. 

PROS:

*Lots of action! No building up and bunkering, no tech tree or special fluff. Just all out action. 
*Great components! FFG did a great job with the art and quality of everything in the box. 
*Randomness seems to kind of balance it's self out in most cases. Because of the destiny cards, you only can get attacked 4 times per re-shuffle. Which means that if you get attacked 3 or 4 turns in a row somehow, you'll have a break for a while to rebuild and attack other players. 
*Lots of back stabbing and table politics, and I mean LOTS.
*Easily modded for inexperienced players.

CONS:
*Needs 5 players to really get the full experience. I won't play with 3 players, and 4 is kinda meh. 
*Game can SOMETIMES take a long time, which makes it drags for what it is.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
There are better games, but this remains one of my favorites. I love the alliances, and negotiation of it.  The massive number of aliens (with expansions) provides so much variety, to an otherwise basic game concept, which gives it legs.

RATING: 7.5
Until recently, I've only played an older edition of Cosmic Encounter, but I have to say that this new version really impressed me.  The sheer number of races available is stunning, even without adding to the number with the expansions. I like the simplicity of the basic rules of this game, mixed with all the special powers of the races along with ample opportunity for negotiation, alliances, and back-stabbing.  Having said all that, I feel like it's a bit long for what it is, and it's missing something that my favorite games have.  I have to be in the mood to want to bring this one out.

RATING: 9
This game is wonderful.  A fantastic foundational structure wrapped up in absolutely endless variability and replayability. You can play this game over and over and each game will present a different story and challenges to overcome, all of it hilarious and devious. 

I will say, though, that with so many variables running around that it is possible to have a bad experience.  Whether through a lopsided distribution of good cards or bad/boring aliens.  I've experienced games where some of the alien powers were never used because they weren't helpful at all in the given circumstances.  That shouldn't stop you from playing this game at all, but maybe recognize a bad game when they happen and scrap them.  No point in finishing a game if no one's having fun.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 4
Cosmic Encounter occupies a spot that is normally taken by small filler card games: a short and heavy luckfest, starting with the alien powers that are all over the place, continuing with the combat cards going from the single digits up to 40, and not stopping at additional techs or special events.

Basically, the leader is constantly reigned back in by pooled forces until everybody meets again one step from the winning position. Then, somebody gets to decide who should win. Hurray!

RATING: 9

I play with flares with one group and while we enjoy them now, there was a period of lots of whining with some of the complicated flares. The same applies to some aliens and I have since culled my flares and aliens.

I also introduced the game to other beginners, but this time without flares. Made the game easier to learn and still remained very fun.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Diplomatic intergalactic conquest. Sounds really intense, but actually a pretty simple system. Draw a card to figure out who you attack, ask for help, play a numbered card, then add up ships and your number to figure out who wins. Easy. This game goes from neat diplomacy game to awesome space conquest game when you add in the unique alien powers. It makes every single game different as each combination interacts differently.

Katie's
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Cosmic Encounter is a game that stands out from the others.  Being deceptively simple, it is endlessly playable due to the mix of variable player powers and their different interactions throughout the game.  Even though each player can "bend" a rule, the game seems amazingly balanced. Apart from the great sci-fi theme, the mechanics feel super fresh yet this game is over 30 years old!  It has a sort of Dune feel to it (with variable player powers), and it would, seeing they're made by the same team. I could see some players getting screwed, as the know-how when using particular races can be easy to grasp or take a bit longer to get. Anyway, it's real goody, and one that brings variety to anybody's game collection. A great one for sci-fi fans and games of intense player interaction.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I don't get to play Cosmic Encounter nearly as often as I'd like.  The rules aren't exactly straightforward, the play isn't exactly balanced, the theme isn't exactly everyone's cup of tea, which makes getting it to the table difficult.  This is basically the definition of Ameritrash, and Euro-centric players aren't going to appreciate the gameplay.

I basically find this game to be as good as the people playing it want it to be.  The win condition is almost tertiary to the often-times wild takeover attempts, and sub-optimal play can yield the best experiences.

My only complaint of the game is the distribution of the attack/defense cards' values.  Either they should have had a smaller range of values or provided a sheet showing the distribution.  Too often new players won't realize that attacks in the 40s even exist.

RATING: N/A
3-5
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
[b][i]Cosmic Encounter[/i][/b] is a thematic game with enough luck, strategy, and negotiation to keep it interesting for everyone. This game has been a hit for a wide range of age groups and game aptitude levels because the core of Cosmic is simple and non-confrontational: just draw a card and attack the listed player. Being forced to encounter a player makes combat relaxed and light-hearted. In fact between combat, player cards, and alien powers, there's so much randomness in Cosmic that it might seem to be completely devoid of strategy at first blush. However, although strategy is on the lighter side, the randomness is balanced by hand management and negotiation so that the game is as involved as you want it to be--there's definitely enough to keep serious gamers entertained. Negotiations are required for the game to be at its best.

Replay-ability is guaranteed through a wide range of alien races. The drastically different aliens are fun and have color coded difficulty levels to easily scale the game's complexity.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
[b]Cosmic Encounter[/b] [i]Peter Olotka, Bill Eberlee 2008[/i]
Cosmic is a game I learnt to like after several plays. At first sight it seemed to me a chaos fest with no sense at all, but after several plays during one year, I started to realize that my first impressions were wrong cause I aproached the game in a bad way. The first time I played I was expecting a strategic game, but Cosmic is not such a thing, Cosmic is a kind of party game in the meaning that it works perfectly in a relaxed enviroment, but with quite a lot of room for some interesting tactic options and backstabbing. It is chaotic yes, but is not completly out of control. Avoid it if these kind of games are not your cup of tea. 

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
The bluffing and variable powers are interesting and teamwork and backstabbing is something I always love in games. However I think there are plenty of games that do the social parts of this game cleaner and faster.

What you need to realise about CE is that the game itself is somewhat ancillary, the actual activity is all about the social interaction. The problem is that the game constantly gets in the way of the fun, it's too complex and there's always rule questions. The game is fundamentally unbalanced and asks the players to self-balance, which I always dislike.

A lot of aliens are just boring, which kind of ruins the point of the game. The rules are poorly written which can result in a much worse game due to easily made mistakes. There's a lot of bash-the-leader and kingmaking by design. For example my most recent game ended because someone negotiated a 5th colony from a player that just wanted to go home and there was nothing that could be done about that. It's not the game's fault, but it still wasn't particularly fun.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.6
My favorite game in my collection. It's hard to convince my friends to play anything else!

So much player interaction, so many interesting decisions. Every play can start a rock slide of increasingly ridiculous flare cards and player powers that throws me into a state of wonder every time and makes me remember why I fell in love with the game in the first place. If this sounds emotional, that's because it is. I LOVE this game. The game is based on an extremely simple core mechanic, which makes it easy to teach and easy to get into. The complexity comes from the alien abilities and the cards, which is also where the real entertainment value comes from.

And the expansions are FANTASTIC! I couldn't believe the game could get any better, and then Cosmic Conflict added the hazard deck, which in my opinion is an even better mechanic than the tech deck from the base game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

This game also has a feel of fitting into a lot of slots in a game night, and it's just versatile. 

Very glad I got this one.

RATING: 10
I love everything about this game. It's the perfect definition of what a social board game is, there's always a ridiculous combination of powers going on and they always feel fun. It's my favorite game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Incoming ramble punctuated by (hopefully) good points:

Haven't played a perfect 10, but this is my favorite game with the most memorable experiences, interactivity, lack of analysis paralysis, and interesting decisions to make (cards to play versus save, gamble on a win now versus hoping no one wins before your next turn, negotiation and table talk, and reacting to the game's unlimited variance). It has that key factor in games I like: excitement. When players are screaming (happiness or frustration) not just when points are added up, but when a good deal or play is made, I know I've found something that's exciting. 

I've played this game like 30 times and it's always a treat. I've never had one of those horror stories of a 2+ hour game (mine are usually 45-75 mins depending on players) and it's a lot of laughing and yelling. Your success is going to be determined more-so by how you act than how you strategize/play, and I think this is a turn off for some folks. That's a bit unfair to me because I still think efficiency and skill are rewarded (more below). 

People also criticize the randomness. My point of view is part of the fun in the game is figuring out how the randomness benefits some people more than others and then forming alliances against that person- knowing this will shift as the randomness inevitably changes again. So you still get this neat little analysis period when a certain tech/alien power/hazard is revealed, but then it's more about social engineering to get to the next step. 

A lot of play is dictated by the cards you're dealt. Of the 30 ish times I've played, about 3 times someone got dealt a hand that was just a clunker with their alien choices. That sucks and makes the game drag a little for them. But it also opens up creative options - like negotiating to give your hand away so you can draw a new one or positioning yourself in such a weak position that people love having you as an ally while you build back up under the radar. Compare it to a game like Munchkin (which I really dislike) where a similar thing could happen. In munchkin your decision space boils down to "who is winning, how can I set them back - oh shit they snow balled and now we really have to get them." Whereas in this, so many things could happen in the span of a turn that you can create sweet little swings for yourself by pretending to be in any type of leaderboard position (ie winning/losing, strong/weak). In other words, the flexibility of the game state is a lot higher for cosmic, meaning things are rarely what they seem and it again comes back to social engineering to do best.

And if people want to make comparisons, this game feels a lot more like Tammany Hall than Munchkin - but with the sheer variety of aliens and other things, it's hard to make a real comparison. 

However, that's not to say smart card play isn't rewarded. Obviously gauging a player's strength based on previous plays, alliances, and table posturing can help you save your best cards for later. And having a clever surprise to change your trash cards into a valuable swing for you tickles even the most Grinch-like Machiavellis. 

People may say that all this randomness and social engineering I'm praising could lead to a game that's completely driven by luck. That's just not true. For ex: I have winners (including joint winners, another fantastic thing about this game that helps to create a situation where after the game, many are happy, many are grumpy, but everyone is excited about what just happened) sign the underside of the box. As the owner of the game, I've played almost every time. But one friend has played substantially less - maybe half of the 30? Yet his name is on there more times than anyone else! He is just good at this game and at this point it's def not a fluke that he's winning - his skill has been rewarded.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
The different power of the 50 alien race include in this game make each game unique.  Every turn, you draw a card to know with which player you're going to have an encounter with.  You can then invite other players to attack with you.  The defender can also invite the other players to help defend his planet.  The attacker and the defender then choose a card to either attack or negociate.  The encounter is then resolve.  If the attacker wins, he and is offensive ally gain a colony on the opponent planet and the defender and is ally ships are destroyed.  If the defender wins, he keeps his planet and is ally can retrieve ships previoulsy destroyed or draw cards.  The first player to establish 5 foreign colonies on the other player planet wins.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Really amazing game.  I have many favorites and it's hard to decide which one i love the most.  But the ingenuity behind this gem takes the cake.  Love this game, and it plays a ton of people like a party game, although it is not a party game - it's a full course interactive rule-bender! :)

RATING: 8.5
A great game of diplomacy and Tom foolery in the form of rule-breaking special powers. Despite the back stabbing this game always brings the laughs. And usually a good chunk of explicit language.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Played only once so far. We had five players, and I immediately saw everything that people both love and loathe about this game. It really comes down to the random nature of the beast - what races you're provided, what cards you're dealt, and what card you draw from the Destiny Deck really determine your success in the game. Any negotiating, or metagaming, you do is negated if the next few draws are against your supposed friend. There's no good way to develop a strategy.

Not that it's necessarily a bad thing. A game like this gives more chances to people who are not so great at developing strategies. Unfortunately, it can go the other way, too, and totally discourage them from ever playing the game again.

I actually do find the game somewhat fun and will play it again, but I do not look forward to the possibility of a game much longer than an hour. When we played, it took about an hour or so to start the second round of play - which wasn't even completed because someone had won by then. A three hour game, given how long the turns are and how random the game could be, would likely ruin a game night for me. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Cosmic Encounter, if you have the right group, is about as close to a perfect game experience as I can find. This isn't about winning. It's about having as much fun as possible. 

I've played with several groups, and it's gone over almost universally well. I found the instruction manual was pretty heavy and weird, but the game was really, really easy to teach. Fantasy Flight did a great job of explaining the different phases, and the bottoms of the alien cards help keep on track.

The aliens themselves add a ton of variety to the game, as well. If you like discussion, if you like chaos, if you like laughter, and if you like fun, I'd highly recommend this game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
So many alien races, so much replay value. Really a fun, tactical game with lots of decision trees and a unique feel every time you play a different race. Everyone I've played this with has loved it, and I don't see that changing anytime soon. Flares are awesome, tech on the other hand felt pretty underwhelming and I don't think we'll play with it again soon. The social aspect of this game is just an awesome experience all around.

Game can get really vicious with the backstabbing, but as long as everyone has a bit of a thick skin this it's a blast. Lately I feel like we've maybe been too nice about it, lots of co-op wins.

Alliance dials from Eons are pretty sweet. I definitely see how Incursion is marked as an essential expansion between the extra colour, awesome aliens, and the rewards deck.

Have Cosmic Incursion, Cosmic Eons

RATING: 8
I knew I'd like this game after watching reviews for it (Tom Vasel's enthusiasm is hard to deny), but man, I really LOVE this game!  The player interaction is superb and the cards bring a lot of tension, but the variety of alien races/powers is what makes this game so amazing.  Though some alien powers seem unbalanced at first, the game really does balance itself out with flare and artifact cards and the fact that players have the option to team up against a leader. Every game I've played so far has been very close and most have come down to all players having 4 foreign colonies forcing the winner to have to defeat their defence with the backing of all the other players as allies.  I can't wait to pick up the expansions.

RATING: 10
I loved the 'chrome' of the Avalon Hill version, but the fact that it only went to 4 players, had 20 alien powers and there were never any expansions meant that it was a bit limiting... this new edition from Fantasy Flight Games is 5 player out of the box, and comes with 50 alien powers and a new concept called Tech cards.... plus there is now an expansion out that takes it to 6 players and 70 alien powers.

While not exactly like the old Eon or Mayfair editions, this version should definitely appeal to players of those older versions, whilst also attracting new gamers to this fantastic game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
There are some games in your collection that you will lose no matter how well you play.  This is one of those games.  It is unbalanced and silly.

Supposedly players are responsible for balancing this game.  Will they?  Probably not, but lord they will argue!  They will debate, and make deals, and negotiate, and watch as their plans inevitably fail forcing them to redraw alliances and try again.  The atmosphere of distrust is delicious.

Cosmic Encounter is a ridiculous situation generator.  The game is trying to take advantage of less-than-ideal situations.  Actually, the real game is just sitting back and enjoying the theater that results from people trying to create a permanent advantage in a random world.  After all, many of the elements in the game are random, but the design balances this beautifully with a high degree of player control.  You will always have options, even if they are rarely the ones you want.

Perhaps the best thing about this game is that it actually allows team victories, provided two or more players can gain five victory points at the same time.  In a way, this ups the tension.  After all, in most free-for-all style games, backstabbing is never a surprise.  It's just a question of when.  In this game, an alliance is tense because it just might work!

Fans of perfectly-balanced strategy games will find this game frustrating and pointless (which is not an unfair point).  Lawful-aligned characters need not apply.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
10! This is so much fun that i consider adjusting my other top ratings. Poker with cheating abilities, some strategy, a huge amount of barely controlled chaos, ever-shifting alliances & backstabbing => whoohoo

RATING: 9
House Rules: 
1. Draw 4 powers and keep 2. Powers are face down until activated. Player can treat every power as optional while face down. Allows you two pick powers that combo well together, and adds a timing element.
2. Two flares per person, or minimun 10, are randomly chosen and added to the deck. This gives more variety and makes the Super Flare very special and rare.
3. The colors are not colors, but names of fruit; lemon, cherry, blueberry, grape, and brocolli. This was stressed to me when I was taught the game, so I carry on the tradition.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Still, it's possible the strategies are just more subtle, and it's fun enough to play again and again to figure this out.

RATING: 10
The true heir to the throne of board games! Cosmic Encounter can be fun a for a broad spectrum of people, gamers and non-gamers alike. Straight-forward enough for newcomers to understand the basic rules, but that all immediately becomes flipped on its head once the aliens are introduced. HUGELY replayable! There's always great tension and player interaction! Cosmic Encounter has led to some of my greatest laughs, and the table talk and politics is bar-none. Good luck to any other board game taking Cosmic Encounter's position as my number one board game of all time!

HAVE EXPANSIONS:
Cosmic Dominion
Cosmic Incursion

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
The highest rated game in my collection. I often use this game as a measuring stick for other games. At once strategic and full of laughter inducing interaction. 

The only other games that rival Cosmic Encounter in terms of addictiveness are Dominion and Star Realms. Almost every time I play Cosmic with new players, it is a watershed moment for them, and many return weeks or even a year later saying that they kept thinking about this game. In the middle of a first playthrough, one player who I was introducing to the hobby stated, with no provocation: "wow, were living in some sort of golden age of board games." 

One caveat: CE is not for people who cannot tolerate heavy and aggressive interaction in games. I had one player become upset because they felt like the energy at the table was very negative, while everyone else was having a raucous time. So more passive players beware.

RATING: 10
I've loved every version of this game. FFG's is no different.

However, FFG included several additions and modifications to the game that I think are incredibly good.

- Morph card: This is a brilliant idea!
- A full hand is eight cards instead of seven: This is a subtle change that seems to affect play in a very positive way.
- Tech: Adding an entirely new sub-set of rules to a classic game in its initial release is a daring choice. Kudos!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
I played this once a long, long time ago during its Eon incarnation, and never played it again. Now, after playing the FFG version, I remember why. The game is, in my humble opinion, nothing more than a glorified version of 'War', full of chaos and rules ambiguities, making for a disappointing and frustrating gaming experience. After having my colonies decimated left and right within the first 15 minutes, I just wanted the game to end. Who I attack is totally random, as it is up to the Destiny card(s). Whether I win or lose is almost completely dependent on the hand of attack cards I have, which rank anywhere from '00' up to '40', which are added to my attack force, which can only vary up to 4 ships (and possibly 16 ships total if everyone in a five-player game allies with me). We compare the two numbers and that's it--sounds like War to me. Sure, there are some things that modify the outcome, but all of it is completely random and chaotic. I suppose that's what real warfare is, but I got the sense that I really had no control over my destiny. There is some element of diplomacy and negotiation, but I am learning that I really don't care for those kinds of games either. I suppose the additional rules in the FFG version will add some elements, but I don't care for the foundation of the game, so I think I'll pass when this comes the table again.

Update (11/01/10): After playing FFG's re-imaging of Dungeonquest, which was equally bloated, chaotic, and draggy, who am I kidding? I'm never going to play this ever again. Dropping it down to a '2'.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
2copies
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
[center][size=6][COLOR=#878787]LIFETIME GAME [microbadge=28495]:star:[microbadge=28496] "PLAY FOREVER"[/COLOR][/size][/center]

Bluffing, gambling, negotiation, backstabbing, outrageous reversals—this game has it all.  And a thick, gooey science fiction theme to boot!  The rules are simple, almost laughably so, but that's not where the game is.  The game is in finding the most clever way in which to use those rules to your advantage, no matter how bleak the situation.  Taken at face value, it's pretty lame, and I can see why some people hate it so.  Add in a bunch of raucous, cunning friends and the game surprises and delights every time.  I'm constantly surprised at some of the subtle ways "I'm screwed" moments can turn into a big win.

Negotiated (or even forced) multi-wins are great since they keep the playing time more than tolerable (read: occasionally [i]too[/i] short—but what the hell, let's play again!).

Includes:

[thing=61001]Incursion[/thing]
[thing=87507]Conflict[/thing]
[thing=114276]Alliance[/thing]
[thing=143760]Storm[/thing]
[thing=153971]Dominion[/thing]

[microbadge=24361]

Brief musings on my various [i]Cosmic[/i] play groups:

[b][thread=774902][/thread][/b]

PS.  The Broken Token organizer/insert is fantastic—and [i]necessary[/i].  Previously, I had managed to get the entire game with all expansions into the original box (!), but it suffered from the classic problem of such things:  THE IMPENETRABLE BRICK OF BAGGIES.  Setup was an archeology expedition; breakdown a chore.  With the organizer everything has a perfect little place, trays nest neatly, and you can see—and just reach out and grab!—every last deck and bit.

RATING: 7
I am extremely delighted to finally put my hands on CE.  I have played it several times before and loved it.  It has everything I like in board-games.  It is light and tactical at the same time, variable alien powers make each game different.  Plus it has optional rules - so you can start with the basics and add additional layers of FUN.  The only bad thing is that I have this game prepared as a Christmas gift for my kids and have to wait another week before I will be able to play it.  

A month later:  a great game which is a huge success with almost all new players.  Tech cards add another nice touch.  

Cannot wait for an expansion.  Hope to see Plant, Worm, Seeker, Judge, Deuce, Wrack, Terrorist, Sniveler, Fungus, Boomerang, Bully, Laser.   

Preferred optional rules:
- Tech
- Reverse cone
- Two aliens per player / hidden powers

RATING: 8.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Only played once and could be talked to into giving it at least one more try. But in my one go there just wasn't much fun.

[Note: have no played twice. The second time wasn't any more fun than the first.]

You have no choice over who you attack, meaning this isn't a game with much strategy. But there doesn't seem to be much incentive for people to form alliances either because of how combat works. You can contribute a maximum of 4 ships to an ally but cards and abilities make an order of magnitude bigger impact on combat resolution (with card value up to 40). Whether an alliance worked out or wiped you out seemed to be dumb luck hinging on the initial deal, so why ever risk it?

Combat comes down to blind bidding but the cards go from 0 to 40 (plus Negotiation), though after a few rounds of combat you at least get to know what flares are in whose hands.

Joining in alliances is the only thing preventing lots of downtime in between your turns.

RATING: 10
My best sci-fi game so far
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Instant hit, since I received it. I love this game. Sadly it has one major flaw, and it is not in the game design itself, I mean it has stood the test of time for decades. But it is in the fact that the game will either be super fun, or super slow/boring/anger-inducing dependent on who is at the table.

The game itself is very simple to understand, and the goal is to establish five foreign colonies on different players home worlds. You are allowed to make alliances to help conquer said planets, allowing people to colonize with you, or they can help defend, and in victory get rewards by drawing more cards. Of course you can both simply negotiate, and trust in each other to do so as well, but once those cards turn over, all bets are off. And here is what makes the game, the negotiation and alliances you make, and of course, break, over the course of the game, and the aliens, which in turn, break the game and allow for so many unique and different games. No game of Cosmic will be the same and each will have a unique story to tell. Some quibbles I have is there are some aliens who are leaps and bounds stronger than others, and some who are almost worthless compared to others. But now with nearly 200 aliens to choose from(with all the expansions) it's easy to just cull those out and have fun, unique, interactive, etc. aliens to choose from. 

Key thing to remember with Cosmic, is that as long as you keep the backstabbing, trickery, guile, etc. in the game you will have a fun time. However, that can't be said for everyone. The rule I follow, is once the game ends, everything said at the table goes with it and we are all friends afterwards, but when anger escalates after the game then we have a problem. This can, and should apply to every game, but Cosmic makes it come out more so due to having someone you trust, stab you in the back while they play an attack card next to your negotiate.  Do not take the game seriously, remember at the end of the day you're all friends and it's only a game. 

Cause of this, I have found the sore losers of my group and the cocky, trash talking, toxic players of my group who I will not play Cosmic, and actually, almost any other game with, due to their behavior. So in a sense I have Cosmic to thank for that, in showing me who the true gamers are, and who the losers are. 

The game is best played with 6 players, so Incursion is the expansion I recommend buying with the base game outright. 5 players is really good, and 4 is ok. 3 I wouldn't touch with a 20 foot pole. 

As far as expansions are concerned if I had to rank them:
*Incursion - Adds a sixth player, and rewards deck
*Dominion - Definitely suited for CE vets, but adds more cards for the rewards deck and really good aliens
*Eons - Probably the most advanced Aliens in the set, suited for veterans, but also the most varied
*Conflict - Great set of aliens, adds another player. 7 player Cosmic works very well
*Alliance - weak set of aliens, but good enough, but not as a first purchase
*Storm- Weakest of all the expansions, Very uninteresting aliens. Only purchase if you must have everything Cosmic
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
Going in to this game, I had high expectations (it is so many people's G.O.A.T. game) and a lot of fear (never meet your heroes: what if I hate it?). And now? Well, it may be my G.O.A.T. too. This game does so many things so well. Don't like direct conflict? The deck decides for you! Don't like your alien's special power? How about one of these other two hundred! Don't like games that feel the same every time? Don't worry, this one is never the same game twice! Dealt a hand of crap cards? Bluff your way out! Hate bluffing? Muscle your way through! The variety of powers, the back and forth, the shared victories, the negotiation...everything just crashes together and instead of discord, you get near perfection. I absolutely love, love, love this game. Fantasy Flight has also done a gorgeous version of it in the current edition. What a masterpiece.

RATING: 8.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
This game is wild chaos.  Players must try to make the best use of their alien race's special ability.  It is zany fun in big groups with several players, each breaking the rules in different ways.  It is entertaining to observe the dynamics of the interaction of the different alien races' abilities.  The game has strong replayablity because there is a huge number of different races and they are very different from each other.  Every play is different from all the plays that have come before.  Some of the races are much more powerful than other races, so it doesn't have some precisely engineered play balance.  I would assert that the broad diversity of alien races and unquestionable imbalance between races is a strength of the game and makes it much more interesting.  Definitely don't pass up a chance to try this game if you haven't played it.  Also, the game deserves merit for fast setup, relatively not too long play time, and fast cleanup. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3.85
Goofy fun with the right group (which, fortunately, I had) but not for the gameplay.  Short enough that if others want to play, I'll play, but I'd never choose it.

RATING: 2.5
Very few games have fallen so far in my rankings as I've grown as a player. I used to love Cosmic Encounter. Nowadays, I have difficulty seeing the point in it. It's random chance baked on top of random chance. The parts that aren't random are largely based around trying to convince people that no no no, you aren't the real threat, it's Jim over there! He's the real threat! Add in the fact that very few solo wins seem to come about, and those that do are almost always unsatisfyingly based on how strong their aliens and cards were.

There are some fun memories I have from CE (i.e. stealing the whole discard with classic filch, and then stealing a cosmic zap for the win). If you asked me to play it now though, I'd need to be either really drunk, or really trying to fit in with a new group.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
OWNED SINCE 2011   
This is a fun and unpredictable game. My kids 8+ really enjoy this game. We like how players can "invite alliances" when attacking and defending. We also like how your opponent is randomly chosen. It makes it easier to attack someone without hard feelings. There are a lot of different racial abilities, some of which are difficult to understand and use for the smaller kids. To fix this problem, we simply limit the younger kids to races they can understand and use. The only problem I have with this game is that it's success really depends on your gaming group. This is one of those games where people have to play cut throat and fast. If you don't, or if you have people who constantly making the same alliance, this game becomes very repetitive. This is a social game first, and your ability to talk and convince people is what makes this game work. Because of the age group of our kids it is not too fun and does not see a lot of table time.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Clearly the game not for me.  Simple, repetitive and all in all... boring.  On paper it looks good, but negotiations, alliances etc. turn out to be pretty straightforward and not too exciting.
  I like all these concepts of races with unique abilities and artifacts with special powers, but I'd like to see them used better, in more interesting way.  For me - wasted ideas.

And one element disqualifies the game aside from my personal preferences: shared victories.  They make the game boring and BROKEN.  It's very easy to ally with sb and win collectively.  Thus winning does not depend on the skills, but on the sheer fact if you (or your opponents) managed to ally.  Win in alliance is easy and totally unsatisfactory.

--

FFG version is way more convenient to handle than AH version, which I played too.  It has also many features introduced after the original was released (like flares) so that's a big plus for CE fans, but not for me.  I just don't care to explore the game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

I foresee playing this game for many years to come.

RATING: 9
What an incredibly fun and intense game! My first 3 games were played with all different types of gamers from casual to Euro to Ameritrash and it was loved by all. After each game we talked for 10-15 minutes about great moments and strategies that happened during the game. Then, we looked at the unused alien races and daydreamed about our next play. Because of those races, no two games will ever be the same. And also because of them, I thought the game would be imbalanced (some aliens are way better than others), but that is not the case. The seemingly strongest race can easily lose if everyone is careful and allies against him at the right time.

RATING: N/A
BCTM - Hasbro/Avalon Hill version
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This is a classic game.  The core mechanics are pretty straightforward.  On each turn you point the cone at the token's on someone's planet, you throw in some tokens, both sides ask for allies to join their side in return for rewards, each side plays a number card, the highest total wins.  If the attacker wins, the attacking tokens slide onto the planet.  The first to get five such bases wins the game.  The fun part is the wild array of alien powers and cards and moon effects that add together to a chaotic but fun game.  You basically look for broken combos and steamroller over the opposition or you pull out a surprise move and slide into victory.  In high school we played this non-stop.  These days there are many other games I'd rather play (which are either more amusing or more thoughtful) but it's still a game I would enjoy playing.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Cosmic Encounter is a game that is broken on purpose. Some players start the game with an advantage thanks to their powers and the cards they hold, even if the score track says everyone is at zero.

It is the goal of the other players to fix the game, making sure the players with the advantages don't win - while still winning for themselves.

It's a unique game filled with negotiations, backstabbing, and savvy play that always seems to lead to moments that genuinely surprise.

It's not a game for everybody and it's not a perfect game, but it delivers a good time that few other games can replicate.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
game night
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Brian
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5

Between all of the different alien powers, every game is different. A lot of randomness (you are at the mercy of the cards you draw) may turn off many, but the sheer fun of this galaxy conquering game is well worth it. The relatively short playing time is also a plus.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I can't explain what makes this game so good. Some sort of emergent quality amidst all the variables. You can tell a lot about a person by how they react to this game. If you can't roll with CE, I can't roll with you.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
You have to go into this game realizing a few things:
1. The base game is okay. Trying to establish colonies on 5 foreign planets is alright.
2. If you do not like player conflict, this game is not for you. You WILL be attacking/negotiating with others.
3. This game relies heavily on player interaction. If you have a quiet, timid gaming group, hopefully this game will break their shells. Otherwise, the game will be dull.

With those caveats out of the way, I will tell you this is one of my favorite games, and you will not have a more exciting time interacting with friends.  The alien powers and abilities, mixed with player dealings is what makes every play through incredibly memorable.  "Remember when Billy asked to negotiate with you so you could both jointly win and he actually attacked you instead?!"

Like I mentioned earlier, this game is not for everyone.  If you are into Eurogames that have little to no player interaction, stop here.  If you are not into being able to trick your opponents with mind games, special powers, or just straight up lies, stop here.  This game sounds very mean, but it is an absolute blast for a light, 30-45 minute game.  Even without trickery or deceit, playing that ultimate combo with powers and cards and laughing in your defeated opponents face, just to have a third player step in and wreck it all, and the fourth player steals it from the third - it just creates those, "Ha!... Oh!... Oooooooh damn!!" moments that you will laugh about and never forget.

Great, great game for fun and exciting groups who are not angered very easily.  Big thumbs up.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
A chaotic but very entertaining game, if played with the right group.
If you can't stand wild swings of luck then i would steer clear of this one.
But if you like games with personal conflict and a good laugh then don't skip this one.

RATING: 9
Loads of fun. The game doesn't stalemate as much as you think it would. There are some pretty vicious things that can happen to players in this game.

In addition the combination of alien powers can usually make each game play differently. Of course in our games the ones with stronger alien powers also seem to be the targets of the nastier artifacts, flares, and alien powers.

Hand management is also a crucial element in this game. Oftentimes you'll have 1-2 great attack cards and the rest of them will be fairly mediocre along with some negotiates that you have to decide when the correct time to use them will be.

RATING: 4
2014-11-23

Initial Rating: 7.0 (July 2010)

Cosmic Encounter was one of the first games I ever played when I got into the hobby. I rated it a 7.0 which was a  low rating at the time considering I really liked most of the new games. 

I had some fun playing the game but I never really liked it even though I love negotiation games. I feel I have way too little control, that is, the game have lots of uncontrolled luck with the alien powers and the cards.  Also it has lots and lots of gratuitous "take that", a mechanism I enjoy less and less in my games. 

On the good side, FFG did a wonderful job with the art and the game components.  I really like the alien variety assuring a great replayability factor, however many of them feel very unbalanced.

Bottom line, I don't enjoy the game.  Way too much randomness and attack the leader (guaranteeing a long game). Some of my friends love the game so I could be convinced to play again but I won't propose it ever. 

Current Rating: 4.0
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.85

RATING: 9
unique rule bending negotiation/strategy game. best expandable game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
A [b]wonderful[/b] reprinting. 

It's done very, very well and is put together by clear lovers of the original Hall of Fame game.

It's very faithful and you get a lot of goodness in the box. 

Right now, it's still a 9. I'd play this with anyone (casual gamers, friends, etc.). 

It's highly interactive, goofy, wild, and fun. It is not heavy, and that is not the purpose or goal. It's fun, casual, beer and pretzels, and messing with folk--and, it's a classic game that inspired a lot of people.

[b]The new printing:[/b]

I personally love the stackable saucers and I think the individual planets are completely fine. In fact, it makes way for easily expandable planet powers that are easily swapped out.

The game play is as classic as ever. 

The alien art is updated, but very inline with the feel of the old set (I have the West End and the complete Mayfair set).

I'm also very interested to see how the technology addition plays out.

[b]My personal question: [/b]

[Q]Is it worth buying when I have the whole Mayfair set (and the West End game of my youth)?
 
[A]If the gang at Fantasy Flight were to autograph the whole set, I'd pick it up tomorrow; I may still pick it up for the upcoming expansions and the new technology but I need to think on this a bit--should I have a 3rd set of this one game?

[b]My personal lament:[/b]
I [b]wish[/b] this could have been a cheaper game for families, but I do NOT dock Fantasy Flight for production costs or for profit--they're a business. I just lament the fact that many families could be brought into play with a cheaper entry point.


[b]I want this game to survive and flourish. It does my heart good to see this one back in print.[/b]
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
No idea why this merits a different BGG entry from the myriad earlier releases of the game. 

That said, this is a very nicely produced version of the game - much nicer than my old Games Workshop edition.

Core system is very simple. About 10 million special effects cards (by no means all of which are used in every game) add variety and longevity. It's still very chaotic and difficult to engineer a single player (as opposed to multiple player) win.

Only downside of this edition is that it's limited to 5 players - my old GW set caters for 6.

Overall, good fun and a design that has aged well.

2014-09-03 - Update: I'm dropping the rating of this from 9 to an 8. It's a great game, and with the right group it is absolutely a 9, but it is so group dependent, and many of the people I play with just don't seem to mesh well with it.

2017-11-06 - And it drops again. I think I will probably end up selling this one. It's a good game, but it just doesn't mesh well with my current gaming tastes.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Thanks Tom Vasel for his useful top 100.

Now that I'm giving CE a 10, it makes me want to derate all other games. I'd rate it 20 if I could. It's not a brain burning game, but still, it's extremely fun (something I didn't know it could exist).

Many people (including T.Vasel) report that CE gets broken with 3 players, but We've been enjoing it with 3 players consistenly. Maybe, the key for this is that we play it maturely, and we have no problem about making an alliance with somebody and backstab him later. It's just a game after all.

RATING: 9
Cosmic Encounter remains highly ranked after 30+ years and has been reprinted multiple times for good reason: it offers an unparalleled gaming experience. Accessible rules, strong theme, bluffing, timing of making/breaking alliances, dynamic decisions, tactical card play, scores of alien races, etc. Of course, where this game shines is in the interaction. Every session generates memorable moments like no other game. A unique, valuable, and influential contribution to hobby.

RATING: 5.5
Conquer and settlement game that includes the possibility of cooperation. Different races keep things interesting… but the power cards you draw can determine success or failure. And if luck is against you, it's a one round game.

BIG PLUS: possible combinations, involves all players
BIG MINUS: heavy luck factor in the cards, re-enticement level is a bit low

RATING: 9
I have watched a lot of the dice tower top ten videos and other videos and I had been hearing Cosmis Encounter, Cosmic Encounter, Cosmic Encounter and I was thinking jesus what is so special about this game, so I take a look and I see just some planet tiles and little pieces, where are the cool armies and ships?

Were is the vast amounts of space to explore and take over, nowhere to be seen...


Fast forward a few months and someone pulls it out at a board game club I am at and asks if I want to play so of course intrigued I say yes.


I won both games in a row and completely understood why it is so great it really does make the game about the people more so then whats going on on the boards, so much interaction.

RATING: 9
FFG comes through with another stellar (*snicker*) remake of a classic game. With all the included aliens and optional stuff like tech, this should be almost infinitely replayable. Too bad they didn't make it for 6 players right out of the gate, instead of putting that in a later expansion. 

I've had a lot of success introducing this as a group game to nongamers, several of whom have gone on to buy their own copies.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
There's a lot to like AND a lot to loathe about this game, depending on who you are. I understand those who give it a 10, but I also can see why someone would rate it a 3. For me it embodies many things to love about classic American game design (complex interactions of variable powers, direct confrontation and high interaction, the possibility of unlikely and remarkable outcomes) as well as elements that can make classic American designs weak (no timing mechanic - so wildly different play lengths, not much room for advance planning or strategy, inconsistency of play experience). In Cosmic, the special powers don't just tweak the rules for each player, they make almost an entirely different game each time. There's great replay-ability because of it. Really what sets this game apart from other variable powers games is the ability to form alliances. It tends to even out the imbalances of the base powers, although can increase game length undesirably as players beg and cajole for support.

An objective issue with this game? When a player gets on the verge of winning, the other players gang up out of necessity, so the game drags on until almost all players are on the verge of winning. Even with all the variety in the game, this pattern seems to play out consistently and is hard to avoid.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 2
This is an extremely chaotic game. What little strategy the game has is completely undermined by the destiny deck and the negating abilities of others via race abilities or special cards. On top of that the battle mechanic is essentially war, high card wins. The whole game is about tactical negotiation; I don't particularly care for negotiation so this one didn't do much for me. Not sure why everyone is so wowed by this. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Simply put, one of the best board games ever made.  Cosmic Encounter's simple premise and mechanics makes it extremely adaptable and thus, a similar but unique (and usually remarkable) experience is had every single time it gets put on the table.

If you're looking for a game on game night that doesn't just inspire creativity strategy and social interaction, but REQUIRES these things for one to achieve his/her goal, then look no further than Cosmic Encounter.  For some, forcing social interaction into your games in this way may be a turn off, but Cosmic encounter seems to strike the perfect balance of force vs will.  I guarantee that if you and your company are willing to play within the spirit of the game, you will have a great time attempting to conquer each other.

RATING: 10
If wonk has a center, it is here, in Cosmic Encounter. Infuriating to players who like machine-builders, maths, multi-turn strategies. In other words: control-dissolving. A game of "giving in", like flying, like death. Hilarious, if viewed from the right location. If I fall into a sewer, some Roman said, that's tragedy. If I see someone else fall into a sewer, that's comedy. Cosmic Encounter is that sewer.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This game is the perfect example of "easy to learn, difficult to master."  Considering how every game you play will be completely different, prior knowledge takes a backseat to developing new strategies on the fly based on the races at play.

Some games can stagnate, some games can even bear little fun...however, for some reason, I want to KEEP playing no matter how poorly the last game may have been.  And keep in mind, this isn't because of the game itself - this is because of the races and cards dealt, how they're played...and how well you can deal with an overpowered and crushing defeat based on a few random draws. 

9 times out of 10 it's a phenomenal game once you overlook any tiny flaws you might find.

I might add, this game is MADE for 4 or more people.  While it says 3-5 on the box, 3 players can make for a truly miserable experience.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
No game has been as much of a hit with everyone I play it with. It can be strategically rich, negotiation-heavy, light-hearted and hilarious all in one game. The joint victory aspect is wonderful and helps to mitigate the "attack the leader" problem. The variety present in the alien cards is like no other game I've seen before and each game feel truly different as a result. Just wonderful - I will never say no to this game.

RATING: 10

This is usually self-correcting, as no one likes to have a powerful opponent go unchecked, so I don't knock it down a peg for its balance issues.

RATING: 6
A great imbalanced balanced. I definitely enjoy this game, but sometimes it feels more like a party game than a strategy game. The actual battle mechanic of flipping over a card is terrible in my opinion, but it seems to work okay when we're all sitting at the table trying to figure out if this guy is about to play a negotiate or an attack card. The reason I play is the insane amount of combinations of alien power cards. It keeps the game interesting and strategy different each time. Good for fun factor, but it doesn't satisfy my strategy appetite.
