RATING: 10
Simply put, given a random assortment of people, there is no other game in my collection that I am willing to teach and play more often than Cosmic Encounter. This is a game for players of all skill-levels, is fun across its playable player range (although is better with more), and plays quickly enough to never feel like it is overstaying its welcome.

No other game in my collection stuffs as much player interaction and variety between games than this one does.

If I ever knew it was going to take longer than that, I would definitely refuse to play.

RATING: 9
Finally, FFG comes out with it's version of the classic. Though I've never played other versions, the game has [b]simple conflict elements[/b] with twists which make the game unique each time.

The whole point of the game is the uniqueness of alien powers. Some are obviously stronger than others, but even the weakest race and pull a victory. Players receive a good balance of benefits from attacking and defending.

Though it's [b]not epic or requires master-planning ingenuity, it's player interactive and quick enough to make things interesting.[/b]
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Simple alien-conquering-the-world game, but loads of fun. A big part of the game is breaking the rules with various races and metagaming your way to victory. My friends loved the lore and flavor text and ideas behind each race. The theme really comes through very well despite the rules being so easy to teach and learn.

Components are fantastic in the FFG version, and dozens of different alien races combine to make the game's replayability almost endless.

RATING: 7
You can clearly see that the game could take forever to play, but with the right crowd this is quite delightful. Design has many brilliant choices. I like especially that the game chooses who you're going to attack each turn; strong, but at the same time not too heavy negotiation aspects; that the game is inevitably going to end and can possibly do that pretty quickly. Thanks to a lot of asymmetrical alien powers there's plenty of replayability and making the alien ships stackable is just genial.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I can certainly see why so many people enjoy this, but there is too much chaos for my taste. I enjoyed myself, but I can't tell if that's because I won or not. My impression is that the game probably works best with players of equal experience. In fact, if an experienced player is playing n00bs, he might consider sitting out and providing advice to the players.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This is a game I enjoy but it hasn't seen much playing time strictly because I often don't have the group size to make a good game.  It does not scale well for smaller groups and I would never play with > 4 players.  The diversity of alien species and powers is mind boggling and will keep this game replayable until I die.  The gameplay is smooth once you understand the benefits of assisting in attack/defense which for some reason has been confusing in each play I've had (newbies have a hard time understanding this).  My knock on this game is that the end game can definitely drag out.  It appears that most games will come down to most players needing one more victory point to win and everyone blocking everyone else from getting it.  Others have referred to it as the "I'm not winning" philosophy.  Convince others you are behind, get assistance, catch up, then become the target.  Ultimately I hope to play this more. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

6 players

RATING: 8.2

RATING: 10
（SSW）
With
Cosmic Encounter: Cosmic Incursion (2010)
Cosmic Encounter: Cosmic Conflict (2011)
Cosmic Encounter: Cosmic Dominion (2014)

感想：
- 互動性很高的遊戲，每一round玩家的行動，基本已影響著遊戲勝負。
- 絕對比外表有深度。
- 遊戲的長度絕對比你想像的快很多！！
- 遊戲基本來說就是遇敵->遊說同盟->決戰->收成，過程簡單，但由遊說，到最後是否一戰，也是關鍵，感覺很緊湊。
- 可惜節奏太快，對於新玩家可能不知道怎麼回事時，遊戲已經完結。
- 可以創作這麼多不同的外星種族超利害，看看背景也是樂趣之一

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I mostly like heavy euros and I usually dislike games with too much luck or cutthroatness. However, this is my favorite game of all time. It doesn't feel like you're playing a board game. It feels like you're a leader of an alien civilisation and try to negotiate with other leaders to take over colonies. The card play is simple but so much fun. The replay value is infinitive, even more with some expansions. You're never a leader of the same raze in the same kind of universe. Everyone should at least try this game. Not everyone likes it, but I know a lot of people have this as their favorite game.

RATING: 9

You're an alien that needs to land their UFOs in other planets, for what? Up to you (obviously other than the games objective). RATING: 9
First published in 1977, this clever and simple game has a lot of character. Driven by a 'prisoners dilemma' mechanic that I have not seen in other games it has appeal for both gaming novices and veterans alike. 

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
3-5 (3-6 c дополнением)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Let's get this straight: Cosmic Encounter is extremely random at its core. But like any good game with a high degree of luck, there are key mechanisms which allow players to exert control over it. In here, players mitigate luck through diplomacy and treachery.

Because, don't get fooled, Cosmic Encounter is all about negotiating, bluffing and backstabbing. This is no space conquest game, not by a long shot. The distinct alien species and their powers are mostly chrome, though they also inject the game with a good dose of variety and unpredictability. What each special power does is give the player a tool to mitigate luck, by allowing him a greater degree of control over a specific in-game mechanism. But, in the end, games will be won and lost at the negotiation phase.

Cosmic Encounter is weird and chaotic, yes, but that's precisely what makes the game unique, as its chaos can be harnessed with diplomacy. And backstabbing.

Rating: :star::star::star::star::nostar:
Optimal number of players:
:thumbsup:5
:thumbsdown:3

[i]For more information on how I rate games, [geekurl=/user/Kodeir]go to my profile[/geekurl][/i]
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5

RATING: 6
[size=12][b]Top 200 board games list[/b][/size]

[size=12][b]Why I like Cosmic Encounter:[/b][/size]
+ The huge variance in Cosmic Encounter (especially with the expansions) means that each game should be different.
+ I am not a fan of games that lack a consistent set of rules. Cosmic Encounter has variable player powers that change the rules but I do not consider this mechanism in regards to this complaint. In short, the game seems to have a consistent set of rules. 
+ The games I have played did not drag on.
+ There are decisions to make.
+ The game has high replayability with all of the different ways the game is set-up.
+ I can tolerate the mechanics

[size=12][b]Why I dislike Cosmic Encounter:[/b][/size]
- My main criticism is that the game is not balanced. They cannot have tested all of the different alien interactions. Therefore some of the games work well and others are a waste of time. In one of the games I played two players formed an alliance and won the game without any of the other players getting a turn. The other players hence wasted their time playing that game. I am currently deciding to rate this game based on the games that work well otherwise I'd be rating this a 1.
- The game is somewhat hard to teach to new players, especially if they are played with an advanced alien.
- The game has variable levels of players involvement

[size=12][b]VERDICT:[/b] Sometimes willing to play this game[/size]

RATING: 8
Cosmic Encounter is a game I always love to play.  It is certainly not a very strategic game, but it makes for some fond memories.  With its expansions, it is playable by very large groups, and it often serves as an enjoyable alternative to a party game.  The hundreds of alien races ensure that no game ever plays the same as any other.  Components are top-notch, rules are fairly simple to learn, and gameplay is fast and chaotic.

Most of my plays have been 3-player games with my kids, which is not ideal, but I'm calling this a 10 anyway.  This is currently (2009-10-31) the game I want to play with them most.

The saving grace is that it plays in under an hour. If I ever have an experience with this that proves me wrong, the rating's going down.

---

Update 12/7/2014: Well after a handful of games that left a bad taste in my mouth I have to say this game is really player-dependent. It really drags if people refuse to come for a joint win. Also sometimes you are given a hand of cards that is really unplayable and demoralizes you to the point you don't want to play the game anymore, especially when you have only 1-2 colonies and several people tie for 3-4 colonies. Then again, sometimes you get an unexpected win after a long grinding, but I just wish the game was a bit shorter. 

Also own the 3 expansions that give +1 player, just too lazy to list them out.

RATING: N/A
In Cosmic Encounter, each player is the leader of an alien race. The object of the game is to establish colonies in other players' planetary systems. Players take turns trying to establish colonies. The winner(s) are the first player(s) to have five colonies on any planets outside his or her home system. A player does not need to have colonies in all of the systems, just colonies on five planets outside his or her home system. These colonies may all be in one system or scattered over multiple systems. The players must use force, cunning, and diplomacy to ensure their victory.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
This is the second time I play the game. I played the older game and gave my first comments there. Playing a newer game did not helped improve the game.

Now I am going to say something a bit offensive:

"I would be more excited to play Snakes and ladder than playing cosmic encounter."

Yes the game is that bad.

At least in snakes and ladder, I could be excited to roll high while in cosmic encounter, if you start with a shitty hand, that is all you are going to get for the whole game since there are little ways to draw cards.

You might say that cosmic encounter has much more decisions to make than in snakes and ladder. In fact yes, you have more decisions, but I should rather say, you have an illusion of decision. 

Most of the time, when you have a choice between A and B you get in situation where either the choice is obvious or whatever the choice you take the result is the same. So you are not taking any decisions at all. So I would say that in a game, you will take an average of 2 to 5 decisions.

Now in order to camouflage the bad game design they have added tons of special abilities to make sure that every game is so different that you won't realize that the core mechanics are bad.

Special abilities could be compared to rolling 3d4, 1d4+1d8, 3d6 keep 2, instead of rolling 2D6. They all have various odds, but it the ends it gives almost the same results and it is always the same crappy game under it.

So a very horrible game where I really don't understand why people like it.

RATING: 10
[u]Awards:[/u]
[b]Game of the Con - 2008[/b]
[b]Game of the Year - 2008[/b]
[b]Special Award for Gaming Awesomeness - 2013[/b]

[u]Comments:[/u]
This is THE edition of Cosmic Encounter. Everything is top notch, the artwork, the components, the clarity of the rules. It is the greatest game I have ever played. It really does go to "11"

[u]Comments Update:[/u]
CE is by far and away the greatest board game that has ever been made. If you disagree with me I'll play my Cosmic Zap and then you will have to agree with me. There, I am glad we got that out of the way right off the bat. FFG has done an amazing job of updating this classic game and making available to thousands of new fans all over the world. The chaotic game that inspired hundreds of other designs really shines through. True to its form CE is never the same game twice, and is the only game that has caused me to name a few of the epic sessions I have played in the past. CE draws out the player and forces them to be able to adapt to the game in front of them, and the players around them. I will never ever tire of playing CE, and for that it gets the Special Game Award for Awesomness for 2013.

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A classic.  I don't know of any game like it.  Very interactive.  Lots of laughter, and of table talk.  Often leaves me desiring to play a meatier game right after playing it (where I would feel more in control of my chances of winning).  But I have a soft spot for such a unique, interactive, and varied game.

The FAQ would require a FAQ: some answers are not very clear (see http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/497563/better-review-of-faq-1-0-more-errors-than-origin).  Similarly, the text on the cards has not been thoroughly proofread (compare to Magic: tG, where errors are extremely rare, comparatively).  The French translation is not written in a perfect French.  All in all, I feel like FFG (or Edge) did not do an excellent job.

The components are fine, but not top notch (compare to Mr Jack and its nice wood, its thick cards and mounted board; compare to Space Hulk 2009 and its compact cardboard; compare the style of the cards to that of Magic: tG, or RftG; the style in CE is "old"; the insert is made of relatively thin cardboard).

The rules are relatively clear, but leave some obvious missing parts.

First play: I would recommend to make up for the teaching time by using the 4 planets/4 foreign colonies variant.  Having the Encounter deck "statistics" player aid was great, I believe: players were able to better gauge the strength of their hand.  I think that I should mention that the hand goes back to 8 when you don't have Encounter cards, so that people can strategize with this fact (like: I don't care if my lousy hand gets depleted…).

Advice:
- For new players: 4 worlds for the first game PLUS telling the players that this is an *introductory game* may be the best way to play.  The upside is that the game does not last too long despite the rule explanations.  The downside is that players have fewer chances of using their power and of experiencing nice situations.
* Rule explanations:
- Go through one encounter, with only the Attack and Negotiate cards as an example (all 3/4 combinations).
- Show the page with the distribution of cards, so that players get a feel for what they will get.  Emphasize the fact that CE is a card game: most of the military power comes from the card, not from the ships.
- Mention the other cards briefly.  Show and mention that the Cosmic Zap might be particularly useful, and that any player can play it; this can be a way of making allies, of negotiating a truce with the recipient of the aid, etc.  Since the other cards are quite clear, they are mostly self-explanatory, and players can start sooner to play.
- Mention the fact that the 
- Have everybody read his power aloud (mandatory or not, short and long text).  Thus, players get to know each other, and will be able to make better decisions.  Players can ask questions, at this point.  Since they had the encounter example, they know what the phases mean.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Jeder Spieler spielt eine Alienrasse, die versucht sich im Cosmos auszubreiten.
Wer am Zug ist zieht eine Karte, auf der beschrieben steht, wen er anzugreifen hat. Dann darf er belibige Spieler einladen mit anzugreifen um Kolonien zu gründen. der Verteidiger läd ebenfalls Verteitiger ein um seine Kolonie nicht zu verlieren bzw. die Helfen bekommen dafür Handkarten/Raumschiffe.
Beide Spieler spielen verdeckt eine Karte und decken sie gleichzeitig auf. Die Zahl der Karte wird zu der Anzahl der Raumschiffe addiert und die höhere Summe gewinnt. Dabei gibt es noch ein paar Sonderkarten die es unberechenbarer machen sollen.
Wer 5 (4 im kurzen Spiel) Kolonien besitzt, beendet das Spiel. Wer die meissten Kolonien besitzt gewinnt es dann.
Alles in allem war ich doch recht enttäuscht von dem Spiel. Ich dachte dass da mehr Diskussion herrscht, mehr Intriege, hinterhältige Absprachen und nicht eingehaltene Verhandlungen... Das gab es schon und die 3-4 Momente dwaren recht spaßig, aber leider lange nicht so gut/viel wie ich anfangs dachte. Schade eigentlich!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
Temporary Rating: 8

I like it very much. The strategies seem endless, but I've only played 2 games and with the basic game rules (without flares and/or artifacts and only with green aliens). But some things I think did seem aparent at least in the few games:

1. The game seems too fast. both games I played ended in only about 40 minutes. I guess the adition of deeper strategies will fix this, also the negotiation thng didn't clicked a lot on the first game, so I also blame the overpowerness of the "Parasite" power in the first game. 
2. We lost lots of ships in the two games. This, I think, was because we didn't grasped the strategy involved in the encounters in the first games.
3. The card rules were the most difficult to learn throughout the game, there's a lot of exceptions and rules that are apparently easy to learn but with the flow of the game they're lost, like the fact that you only have the 8 first cards in your hand.
4. We missed (most of the time) the rule to have a second encounter when we won the first one on our turn.

There's a lot involved in Cosmic Encounter, but I am willing to learn it all and my group seems enthusiastic about the game and all it's possibilities too.

EDIT: I've posted my definitive rating, I might change it when I play with the yellow and red aliens and when I include Technologies to the game, but 9 seems a really good reating for this game and I'll tell you why:

This game is awesome. I just played with Flares, Artifacts and the deepness and variability becomes noticed in every way. The subtle variations to the game rules become really big when you know how to use them to your favor. For example I was playing a game where the Sorcerer was used and the player explained the power. When I saw that player using a Negotiation card and turning it against his enemies, I knew that this was the kind of game I love. 

All the rules are subject to breaking in every manner, and that's somehow refreshing. 

I haven't even used half of the options on this game and I already love it. I can't wait until my next game!

Edit:

I have to give this a 10, I just have to. The interaction of powers, the variants, the flares, the negotiation and the relative quickness of the game are some of the things that make this game awesome. I'm up to the yellow level on aliens and it gets more and more interesting. The sheer amount of possibilities is what makes me want to play more and more, Some of the interactions of powers are so awfully insane and hilarious that I can't really wait to pull this game out of the shelf again...
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Joe's
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This is the game that is played the most since I bought it. We leave tech cards out, nobody thinks they add something, this doesn't change anything. This is THE 10.

The interactions between the aliens makes this game, you will never get the same game twice, even with some same aliens, as all the players together make the game. Some aliens might look overpowered but in this game this will almost cause this alien to be the main target, making it less likely he will steamroll through the game.

So far the 'Human' has a 100% win rate. Very surprising as at first sight you would throw him away.

So many epic games that stay in the memories, this is why it absolutely deserves the maximum score.

RATING: 9
A very solid, deep, high octane game. I love the high social interaction, seat gripping excitement as the encounter cards are turned over, random card zaps, and just epic plays. Aliens are all unique and game is high replayable. Almost could be a 10 if the game had a much better rule book that tackles/gives examples of special scenarios and if the rules were more clear in certain conflicts. A little complicated but very fun.

Just shy of a 10, but still a very solid game.

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
What can I say that hasn't already been said? This game redefines "overpowered" and makes it awe-inspiringly fun. As I have said more than once at parties, Cosmic Encounter balances upward; every race of aliens has what feels like game-changing abilities, and the entire tempo and balance of power can hinge on a bizarre error caused by one person forgetting what sort of insanity the guy to their left can unleash. I've seen games where sure victory was snatched away by an assaulted planet suddenly exploding, where a person willed themselves into losing by swapping hands with someone who was holding onto a garbage hand due to a single valuable flare, where I literally did not get to take a second turn because everyone was so scared of my aliens that they didn't stop the aliens sitting to my right from establishing colonies. Negotiation is at the core of this game, but it's also very random, and I personally find that to be a fun, peanut-butter-and-chocolate sort of experience.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
This game is phenomenal. I picked it up after a bunch of professional reviewers suggested it (e.g.  Shut Up & Sit Down, Dice Tower, etc. -- Go watch their youtube reviews). I will expand on this review later but this is another game I can play with my non-serious gamer friends, who find games like A Feast For Odin and Power Grid absurd and over complex, and my roommates (who are serious gamers) freaking love this game and, in the days after it arrived, my roomates and I would play it until 4am every night . 

Pros:

>This game is simple and I can explain all rules in less than 5 min. 

>This game is fun, in almost every game I have played.  Everyone has laughed a lot and immediately asked to play again. In fact, I have never played a single session of this game, every time I open the box, I play it at least twice before putting it away.

>This game is more replayable than any other game I have ever seen. With 50 alien races out of the box, which all play the game differently, you will most likely never play the same game twice - especially if you get an expansion. 

Cons:
> Some races are better than others, which can make the game un-fun for the other people at the table
> Will add more here - running out of time for writing.

RATING: 10

RATING: 6
One of the few games from the 1970's that is worth playing today.  It is a pure negotiation game with radically asymmetric powers for each player.  You have a hand of cards that allows you to negotiate or engage in combat.  You can call for support from other players.  I like the game, it is very solid, but don't feel I need to own it.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Great mechanic. Not concrete (very abstract), lots of negotiation, bluffing/lying, and heavy interaction.

Seems like a fast playing RISK game mixed with negotiation element (DIPLOMACY) plus the insertion of bizarre characters makes it seem a tad like a CCG/Domaine-type game, but nevertheless VERY fun.

Worth playing someone else's copy until Small World and Nexus Ops have been played more. Perhaps consider Nexus Ops team play.

Each games is varied and different (like SMALL WORLD).

CONS:
-- doesn't play with 2 (however there may be a variant - which doesn't seem to have much appeal); okay with 3 (HOWEVER, Sweet spot is repeatedly said to be 4)
-- has a fantasy/space theme (but not too overwhelming)
-- expensive
-- Some cards are SO overpowering that it can make the game seem unbalanced (unfair)
-- BIG CON: Can promote teaming up (especially in a 3 player game)
-- BIG CON: Because of the cutthroat aspect (similar to Diplomacy) it rewards folks who are outright liars (while this may make the game exciting, it certainly will hurt feelings and can potentially create ill feelings)

PROS:
-- very dynamic
-- lots of interaction; encourages a lot of communication
-- very fun
-- the game has been around for 30 years

NB: The older Avalon Hill version of the game can frequently be found for under $15. However, the new FF game has Alien cards which SIGNIFICANTLY improves the game play and strategy and fun factor

Good reviews: Fun seems to be the overriding theme (even though the game can be played with more strategy): http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/547153/one-of-the-most-fun-games-i-ever-played-even-thoug)
http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/501233/review-of-the-basic-game

"Don't buy this game if" review: http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/519113/dont-buy-his-game-if-6-cosmic-encounter

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Like a more interestingly-themed Diplomacy, but every game's different since you have 50 races to choose from (just in the base game).  And it auto-balances since you have to get help from other players (like Munchkin), so the weakest player will be getting help and not messed with.  As a result, kinda meh about it, would play, and only maybe would get just because interaction is always the best kind of play, and super simple rules make it great to show complete beginners how fun board games are, and there's so much variety.

Bought it a guy from CABS for $30, brand new, which was awesome - randomly saw his post on FB.

Traded away at Origins'16 Math Trade. Works really well for both players that need a bit of guiding through strategy, or want some interaction without serious diplomacy (gotchya' play). Just didn't get its hooks in me or the group, though.

RATING: N/A
青年店
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 1
The gaming equivalent of "madcap" comedy. Massively unbalanced (albeit deliberately), vast amounts of luck, and can drag on for ages (2 hours on one excruciating occasion). I have given this game a few chances, but all it has delivered are some of the most unpleasant gaming experiences I have ever had. I want to make meaningful decisions and have influence over my own destiny, rather than have the whimsical vaguaries of group politics and negotation completely determine the outcome... and if the outcome must be down to those things then the 'game' needs to last 30 minutes at most so I can move on to something more interesting.

There is no substance to justify it lasting any longer, with probably the most abhorrent feature being the lack of control over who to attack on your turn. This is the one game I absolutely veto in my regular gaming group. It's a bit like gathering around a table, and taking it turns to say 'I would like to win, will you support me?' until someone gets bored and agrees (that would be me, at first time of asking). I'm just astonished it is currently top 100. If you want to play a negotiation game then I'm the Boss! is much better, i.e. it actually functions as a game. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Played this recently after many years. A complete waste of time. My character was so powerful, no-one could stop me winning even when they all worked together. I guess some people call this complete lack of balance "zany". I call it "shit".

RATING: 8
4-5+; Best: 5; 60-120 min; 10+; 2.55/5; 2008
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.7
Not really a strategy game in my opinion, but loaded with interaction and tactic decisions. Most of all it is tons of fun playing it and it finishes with in an hour. There is a fait bit of randomness in the set-up depending on what alien you aquire and the attack pods you recieve, but then it mostly come down to the tactical moves if you win or not, even though you might have to go for a combined win with a superior alien. 
The replayabillity is huge and two games seldom are alike, even with the same aliens present. 
Defenitely worth a try when provided the oportunity.

I think I can take this into any room where people are willing to play a game and show people a good time.  I took it with me on a Christmas Eve to a fairly formal dinner a few years ago.  At first people were scoffing at the idea of a board game on Christmas Eve.  ...We still play the game every Christmas Eve and we still talk about games years later.  ..It's THAT GOOD!

Cosmic Encounter: Kosmische Herrschaft

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Own this and Cosmic Incursion, Cosmic Conflict and Cosmic Storm. 

The game doesn't work for everyone, as it requires a lot of talking and interacting with the other players. If you and your group do not have a willingness to deceive and be deceived, have things shatter around you as you try to make a plot last till the end, then it might not be for you.

If you do, then this game offers basically infinite replayability. Every single game can be different. One game might last 20 minutes, the next one an hour. No two are ever really the same. As you get to know the game, more strategies unfold and you can start to use the knowledge to bluff other experienced players into thinking something completely different is going on. 

A gleeful, playful gem of a game that hasn't gotten old, even after what I can only guess at is around 200 playthroughs at the time of writing. 

Highly recommended!

You don't get the feeling that you achieved something meaningful, but, nevertheless, it's just pure FUN. It's, also, great - and easy to grasp - for kids.
The only complaint I can have is that it can drag too long with 5 or 6 players. I think 4 is the ideal number.

RATING: 9.5
Cosmic Encounter is the perfect balance of silliness, negotiation, hand management and role playing.  It's really easy to learn, the idea that who you attack is not determined by the player (generally) allows the game to have combat without the "anger."  I also really like that you can have multiple winners and regardless of the outcome, I always remember the crazy interactions and rarely who won.  Lots of fun, great with 5 or 6.

RATING: 6
I went into my first play skeptical, having burned out on the original back in college and not played it in years, but this version surprised me. It moved quickly, seemed like it was going to be over rather soon, and then went all pear-shaped and got interesting.

It's enjoyably social, and I love that the initial decision -- who to attack -- is generally made for you. Lots of twists and turns, and tons of variation in pretty much every encounter.

It's not My Jam to the Max, but it's fun.

RATING: 8
Lots of phases in a turn (i think 8) but simple and fast to execute. Combat is easy, super trump card style (bigger number wins over smaller number). A bit heavy on card management plus you need to keep in mind which phase a card may be played. There are tons of alien races with varying effects and difficulty (in usage) to choose from so I think replayability is pretty high. Its rather quick too (although it took us a while earlier since there was a lot of text to read).

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
A masterpiece of a game with near infinite variety.
The base mechanism of the game is as simple as can be : pull a card to see where you're attacking, choose how many people you want to send, and ask other people if they want to join. Then play a card with a number, highest total wins.
Where this game goes from "meh" to being a masterpiece is all the different alien races you can play. In the base game you have fifty. Each of the three expansions that are currently available add another twenty. The next expansion (Cosmic Storm) will add another twenty-five. That's a total of 135 different races, each with their own gamebreaking rule.
Now, you may think that with that many races it would be impossible to properly balance them all, and you would be right. The balancing actually is on the players who will gang up on the more overtly powerful player making this game a contest of negotiation and politics.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.9
2017 Top 100 Favorites of All-Time: #1

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
4 / 5 - Great.

Most of the fun of a big multi-player civ-building game stripped down to its bare essence and crammed into an hour or so play time. The different powers keep the strategy interesting and add spice to the negotiation element and there's just enough screwage potential to make things fun without being overly nasty. Constant need to gain new allies each turn means every player is involved in every encounter so downtime is virtually nil. Slight question mark over whether turn order is an overly big determinant in the winner, but lots of fun whether you win or loose. Could well be a 10 on repeat plays.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.2
Great little game, very good when you want something fast enjoyable with a little chaos and a little depth, without being too crazy or complex.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.99
Old school gaming and a rather streamlined space conquest game in it's purest form. The huge vast number of races offer endless replay but each race offers limited amount to take in so it's easier to manage despite players likely having to learn 1-2 new races every time they play.

What separates one game from another and the really good games from the classics is dynamic gameplay that leads to stories over the years. This game has it in spades. There were multiple moments when something would happen and one player sat there stone faced as they tried to figure out how to counter what just happened, and the rest of the players were laughing. That's the kind of game I want to play.

I really want to nitpick this game to find a weakness, but I think that's just personal opinion getting in the way. Part of me wants more complex races, but the reason for the simplicity is due to its age as a game and it works well enough as it is. Easily the best play of DaveCon 2012. That's between 16 games for those wondering.

Updated ranking based on researching about king making issues. Need more plays before I feel stronger about where to rank it.

Rating Potential: 8-9. Just need plays of full games to see about the king making issues since my one play was a partial play.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Best: 5

4, 5

RATING: 9
This is quickly moving up the charts. I may have to put this in my top 10. Even with just a single expansion there are so many combinations of cards/alien powers that the game will never play out the same way. The alien powers are in no way balanced so if you are expecting that, this is not the game for you. It's very a backstabb and conflict type game but that's part of the fun of the game. Go into this with a light heart as competitive play is not the style of this game.

RATING: 10
I love this game, the fact that the game forces you to attack players every turn takes away a certain awkwardness from board games that can make you feel like a dick when you play very agressively. The deception and dynamic formation of alliances really makes this game fun. Also, I have never played a match of this game where I had a bad time, it is one of few games where even if you are losing, you can have a great time and you still have value to contribute to the rest of the game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Cosmic Encounter is a simple game that works with pretty much any crowd. It's not a BAD game, but it's a game with a rubber band like tendency. Someone gets ahead, everyone gangs up on that player, rinse, repeat. Not a terrible game, and can be fun, but vastly overstated.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
I had heard lots of great things about Cosmic Encounter.  For awhile I was on the verge of buying it myself.  So, when I finally had the chance to play it I was excited.  The theme sounds super fun: intergalactic warfare with shifting alliances.  Great!

But then I played it.  I've never felt more like a game played me, rather than I played it, than when I played Cosmic Encounter.  Every turn I MUST attack someone, I have no choice.  The draw of a card decides whom I attack, I have no choice.  How I go about attacking the other players is largely determined by my race, I have little to no choice.  Whether I can support others in their attacks or defence is ultimately up to those other players, not me.  I'm constantly being told by either the game, the other players, or both as to what I can do, how I can do it, and when.

The only choice I have is whether I'm going to play a number or a negotiate card.  Sorry, not good enough.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.9
One of my favorite games.
True negotiation/diplomacy classic, very few games are relevant 30+ years after their release. In my collection Survive is only other game that's as old, traditional cardgames aside. Both games have had very nice anniversary editions (in case of Cosmic Encounter, FFG) that are also their definite editions. Small minus is that you need Cosmic Incursion to complete it (6th player), but the expansion also comes with some new aliens and very nice Rewards deck so.. ok. Cosmic Encounter is almost perfect game. I wish it was slightly less complex (I guess there's Munchkin for that, underrated game on BGG, but it's also missing most player interactions of CE and isn't as replayable in my opinion), but as it is, it's pretty much for gamers only, even if you leave flares out. That's fine, you can try to lure heavy strategy gamers to try this one. As far as 'gamers games' go, this is easily the most fun one.

Expansions:
+Cosmic Encounter: Cosmic Incursion
+Cosmic Encounter: Cosmic Conflict
+Cosmic Encounter: Cosmic Alliance
+Cosmic Encounter: Cosmic Storm
+Cosmic Encounter: Cosmic Dominion

RATING: 7
Was very keen to try this.  After first play, I'm not sure what to make of it.  The game was overly long and took a while to get our head around the rules / strategy.  The rules book could have benefited from a more detailed discussion than it had.  Depending on how competitive the game is it can run for a long time due to the victory conditions.

Will play again and then decide if it is with holding in my collection.  Fun game, but has a tendency to drag due to not having a fixed end game (skilled players have a tendencey keep in other in check).  I may greatly vary my rating of this with further plays.

Played with 5.  Much better than with 3.  A very chaotic game.  Really hard to control one's fate. Would play again, but no desire to keep this in my collection.  Plenty of other games I'd rather play.

RATING: 7
It's good. There are a ton of different alien races, which adds variety. Some powers feel decidedly more powerful than others, though. The luck of the draw will end up deciding more games than actually building alliances. The sheer number of different races doesn't really mean a lot of replayability, in my opinion. The replayability is there, but a lot of it feels so random that each individual variable doesn't seem to matter that much.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Good
Large variety of aliens to play, each has unique mechanics that makes the game feel slightly different each time. 

Quality components. The ships, cards, cardboard stock are all solid and look visually pleasing. 

The game tends to self balance itself, so we haven't had any runaway leader issues. 

Bad
The game has solid mechanics but this has a Munchkin-like feel in that you have to recruit other players in order to win. In the limited games we have played it has been group wins, where the couple of folks excluded were the ones playing to win by themselves. So it felt unrewarding all around. 

I have watched several gameplay videos/reviews on this game and there must be something that isn't clicking with my group. Because of this I would like to give the game another shot, but perhaps with some vet players to see how the strategy pans out.

RATING: 8
This game can go either way. On the surface it seems to be not all that interesting and with just way to many options for races and powers. With the right group of people it becomes a mass of bluffing and negotiating and working to keep the leader down. If your group doesn't understand that social aspect of the game, or their are inexperienced folks it can fall flat. When it works with the right group, its one of the best games of all time. If it didn't require the right group, I'd rate it a 10. As it stands, there are some groups I wouldn't always want to play it with.

RATING: 10

It's not complicated in rules, it's not complicated for people who are new to games, but it plays in a very rich, very satisfying way that just works.  Each time I play it, it gives me a story for months to come.  I can tell you each of my victories and defeats and how they came to be and who I pissed off and who was my friend until they weren't.

Do not get this game if you like to sit quietly by.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Negotiation + screwage = fun!

Rating rises from 8 to 9 after 7 plays.

The rulebook is astonishingly clear.  It unambiguously explains the game in a logical order and it's easy to look stuff up during the game.  It's hard to believe it's from Fantasy Flight.

The components are very good, with one exception: the score track.  It's very fiddly and as the warp tends to rotate a bit in normal play it's sometimes inaccurate as well unless you remember to adjust it whenever you touch the warp.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7.9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Tenuous - group hasn't taken to it, living on borrowed time

This is a very fun and good game for the sort of game it is. That is, a highly interactive (both on the table and above it - talking, cajoling, negotiating, begging and coercing your fellow players), chaotic (your hand of cards and the distribution of take that effects, the many alien powers, the destiny deck which decides what player you must attack), silly (again, the alien powers for example) sort of game. I can see how this game makes for poor sessions, how it really ends up with people saying "... and people say this is fun?" (only worded so much more strongly).

However, with the sort of group that takes it and runs with it, for me that would be my childhood friends, accepting the chaos, laughing at the wacky way they were just screwed something horrible, the malicious glee of backstabbing someone just because, then the game becomes a great vehicle for fun. And I like that. Its exactly what I want from the game (not every game, just the game for these sorts of occasions, see circular logic - I don't care), just something that facilitates a nice time - that can make people laugh at silly things even if no alcohol is in the picture. 

This game does that better than any other I've tried. If I am to mention negatives I'd say the worst are: 

a) this is that this falls in the category of games that is very hard to teach people not used to games - the style of game where you have the rules, then you have all these cards and abilities that break them and that's the game.

b) the way the game is prone to the ending of all players are on 4 colonies, making it drag a bit, making it feel less clever because of it. Though typically even then it's the player who I'd say "did the best" who ends up winning, for what it's worth.

A great game!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
This is meant to be a fun game, not a brain-burner, but like many games, it depends greatly on having the right group to make it fun. I have had fun playing it, but after three plays it is not something I want to come back to. At its core, the combat resolution is not very interesting (totaling ships plus combat card values), though the special powers and action cards -- which in such great numbers give the game incredible variety -- is where the combat is really decided. For me it is too much. I don't like chaotic rule-bending, which this game has in spades. A typical encounter: "I have more, I win." "Oh no you don't, because I have this special action card!" "But wait, my special action card cancels yours!" "Not so fast...!" Sigh. Does anyone want to play a game that is actually a game?

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Played FFG edition. Loved it more than any previous. The mechanics are brilliant in how they deal with forcing attacks (and randomizing who is being attacked), the possibility of shared victories, and built in "replayability" with the alien powers, flare cards, and technology. And lots of player interaction kills downtime. A fun game that plays differently every time. Only drawback, if you can say it is a drawback, is that it really needs 4+ people to play and enjoy it fully. You can play with three, but it is a different experience and can turn lopsided in the asking for allies portion.

RATING: 10
Possibly the best negotiation game ever.

The powers you can have, which depend on which race you get, are so vastly different... and fun! And yes, they are not balanced, but that's what the negotiation is there for (in part): someone got an incredible power? then don't help them when they attack, anbd ally with the player who gets to attack them, or don't negotiate with them...

So much chaos, but sooo much fun!

RATING: 7
Way too random and chaotic if all the expansions and associated cards are added in and stirred together.  

Using fewer of the expansions might be better I think as the additional cards dilute the basic Encounter cards like Negotiate and Attack cards with a lot of junky and funky situation specific cards.

Less is more I think... might still rate the game a "6" or "7" if the game was pared down to the basics.  But for now, the game is too chaotic and random for me to enjoy in it's present state with everything thrown in.

The good news... with the FFG edition, players can choose pretty much how they'd like to play.

RATING: 10
The negotiation (and backstabbing) game with no equal. An event game, and one best played with gamers willing to go the extra mile in roleplaying.

Expect to lie to your best friend, team up with your worst enemy, and have both roles (and alliances) rethought every single encounter.

Another 'essential' game -- if you're in any way interested in designing game, Cosmic Encounter is a *must play*.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Hard to believe I've never played this classic, but after a handful of five player games lately I finally see what all the fuss is about. The rules are loose in that old-school way that encourages players to define the experience themselves (negotiate is a prime example of this; it's a design choice I think most modern games would shy away from) and the alien powers provide great variety without adding too much difficulty. I could see how this wouldn't work for some- the game is all direct conflict, so if you're uncomfortable with that (as many in my various groups are, including my wife) you could have difficulties enjoying the game, and I do think it ran a bit long for my tastes. All that said, I'm looking forward to playing again.

RATING: 9
The granddaddy of modern board games. It involves competition, cooperation, bluffing, bargaining and strategy. Players take on the role of aliens with special powers, all of which are useful in their own way.

I played with my brother once, and late in the game he said he had been stealing cards all along. We all got mad at him, until he told us that he had the Filch flare card, which allowed him to steal cards. It was a genuine surprise, and he had played it beautifully.

Fantastic game. Highly recommended.

RATING: 9
Very random, very swingy, very fun.  If you want a balanced game, you are probably looking in the wrong spot.  The trick to the game is looking to see who can do what and then try to plan/swindle your way through the game and try to come out on top.  Some races are much more powerful than the others, but that's just part of the game.  Very fast to play though, and my games (even with up to 6 players) have only lasted an hour or so.  As any negotiation game, the players really make the game.  With the right group of people, this is one of the best...with the wrong it can be very stale.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Hysterical fun, infinite re-playability. I am absolutely shocked I overlooked this one all these years, and the FFG reprint makes it brilliant. I will never ever refuse a game of this, and find myself suggesting it before anything else.

Here's why: as light as it seems, and as easy as the rules are to master, this is a game that almost purely focuses on the metagame. Each round, as allies are called for and opponents weigh the likelihood that players can beat another, a rich experience of meta-game awareness develops and the negotiation, at least in my playgroup, is intense, ornery, and hilarious. Add to that the fact that a five-player game is done in under an hour and we find ourselves playing game after game in a row, shuffling and dealing out new powers, mutliple powers, playing with hidden powers for those "gotcha!" moments. It's just plain a blast - other than Diplomacy, some of the most fun I've ever had playing a game - I laugh, I cheer, I get pissed off, I get revenge, I threaten, I bribe, I make and break deals, I do nasty backstabby stuff (like call for allies insisting aloud I can win and than play low cards to intentionally lose), and I still cannot get enough. For the price, this is going to be years and years and years of endless fun with no chance of burnout. Love it.

-----------------

Edit: this game is an absolute smash hit with the teenagers at the high school gaming club I sponsor. The only other game that got such an overwhelmingly positive reaction was BSG, but given that this plays so quickly, it was an immediate success and there was instant demand for more more more more more. And to be clear - this is an ideal game to play with them - enough metagaming and negotiation to keep things interesting for me, but enough crazy chaos and comedy to give them a fighting chance against me :devil: Ratings bump to the top.

------------

Note: this gets played almost every week in gaming club and I always sit in on at least one or two games, so I have several unlogged plays of it.
------------
Though I never get tired of this, I do have to admit after hundreds of plays (so many I don't bother logging them), that it's only fun with the right group, which is somewhat of a tick against it. I will always want to play this and say yes to it, and with the right people it's a ten. With the wrong people, it's closer to a 7.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Game seems to do better with players of equal experience and understanding of the game (moreso that most other games).  Just starting to understand the draw of this game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
One of my favorite games due to the way it forces social interaction among the players. I love the fact that alliances are constantly made and broken, but due to the game deciding who must attack who, there's never any hard feelings. Great theme and, with so many alien races, every game feels unique. At roughly 90 minutes a game, it's just long enough to be satisfying without becoming boring. The only downside is the rare occasion when certain race combinations are drawn that draw out the game past its welcome.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
+2 replayability off the charts. with the combination of different alien races, it's basically a new subset of rules each game.  
+1 Love the artwork. and there's so much of it. Normally a half-pointer for me, so a full point is a lot. 
+1 Has great depth of strategy (deep but accessible), but mitigated by having the weight to match, with reasonable setup/learning time and rule complexity. 
+1 the bluffing mechanics and alliance elements in the core rules, combined with a lot of card effects, create a social element to the game which is awesome. 
+.5 there's so many mechanics that the theme isn't truly immersive - but the fantastic artwork, flavor text and variety of species do give it some sense of theme. 

-2 (up from -1) As I play with more groups, I see that the mandatory, direct confrontation in this game really seems to put a lot of players off. It seems not sufficiently softened by limited negotiation options, compensation and non-confrontational aliens. Infinitely replayable games are less fun if you need a very niche group to play them with. 


-.5 There's an element of rules lawyering which is necessary to fully explore the depth of this game - which can be jarring. This is mitigated somewhat by the crystal clear rule-book/alien cards. 


Fantastic game, with rules that seem light - but basically a new set of supplementary rules each time you play, depending on what aliens each player draws. The interplay between these rules makes the game truly great. Not for the faint of heart though. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Another game that made a terrific first impression.  The FFG version adds flexibility which I appreciate. The variability of attacks and flares can make for a disappointing game once in a while but when it works it knocks my socks off.  One of the few games I like where rule arguments are almost mandatory.

RATING: 7
Ich weiß das Cosmic Encounter in vielen Toplisten hohe Platzierungen hat. Bei mir will der Funke noch nicht so richtig rüberspringen. Okay, die Regeln sind eigentlich relativ einfach, bieten aber auch ihre Tücken. Damit will ich sagen, dass es nicht so intiutiv zu spielen ist, wie man vielleicht glauben möchte. Die vielen verschiedenen Alien Rassen und ihre Fähigkeiten sind ohne Zweifel cool, jedoch stört mich die enorme Unausgeglichenheit. Manche Fähigkeiten sind unglaublich stark, wieder andere eher wertlos. Das Spiel steht und fällt mit der Kommunikation und Interaktion zwischen den Spielern. Wer verrät wen? Wer greift wen an? Wer verbündet sich mit wem? Bisher waren die Partien in Ordnung, aber auch noch nicht die große Offenbarung.

RATING: 7
Cosmic Encounter is a great game, if you accept, that your influence over the game is somewhat small and there is a lot of randomness and take-that elements involved. Also the aliens are not at all balanced, so players need to work together against a strong oponent (Yes, unbalanced powers is a plus in this game).
Unfortunatly it is too long. Almost every expansion adds new players, but I think 5 is more than enough (better 4). The game and the downtimes get too long with more players, even leading to games, where the game is over before everyone had a turn.

I could not fit everything in the original box, so I use the box of "Shadows of brimstone" for this one, including all the expansions.

There are many expansions and the sucker that I am, I got them all, knowing that I will never be able to use all of the new (and old) content.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
[b]Like:[/b]
-Discovering new aliens for the first time

[b]Dislike:[/b]
-Very player dependent
-Too chaotic

Love the game, some of the cards and aliens are just really funny and create those excellent "WHAT?!" moments. The mechanic where you have to play every card first before you get new cards is just lovely! However, I definitely don't find it as genius as a lot of people may want you to believe.

If people don't form alliances it can be quite boring for others to just watch encounters, and some people really dislike having multiple winners (I know I used to hate them). Also, some cards and aliens are really difficult to understand, which surprised me since I consider myself a heavy gamer. This leads into a yet another thing: lots of unclear rules, which can ruin someone's planning which is frustrating.

The positives I mentioned in the first paragraph also kinda disappear once you get to know the game. The lovely "WHAT?!" moments are almost entirely gone once you've played through all the aliens and the card management becomes uninteresting when you realise you're almost always at risk of a opposing negotiate, and then (I found) it's best to just play your most powerful cards as soon as possible so the others can't snatch them. This leads me to have... kinda no positives anymore.

In the end though, it does things you won't find in any other board game in terms of unique, special powers. However, after several playthroughs, the game just doesn't surprise me anymore (that's about 10-15 plays though, so if you find that worth the money, go get this!).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I know this is a divisive opinion, but Cosmic Encounter has really been replaced by Munchkin at this point. Both games involve negotiation, player powers (inherent or otherwise), luck of the draw, and occasional cooperation, all without the shared winning conditions that Cosmic has. That all being said, I do like Cosmic Encounter, and objectively-speaking, I do feel it's a more refined game. I just feel that it's a little overlong for what it is, and the player powers are a tad more convoluted than they ought to be. For such a minimalist game, however, it really brings out the negotiation and backstabbery in a strong way.

I had my first bad game of this earlier this month. Honestly it all came down to the fact that I had not yet lost and EVERYONE at the table was determined to make sure I lost, so while it was fun for them it was not much so for me. I can't blame the game for that though - just my friends :P
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
The most impressive thing about Cosmic Encounter is its legacy. Unfortunately in a post-CCG world where "rules on components" is a given, the game does only shine as a demonstration of the truth behind most ameritrash designs: you don't even have to try to create a fair game, because no matter how screwed up a given setup might be, no matter how much one or two players look like demigods or cockroaches compared to the rest of the table, free-for-all conflict and bash-the-leader negotiation will balance the game for you. From that perspective, we're facing a game that, once all the complicated interactions have been solved and everybody understands the pecking order of alien powers in a given setup, is simply about lying on the content of your hand.

RATING: 4
I really really want to like this game, because I bought it recently, and it wasn't cheap. But the gameplay feels slow, there aren't any interesting mechanics, luck seems to dominate all decision-making, and the only tension in the game comes when you're flipping over your encounter cards to see who happened to pick the larger number. As far as I can tell, it simply isn't a very good game, and I'm not sure why it's rated so well here. 

I'm willing to give it more chances, and in fact the time I managed to play with five people, there was a glimmer of fun. But with three, it's simply a dull experience. Many of the alien powers aren't exciting at all, and alliances don't mean anything in the long term, which bothers me a little as well. It seems flawed, and while it looks great and I love the components, it doesn't save it for me. Hopefully I find something in my next few plays to raise the rating from a 4.

RATING: 6
The new 2008 version of Cosmic by Fantasy Flight Games. Having only played the basic game of this, the only rule changes were 1) the addition of reinforcement cards of value 3, allowing main players or allies to play them after cards have been revealed, and 2) the destiny deck has more variety on who you can attack. There still is a ton of luck, but the game plays quickly, and is over in under an hour. It's a great game for 1977, but it shows it's age.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Tom Vassal's tom pick out of 1500+ + Fantasy Flight + few or none expansions yet so I don't feel like I have to catch up = board game I must get. I'm not usually into the Sci-fi as much but I like it enough that I should have more sci fi games than just 2210 which is just painted-on sci fi

Update: played it online and though I liked it more than my group AND it was online I definitely see the weaknesses of this game really apparent. I simply don't think it's worth getting even if its 2 more points than our gameplay was.

In person, with perfect mood, perfect people, and great atmosphere I could maybe see this moved up to a 5.6 experience.

For a game that's purely competative like this one, it's remarkable how poor some of the balancing is. That says I admire this games accessibility and quickness for what it is.

RATING: 9
A largely chaotic and very fun game.  The Destiny deck controls who you must attack, so even if you want to lay waste to someone else, you may or may not be able to.  This doesn't mean that you have no control over your alliances, as that is where a lot of the game centers.  Some good twists to be had there.  The sheer number of the alien races creates a lot of replayability in this game, and I can see myself enjoying this one for a long time.  Good job on the remake FFG.  Thank you!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
Totally pushes all of the wrong buttons for me. I have heard so much about this game over the years and finally had a chance to play it with the FF version just released. The one positive thing I can say about the game (other than the expected high production value of Fanstasy Flight) is that it ended fairly quickly (though it still wore out its welcome). Variable powers may have been an innovation back in the day but it's been done much better since. Player's have too little influence on the outcomes of the battles so it becomes just a guessing game heavily controlled by who has the better cards and/or power. I would rather give all involved a differently-sided die and then roll off to see who wins. Argue if you will about the social aspects of the game, but that part is also just another ingredient of luck thrown in the pot. Consider me unimpressed.

RATING: 8
I'm a bit on the fence with this one.

The first time I played this was with 5 players and it was amazing! It was definitely a 10 at that point.

However since then I have played it 2 other times with 4 players and it was simply okay. I'd probably rate it a 6.

I also played about a half of a 4 player game with some people that aren't as big into heavier games and it was a total nightmare. 

The fun this game offers is really dependent on the number and type of people that are playing. If anyone is over analyzing their turns it can grind to a halt.

So I love what this game has to offer and I'm giving it an 8 for now because of how awesome my first game of it was.

I promised myself that in the future I am only going to play this with 5 players so maybe my rating will change after I get more of those games under my belt.

RATING: 9
Hang on! An FFG game where the rules aren't a complete mess???
The game is so simple that anyone can get the hang of it after just one turn of play. Draw card to see who you must attack, send ships, ask for allies, play attack card, have resolution. If you win, you may repeat once.
Yet the fifty (50!) Aliens you can choose from make sure that no two games will be the same, since each Alien allow its player to break the rules in one way or the other.
Love the way players interact with (temporary) alliances and negotiations.
Finally tried the Tech cards. Must say they added a surprising amount of fun to an allready great game.

We keep playing this one, and it's alway fun.
Increased the score: 8 --> 9

RATING: 9
Chaotic fun! Rowdy negotiations, lots of cross-table banter, turns that involve almost every player, relatively short game length: Whats not to love? Well, the free-form relationships and temporary alliances necessary to do well may be difficult for introverts to develop. Cagey, lone wolf players may also be frustrated with the necessity to form alliances to succeed, but I'm really stretching here to find fault with Cosmic Encounter.

One problem with CE is that it plays better the more players you have and my little gaming group has difficulty exceeding 4 attendees. Another is the fact that the base-game only has components for 5 players, when it could easily play 7. Boo! Fantasy Flight for forcing me to buy expansions just so I can have more people play, especially since most earlier versions played 6!

RATING: 8
Awesome game. So much replayability. Needs to be played with the right group, though. One of the things that keeps it from being a 9+ for me is how unbalanced many of the aliens are. =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
My favorite game. It's hard to do this game justice in a small comment, but I will try.

There is a great deal of *life* to this game. The components, from the ships to the alien cards are all excellent and really bring out enough theme to make it fun. When we go around and read our alien cards there is usually a lot of nervous looks and awe at the alien being read, and this happens for almost every alien! Even the ones that don't strike fear still are useful enough to keep themselves afloat. There is always a heartbeat with this game, and while not everyone at the table will be pleased every time, it feels like someone is always having a blast playing.

It's a game about strategic alliances and bluffing, but it does it better than any other game I have ever played. I only play the game with pretty basic rules (no flares or tech, but expansion aliens) and I just love how everything is so simple yet so smooth. 

This is my favorite game. Like many have said, this game represents what I think of when I think of why I love board games. There is an unmatched type of player interaction here. Not purely antagonistic and not too cooperative and just enough that one person's bluff could win them a game.

I would like to try the hazard deck from the Cosmic Conflict expansion. Will see if that can shake things up in a good way.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
The evolution of this game is proof positive of the power of the Internet.  Cosmic Encounter has continually changed its mechanics over the course of four decades, both with official expansions and a legion of homebrews, not because anything was broken in the game -- the core game is simple enough to explain to a 6-year-old -- but rather for the sheer fun of experimentation.  The game survived 30 years for a good reason and FFG tapped into the CE community for advice on how to keep the spirit of the game alive in the 2010's.  And they released a thing of beauty.

Improvements?  Oh yeah.  The return of massive numbers of aliens, the most in any CE core set to date.  The benefit of 30 years of CE fanbase experience to tap for ideas such as new races and technology pursuits.  The replacement of an awkward board for a simpler, disc-based system that can allow for shorter games.  The coolest-looking ship tokens to date, straight out of "Plan 9 From Outer Space".  A tighter deck of Attack cards, which makes every ship count in battle.  And for the first time ever, a perfectly laid-out FFG rulebook.   (!)

Like most Ameritrash games, the true game is not in the ruleset.  It's on the table.  This is a game of bluffing, negotiation, and brinksmanship.  Think of it along the same lines as Poker: It's less about hand management and more about opponent management, and if you feel the game is simply too random (which can be a valid criticism) I suggest starting there.

If you've never played Cosmic before, you couldn't have come at a better time.  Look past the soul-crushingly unattractive box cover art and you will be richly rewarded with a classic game that continues to showcase creativity, true player interaction, and fun above all -- a 10 with a laser-gun-fired bullet.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.8
Rarely get to play because you need more than 2 and the right group of people. I love it, but some around me do not like it at all.

Chaotic, funny, crazy. Massive player interaction. Bluffing, negotiating, backstabbing, everything you might want in a social game is found here. 

Main complaint is that its very hard to understand how the game actually works, it's not inherently complicated but the rules are either very poorly written or just are not intuitive. I guess being 30+ years old, it naturally will be a little clunkier. Since I only play a few times a year, I have to relearn/constantly reference how everything really works.

RATING: 7.5
Very entertaining political game. It's practically all politics and so can be very random; I'm not sure if it's possible to be skilled in it. But if played lightly, it's a real blast and produces many memorable moments. It can handle a large(r) number of players as well.

My main gripe is that there are a lot of rules corner cases for some reason. All my plays are half taken up by either forgetting, reminding, or discussing rules. Worst is when a dramatic play is ruined by the fact that it's illegal. For what should be a light and fast game, it's a significant problem; I imagine it should be Shadow Hunters-esque in terms of speed but it really isn't. Perhaps this will go away if I play with a group that's very familiar with it?

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I love the different powers. I like the negotiation aspect. I like just about every aspect of the game. This is a game that prides itself on randomness, and every so often that randomness can get it into trouble sometimes (game lasts way too long, a player waltzes to victory with ease, no-win situations). 9/25/2013

Expansions:
Cosmic Alliance
Cosmic Conflict
Cosmic Incursion

Verdict:

What I Like: Replayability is off any known chart. It's statistically certain you'll never play the same game twice. Every alien power dramatically impacts the game. The negotiation driven alliances are the beating heart of this fairly enjoyable experience.

What I Don't Like: Internet FAQs are a must as there is so much extra rule text and rule breaking text that interacts and contradicts among the various powers and cards and expansion stuff. Some of the games can be completely broken by these powers. The worst case is when everyone selects a defensive alien and the game. Drags. On. And. On. Forever. My taste in games over the years has morphed to be more euro bent, and this game sits unashamedly at "very random" on the scale of amerithrash, but I'll gladly still play it from time to time. It's definitely an experience game more than a serious competitive game.

RATING: 8
[b]Cosmic Encounter[/b]

[COLOR=#FF0000]A year later... thoughts and rating (8):[/COLOR]

[i]I was fortunate enough to get 2 more plays of Cosmic in this last year. This has really changed how I feel about this game. I still think it is amazing and great fun, but the group you play with really determines how much fun you're going to have. This game loses a lot of it's charm when it is played with a more serious group of gamers. One of my 2 plays was with a group I normally game with, but the dynamic was a bit off and I felt like everyone was too serious and unfortunately the game fell flat. 

I would love to play Cosmic more, but so far my initial introduction to the game was the best experience I had. Everyone was into the game and everyone role played their race and let their race dictate their play style. I'm looking forward to playing again with a similar group.[/i]

[COLOR=#FF0000]Initial thoughts and rating (9.5):[/COLOR]

[i]- The Grudge: Okay they are one of the many races, but they are the first race I got to play.
Normally I am a pretty laid back guy, but when I play games like this I tend to get really fired up and play aggressively.
The Grudge fed right into this, they allowed me to have a strong negotiation presence whenever I was involved in a conflict.
- Negotiation: The whole game is about negotiation and reading other players, which may be my favorite mechanic in a game.[/i]
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Two things I really like about this game, it plays quickly with little downtime between turns (even with 5 players) and the alliances mechanism allows almost every player to participate on almost every turn. Great player interaction in this one.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
So we played this for the first time. We have five people. John, Kassie, Ashely, Paula and I. I was the sorcerer race. Which seems like a pretty potent power. You can set people up for automatic failure if you have a negotiate card. Of course only works when attacking, and sadly your alien power is shut off if you lose enough home colonies, which happened to me very quickly. Paula commented that the little UFOs looked like nipples, everyone agreed and started referring to their ships as space nipples. combined with the cone of death this became pretty amusing. We discussed the destiny card mechanic and agreed it was both good and bad since its stops inevitable stalemates by forcing action and further it gives you a bit of diplomatic immunity as you can say your attacks for the most part are out of your hands. I really think the fun of this game is dependent on how the people play it. It can be flat and simple if you just go with the flow or you could spice it up with intrigue. I feel at a disadvantage, because I was like the board game prophet of our gaming group introducing people to board games. I was lucky enough to have played settlers in the early 90s. And Magic the gather and D and D before that. Anyways because of that I am sure to be targeted and destroyed. Unlike other games you can't force your will on people via superior strategy you have to be the most likeable person in the group. Which just so happens to be my wife, plus Kassie is like my wive's twin sister in likability. In short a try hard gamer like me is doomed to lose most times.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
2015 Secret Santa gift
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This is a great game for those times you have but an hour. ALso, it is a great version of the original game from the late 1970's [I have that one as well]: this is mainly expressed in the various alien-species-cards. Each such card breaks the very simple rules of the game in some way, and the nearly-endless combination of aliens battling and aligning for conquest through their weird powers is both light-hearted, funny, and very tricky at times. 
The only major flaw I find in the game is the fact that some aliens are so powerful that the only way to beat them is for everyone else to gang up on them almost from the start. 
The only minor flaw I find in the game is that it is conceivable for all players but one to win - i.e., there can be one loser and 4 winners, for example.

RATING: N/A
An excellent game for 2 to eight players with expansions! This game almost feels like a party game with the right crowd. It really is a very simple to play and teach new players. The amazing variety of races to choose from really make this game outstanding! I always look forward to choosing my race from the 2 randomly drawn at the beginning of every game. So far, we have only played with the base rules and all basic races. I look forward to adding in some of the optional cards and advanced races.

In our first couple of games we accidentally missed the rule that you could only add up to 4 ships to any skirmish. We were playing with any number of ships. Basically it led to a faster game, but it was still a lot of fun.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Its a lot of fun with the right people, people that can embrace the wackiness inherent in the game. This game is not balanced on its own, if you are distributing aliens at random, there are some that are objectively more powerful than others. Players need to be able to see this, and work together to reign in the powerful aliens, while also finding inventive ways to leverage their own aliens' abilities.

Ive found it to be polarizing, there are people that I have played with that can't stand it and others, like myself, that could play this game weekly and not get tired of it.

I have Cosmic Incursion and Cosmic Eons expansions, would like Cosmic Dominion.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
I enjoy when playing with real fans, but it's a luck fest. The mechanisms are pretty simple - negotiate like crazy and then big card beats little card (with support modifiers from allies) if you weren't able make a deal. As such the mechanisms, and the board / components for that matter, don't lend themselves to being a great game in themselves. All the fun is in the special powers and being able to do the best with what you get. Having a sucky power is ok if you can use that perceived weakness as a strength in the negotiation aspect (a bit like Diplomacy really).

The fluidity of the negotiations keep any leaders in check, so I guess the strategy is to build yourself into a mid-game position from which to strike for the win. This is really an experience type game, trying to do the best with your powers and seeing what happens and telling the story afterwards. Which is of course quite a different gaming objective from most German / Euro games. If you love deal making, this is a game for you. If you don't, and you just play the cards as you get them, you're in for a luck-fest, one which I'm not a big fan of.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
This game sort of reminds me of Munchkin… Players battle with each other and ask for help from other players and try to aid/hinder each other.  Combat is resolved by secret cards that represent power levels and there are plenty of effects that can determine victory or defeat.  My games have felt like a lot of chaos and then just hoping you can end up at the winners' table at the end.  The many different alien abilities help add variety.  It's one of Tom Vasal's favorite games of all time and I'm not sure why he likes it so much.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
The more I play this, the more I really enjoy it. To have fun playing this, all players really need to really play up their alien races, which also means that people need to let down their hair a bit. Unlike any game I can think of. Much replayability.

The quality of the cards and components is good.  The design of the game is very teaching/non-gamer friendly, while still maintaining a very appealing style which helps make the game experience enjoyable.

You will treasure the awesome experiences you can and, hopefully, will have playing this game.

RATING: 8
