=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
At first glance, Cosmic appears a simple game. Players play a game of War with an added hand management element, while alliances form and splinter. 

However, the 'alien power' gameplay, which allows each player the ability to break the rules of the game in a specific way, allows for near-infinite replayability and dramatically alters how players approach combat, hand management, and diplomacy. Ever time I have sat down to play Cosmic, I've faced off against new and daunting aliens. Almost every alien power can be game changing if understood and played correctly, and alien powers are unique and flavorful. 

Any player who controls five planets belonging to other players wins the game. The dynamic alliance feature allows for multiple players to win the game at the same time (if those players have control of four other planets and win a fifth in an alliance together). This results in exciting shifting blocs and memorable last-ditch efforts to keep powerful alliances from winning the game. 

My only concern is that games are best with 4 or 5 players. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Succeeds where The Resistance fails, which is to say that it has some negotiation, but it isn't pure negotiation and deduction and people can still play and enjoy without worrying about being too involved in the debate and back and forth if they don't want to. The destiny mechanic is an ingenious way of minimizing the king-making, bash the leader, and the inevitable petty vendettas.

After several plays, I absolutely love this game, as does my brother. Everyone else seems unenthusiastic, which is sad.

The game is full of priceless, hilarious, and memorable moments.

< 4 player: Why bother, play something else.
4-6 player: Ideal.
7+ player: A bit much.

RATING: 7
I'd cite CE as one of the best gateway games. Game has a lot going on theme-wise, aliens are diverse and their artwork has a lot character to it. Stackable spaceship tokens are pure genius.

Rules are easy and well laid out. Cards have a little frame that says who and when can play them, which simplifies things a lot.

All of the above create a framework for fun and diverse negotiation game. It's not the heaviest game around, but everyone in my group is always happy to have it on the table.

RATING: 9
Great game of bluff and negotiation. There are lots of chaos and surprise moments: there are overpowered cards and player powers. Yet it is still somewhat balanced thanks to the negotiation phase of each turn where players can form alliances. You can say whatever you want about your cards and give promises, but you cannot show your cards. There is no downtime as you almost always end up taking part in the battle between two main players. Love the sci-fi theme too, the art is very well done. The game is highly variable and replayable thanks to the 50 available alien races that all bend the rules a lot and interact with each other differently. Best if played few games in a row.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Yes. This is super fun. Can't wait to play more.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
I had high hopes for this game and it disappointed me.  In fairness, my comments are to the introductory game.  

I loved the theme, the interaction, negotiation, variable races and powers, and it had interesting cards.  What I didn't like is its implementation.  I found some cards to be too overpowered.  The problem is that with only 1-4 limit of ships attacking/defending and one encounter card attacking/defending can make your hand or negotiation utterly worthless.  Amassing a decent sized hand of encounters, artifacts, and reinforcements was also of little help, especially someone down on cards with none can get new ones.  There appeared to be little strategic decisions.

Overall, it is a great idea not implemented correctly.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Similar to Wiz-War, this game is very much a product of its era, but unlike Wiz-War, this one works in modern times quite well. The combination of a HUGE variety of alien races that all do unspeakable things to the game and a host of dastardly double-crosses, constantly shifting alliances, and random targets of violence combine to make this an enjoyable blitz of conflict as opposed to Wiz-War's convoluted "anything-goes" cards. I can definitely see my rating of this increasing with further plays.

RATING: 9
an exercise in controlled chaos and negotiation. 

People going into this game not expecting conflict or wild swings of fortune are going to be really unhappy. 

It's important that all players understand what they are getting into when playing this game. Otherwise there may be rage quitting and hurt feelings (due to ganging up possibilities). Because of this, you must play this game with the right crowd.

You most certainly can play a better game than others, but it hinges on your negotiation skills, when to use not use your cards and powers, and your alliances. (There is a lot of randomness/chaos.)

For the most part this game is just hilarious fun and you just can't take it too seriously.

RATING: 8
If you don't like conflict and broken promises...stay clear of this one.  In concept, a simple game ... simply get your ships onto 5 other player planets.  Yeah...right!  You must make alliances with other players and wheel and deal in order to get ahead in this one.  Each player represents an alien race with its own special abilities.  Colonize another's planet will involve some help.  But be careful, because other players can choose to help the defender for their own rewards.  Wonderful, interactive game only made better by the myriad of expansions out there.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.31
There is just something about this game... unfettered by concerns of balance or elegance or any modern game design concepts. They took a simple idea and made it the most fun thing they possibly could. The signature of raw inspiration is embedded in every thread of this game. Everything is hilarious and screwed up and beautiful. I could play it endlessly and never see the same game twice. 

A challenging one because the first time you play it it doesn't make sense. "Huh? Why is this a game? How is this some all time classic?" A game that actually demands you change the way you think about games to enjoy it. Once I stopped trying to play it like a strategy game, and embraced the chaos and scheming and madness, it blossomed like a hyperdimensional flower. But it can put people off if there is not a guide there to reveal the enthusiasm.

A game that is a greater vehicle for pure fun than pretty much any I have ever seen. You make it what it is, but it provides the richness of raw material. The cheshire cat of games, a timeless grin.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I have only played this game once, but it blew me away. I tossed around the idea of buying it for a few months after seeing some review videos of it and wasn't really sure I'd like it. I finally pulled the trigger, and all I can say is that you need to play it to get a real feel for the game. The mechanics are pretty simple, but what makes it great are the layers upon layers of strategy involved. The base game includes 50 alien powers, all of which allow you to break the rules in some way. Figuring out how to play and counterplay these powers is what makes this game awesome. If you choose to play with the techs, it adds yet another layer of options (although you might want to play a few games before using the techs...my group used them on our first play and we pretty much ignored them. It didn't harm the game at all, but the cards just sat there for the whole game).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I have played (and owned) just about every version of CE since the original Eon. Of the various editions, the Avalon Hill edition had the best art and components but lacked much of what had been available before(they should have released an expansion); the West End was bare bones (and I have saved nothing from it); Mayfair altered the game and added (way) too much crap (but I have saved a ton of the aliens they had offered. Now the FFG edition...they did it right. Everything that a basic CE game needs has been included and I enjoy the new 'Tech' variant. However, I still enjoy the AH components (especially the board/warp) and we continue to use these unless we have 5 players.

CE is a classic game that remains 'alive' even in the new world of Eurogames. Every gamer should own a copy.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VAGdKMMnk-U
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Ah Cosmic. I've had some of my best gaming experiences playing it, and some of my worst. 

The basic rules really aren't that complicated. You need to get everyone to understand the structure of a turn (8 or so phases) and which cards they can play when, but the graphics (at least on the FFG edition) really help with this. But the game is really about the exceptions to the rules - your alien power, your cards - and their interactions, and these can quickly become overwhelming for new players, even without including any of the many modular add-ons like flares and technology.

It's also *highly* group dependent. If you play it as a Eurogame, it's no fun and just seems dumb. There needs to be negotiation, backstabbing, outrageous risks, lots of laughter and no hard feelings to make it come alive. It really is a 'game of infinite possibilities' - you'll never play with the same combination of aliens twice, and most of the fun is just sitting back and watching the crazy shit that can happen.

Some peple have talked about the endgame being 'broken'. I don't really agree. Sure, a whole bunch of players can decide to have a joint victory, but more often people will try to save up cards for a final push on their own, or someone will win in a crazy unexpected way.

It's one of the most divisive games I know. Several friends who generally share my tastes absolutely hate it, and I've not yet quite figured out how to predict who will and won't enjoy it. But if you can find a group of four or five (or more with the expansions) who really get it, it's an outrageous amount of fun. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
All the different crazy alien powers make it fun, but it does sometimes seem like you don't have much control over how well you do.

RATING: 7

RATING: 9
Simple space combat game about destroying and colonizing your opponents planets, however each player becomes one of 50 unique alien races that drastically breaks the rules of the game. A certain race multiplies their attack power by the number of ships they have, one race automatically wins the game after a certain amount of time, one race reverses the numbers on every card. It may seem unbalanced but people who have more powerful races tend to be ganged up on.

RATING: 10
I only have one play of this, and it was with some non-gamers, and it tanked. I like everything about it though, and fully expect to enjoy it once I get a chance to play it with people who like this sort of stuff.

UPDATE: After playing with some gamers, they loved it. The fact that everyone gets a unique power and adopts a type of personality for the game makes it feel like an actual Alien conflict, which makes the game shine.

Tentative rating: 8/10 based on the games I've played. It could go up with the right group. My group loves multiplayer Magic though, which directly competes for sessions with Cosmic Encounter, so I might not get to play it much for a while.

UPDATE: I played this with a group of laid-back gamers and it rocked. Everyone got into it and had a great time. This game is brilliant in so many ways.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
There is something "cool" about this game I cannot really grasp. Good components and "ships" look nice. At it's heart, it's really a negotiation game, so if you don't like it, it's not for you - it's less likely for one player to win "alone" just by game mechanic. 

Also, given the amount of rules on player's cards, it feels like it's terribly unbalanced. This might be a nice game for a filler, but serious gamers will be probably put off by some insane combos certain characters can pull of. It looks like most chars gets this really really good superpower, and it's race towards the end. The scoring is also a bit flawed and the game either ends with 3 players winning the game, or drags horribly, because everyone else is trying to deny that last point to the winning group/player. 

I would play again, but not going to buy it. Too many design decisions that annoy me.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I know that the game is supposed to be centered around politicking and negotiation, but sometimes the game state is so horrendously unbalanced between two players based on their alien powers that it just feels unfair. When the option to stop a runaway lead is to gang up on someone, and you also can't influence which player you'll have an encounter with, it's tough to have a proactive effect on the game state. You can only play so many negotiate cards while waiting for the leader's turn to come around.

Also, Flare cards are stupidly good since you don't discard them after playing them. It adds too much variance for my tastes, because That Guy who draws all of the Flare cards usually just wins.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5.25
My My, how expectations can be wrong, at least so it appears. This has been on my must-have list for quiet some time, despite the fact that I never played it. Now, I had the pleasure of trying it for the first time and was royally flabbergasted by it. It is a very simple game, which is not a bad thing, but it is so random and yet at the same time limited in its possible strategic decisions that I never really experienced the sensation of playing a 'game' in the true sense of the word but experiencing a cascade of random events unfolding before my eyes. The destiny cards are the first thing that I found bizarre, if you cannot choose who to attack, the winner of the game can solely be determined by card draw. Yes, yes, you might form alliances, but who would ally with you unless necessary anyway and then, where is the strategical decision ? Same goes for defending. The abilities are a good idea, but I found that too far in the game-breaker instead of tactic enhancer field. All in all, I am still astonished by the mediocrity of this game and will most definitely have to play it again and make sure whether it was just a one-off bad experience.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Cosmic is a brilliant mixed up mess of chaos.  Sometimes it sparkles with the brilliance of a galaxy of suns.  Sometimes it wimpers.  And either way, it's all your fault.

Cosmic is a bare bones game design.  Thematically players embody alien races trying to colonize foreign planetary systems (you know, the ones controlled by their opponents).  But all the manouver of a multiplayer confilict game has been removed.  Players don't get to choose who they attack.  Instead a player draws a destiny card and the card tells the player who he has to "encounter".  Then the attacker loads up the "hyper space cone" and attempts to finagle some real estate out of his opponent.  The attacker and the defender play cards in a blind bidding fashion.  The card values add to the number of ships committed to battle.  Highest value wins.  If the offence wins he gets to clear out all the locals and move in.

It's all pretty simple, but there are a couple things that really make it crazy.  First, the combatants can request help from the other players.  Second, and this is the game's trademark mechanism, all the alien races have their own unique (and seemingly unbalanced) powers.  The simple game mechanisms get warped and wobbled.  Furthermore one player can win or all but one player can win.

The strength and the weakness of Cosmic Encounter is that you, my dear player, can make it go any way you want.  A more systemic flaw is that players tend to gang up on the leader.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
With three plays I feel I haven't even begun to scratch the surface of this bloated beast of a game, but man has it been great thus far. 

A rather basic core game is raised to terrific heights by adding numerous variables, lots of player interaction and providing many occasions for laughing out loud. 
Long term strategic planning, which I tend to really like in a game is completely off the table in this organised excuse for chaos, but it is something I will gladly do without if it means I can have fun to such a degree. The art style is not really to my taste as it leaves little to nothing to the imagination. 

Still I would be surprised if it doesn't retain a perfect 9 score for me.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.75
The Dutch version of "Cosmic is a direct copy of the Fantasy Flight version with similar components and a downright embarassing translation. Seriously, it looks like a first draft that no one bothered to proof-read before shipping the lot to the printers. Overly long sentences with typos galore. Ït is a big game with tons of text but come on, really?

The game is fantastic as ever and the publisher needed to get at least one thing completely right: To deliver a good translation in order to expand the potential user base and help get it to more tables. That didn't happen and I wager good money that we won't be seeing a second print run to correct the plethora of mistakes, unfortunately.
In its current state it is hard to recommend it over the English version in any way, unless Dutch really is the only language you or people you'll be playing this with can understand.

RATING: 3
Pros:
1. Classic - This game is a classic.......

Cons:
1. Long - This game takes way too long to play.
2. Imbalanced - The alien powers are all over the place. Some are extremely powerful, some are useless.
3. Negation Based - Games that incorporate negotiation usually have the same issue. They rely on the players to balance the game. Generally, I find this to be lazy game design. 
4. Games end in a tie - Almost every game ends in a tie or if you're in to double speak "Multiple Winners".

Summary: Some people love this game, but it's clearly not for me.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
While there are elements from the EON expansions that I miss in this edition, it's by far my favorite of the ones I've seen or played, including the Eon version. Superb art, terrific encounter phase timeline on every alien power, great rules and definitions clarifications, and I really like the new planets & ships (though I do miss the hexes... just for nostalgia's sake).

My only gripe as a long-time fan of the Eon edition, and an owner of a much-played Mayfair edition, is that they used the re-named game elements from the most recent reprint.  Edicts are now Artifacts, the Hyperspace Cone is now the Hyperspace Gate, Challenges are now Encounters... that last one make the most sense considering the name of the game.  It's just got to be confusing to new players as I explain the game, "... at the beginning of each Challenge, I mean Encounter..." "all their tokens go to the warp... I mean ships go to the warp."

RATING: 8.5
Cosmic Encounter is an often hilarious game of making and breaking alliances, often in the same breath.  
Utterly random, unbalanced and chaotic... but... for once that's just fine.  Cosmic is far more interested in inspiring crazy hijinks and player narratives than it is in arbitrary concepts like "fairness" or "long-term strategy". 

I have yet to walk away from a night where this hit the table without a grin and a story to tell.

Side note:  With expansions, you can include up to 8 players.  This is a TERRIBLE idea.  4-5 players is what you want.  6 with some patience.

RATING: 5
There's no denying the place that this early American hobby game occupies in the cannon of tabletop games. That said, the game's design shows its age.  It is pretty chaotic and can be overly long when played with anyone who does not understand this isn't a strategically deep game, and in turn constantly over-thinks their turn. That said, like a lot of these diplomacy type games, this one is very group dependent. So with the right group this does have the potential to be a lot of fun and should play pretty quickly, which is rare enough for this type of game that if one were a fan of take this style games, you could do worse than this one.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 1
You know, I actually do not hate the game. It's just that every time I play this, it is decided by rather random factors. The key to this game and rather all diplomatic games is on the players. Once you see people growing spiteful with one another, or give favorable sympathy, it really turns into a different game. I hate that. Winning the game becomes about "ganging up" rather than through clever play. I would rather have a game where people act in their best interests to win logically than be at the whim of emotions. Games that throw the balance on diplomacy, risks throwing the balance on illogical players. So the game can be fun, but most of the time it will be ruined by illogical players deciding the game. I'm here to win.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I've played this game at least half a dozen times. Every time it ends the same- half of the table gets tired of the back-and-forth nature of the victory points and 3 or 4 players team up for a tie game.
There are some decent mechanics in this game, and some of the alien powers are just great, but I'm convinced something is missing from making this game work.
No matter what aliens are chosen. No matter what cards are drawn. Cosmic Encounter just doesn't end until everyone gives in.
So, overall, yes, I love the theme. I love that it supports up to 8 players and the basic idea is very entertaining. It's just too much of a fiddly mess to support itself.

RATING: 4
This is a game I probably need to play again to truly form an opinion about it.  There were several aspects of the game that were off putting to me.  First, I felt completely out of control about what happened to me.  Destiny cards and the ally nature of the game made it seem very swingy.

The attack cards are so widely distributed.  I played a 10 early, which seemed good but got destroyed by a 30 or something.  So wildly swingy!

I guess I'm just not a fan of ameritrash games.  I would never ask to play this game and wouldn't recommend it to anyone.

Having said all that, I can understand how others might enjoy it.  If you like a lot of confrontation, negotiation and want the game balance to be driven by the people in the game - go for this.  If you like to be the agent of your own destiny - pass.

:star::star::nostar::nostar::nostar: [b]Artwork[/b]

RATING: 4

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Often a fun and slightly outrageous game. It has simple core mechanisms and yet, creatively, it's had everything thrown into it. It has deception, randomness, negotiation etc in spades. It's bordering on being a party game.

However you probably won't like this game at all if you:
- Dislike the massive amount of randomness, both from the cards and the players.
- Dislike the massive amount of 'metagame', for example where players will gang up on you just because is SEEMED to them that your particular alien character was overpowered in a previous game.
- Dislike the MASSIVE catch-up mechanism, whereby you exclude players who are doing well from making progress towards the finishing line (while helping players who are behind, in return for them helping you succeed in fights). Seriously, the game often concludes with all players being almost at the finishing line together and then one player edging a victory just because of a lucky card they drew.

Depending on how much the above problems worry you, this game could either gert old very fast of genuinely feel incredibly fresh and new each time you play it.

The world's number one boardgame youtuber Tom Vasel still says this is his favourite game (as of 2016). But he likes silly games. By comparison, my gaming group has never requested that Cosmic Encounter comes back to the table. I also had a quite flat game of it in a different, lively gaming group in London a few years ago.

Interestingly, Tom Vasel's own game that he published, called Nothing Personal, fell into exactly the same trap of having such huge catch-up mechanisms that the first two-thirds of the game are irrelevant infighting.

I'm wondering if I should have rated this a 7 instead, but honestly I'm simply not usually in the mood to play it.

RATING: 4
Asymmetrical powers always interest me but never fail to leave me with the impression that some powers are much better than others. Obviously, the dozens of powers available in this game couldn't have all been rigorously tested against one another for balance.

The game loses points because it's important to me in a game that equally skilled players have an equal chance of winning.

*It occurs to me that savvy players should weigh the strengths and merits of the aliens in play so as not to ally too frequently with overpowered races. This might counter-balance the powers of those races.*

RATING: 10
Considered by many people (myself included) as the great masterpiece of board games, this is a very peculiar one, no doubt. I see it as other special games, such as "Tales of the Arabian Nights" or "Dungeon Quest", meaning that every time you start a game you don´t know what´s going to happen. It´s an unknown adventure! As a player, we  will not have control of the situation of the game. And I love that chaos!! This game is pure fun, and in all the games that we´ve played, we´ve enjoyed a lot. And it doesn´t matter who is the winner! A truly masterful classic. But hey! Not for all tastes, of course! Played with the correct people, is a blast!

RATING: 7.5
Dice Tower Secret Santa 2010 gift.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
A classic that I would personally describe as a "strategic beer and pretzels game."  Use your little space ships to take over opponents' planets while trying to protect your own.  Add cards that momentarily break the rules completely out of left field.  As a result, there's a tremendous amount of luck, but also a tremendous amount of laughs.

There is such a "go after the leader" ability that I'm always afraid it will devolve into an unending stalemate, but someone somebody ultimately gets that last point.

The new edition has gorgeous and well-done components that are very self-explanatory.  Unlike some devotees, I'm afraid I would get burned out on this after more than an occasional play.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
A fun cosmic negotiation game, must play more ... and I have to get this one ...

Generally well enjoyed by most players.

Heaps of replay value with just the base set, would like to pick up the expansions one day so I can increase the group size that can play.

RATING: 5.4
I've played Cosmic Encounter countless times since 1978. In one sense no two games have ever been alike because there are so many alien powers to choose from but, regardless of your power, the game is all about manipulating your friends into making deals that are not in their best interest while they try to do the same to you. I would categorize this as a party game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Cosmic encounter is in my opinion at best a so-so game. In this game you play an alien race or possibly two who are trying to take over at least 5 planets that are owned by other players. This is done by essentially playing a version ofthe original card game war with special abilities on some cards. You can also ask other players to add their cards in to help you.

Pros: fun negotiation at times, extremely interactive, fast and easy setup, game can play up to 6 players.

Cons:games are variable long, usually erring on the short side, the game can end without some players even gaining traction,not strategic, all based in peoples ability to manipulate others,  no one winner so all but one can win in some cases.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Very fun but very random game. Can be stuck doing very little due to the randomness. But on the other hand you can be on a complete steamroll.  New players are annoying because they just open invite alliances constantly.

RATING: 6.5

2.55
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.6
THE standout game of the 1970s/1980s, it still deserves its very high rating. The recent re-implementation series is even better.  ALWAYS in our top 10 game choices. EVERYBODY we know who plays it, likes it. There is almost no down time, because every player can almost always somehow be involved in proceedings. The only problem which keeps CE from being played more by us is the highly variable and unpredictable game length, which means we have to allow sufficient time for a long game. (My guess is that our average is about 45 mins, but has gone as long a about 2.5 hours in one unusually long game.)
Funnily enough, it is also possibly the best socially interactive game that we play, aside perhaps from Pandemic. Which reminds me of another plus - you can have multiple winners in this game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Here's how I teach Cosmic Encounter, including suggested power selection:

Do a sample turn. Start with the simplest elements, and add complexity. Deal each player a standard hand and powers. Tell players to ignore Edicts, Reinforcements, Flares, Powers, etc. for now.

Flip the Destiny deck and go through a challenge, including allies. Then go through the following sample combats:

a. Each player plays an Attack card.

b. Each player plays a Negotiate card and attempt to make a deal. Mention that "base for a base" is a very good deal, as well as trading cards.

c. One player plays an Attack, the other a Negotiate. Explain Compensation. Mention that Compensation is a very good way to obtain Flares, which are reusable, and covered later.

d. Explain how Reinforcements work, as well as Edicts. Then redo the challenge, allowing everyone to play Reinforcements and Edicts.

e. Explain timing. By now, players should have a rough idea how the phases would work. Then introduce Flares and Powers. Redo the challenge, with all the game components.

I should mention that, with powers, I prefer to deal each player two green powers face-down. At any time, a player may use his power by revealing it at the appropriate time. I find that one-power games can be incredibly dull, since some players may use their power rarely in the game (especially those which occur only when the player wins as a main player). Revealing powers allows players to introduce new rules (and that's what the powers are -- new rules players have to understand) to the game at *their* pace. Dealing each player a power face-up requires new players not only to digest the base game rules, but also *every* player's power. 

***

In no particular order...

* One way to get past "power overload" is to play hidden powers. You are dealt your power and keep it face down until you decide to use it. This allows new players time to digest the basic rules of the game before powers come into play. (Personally, I recommend each player receives *two* hidden powers, so that players get to play with their powers more often during the game!) Likewise, you can shuffle the Flares (and maybe Edicts) into the deck *after* initial hands are dealt.

* As for the science fiction theme, it's about on the level of Race for the Galaxy. Myself, I think the science fiction theme works fine.

* Regarding diplomacy and negotiation, I think anyone who's played games involving simple negotation (even Steve Jackson "take that" Games, where players end up taking down whoever's leading) will easily understand the negotiation necessary for Cosmic Encounter. Remember that, when making a deal, the "base for a base" agreement is one of *the* best moves to make early and mid-game, since you each now have gained one more base than the players not in the deal.

* A tip to avoid bad hands: In Cosmic Encounter, having a hand of many cards is rarely a disadvantage. So, if you have a poor hand, make a deal with your opponent that includes giving away *all* your cards. This will allow you to draw a new hand which hopefully is better. Alternately, ally defensively and draw cards so you don't end up in this situation. With flares, I actually find I rarely have a bad hand, since, even though I may lose a challenge, at least I can use a flare to my advantage.

***

I pretty much *like* the "do not reveal until played" variant, but, with n00bs, it's "deal two and keep them secret until revealed". I also suggest shuffling in the flares *after* dealing the initial hand.

* N00bs have enough to learn from the game besides the powers. Requiring them to digest the power *before* the rules is equivalent to learning the advanced rules of the game before playing the basic one.

* Some powers are outright boring when played alone (eg. "Usable only as an attacking player"). Even a "when a main player" powers might not be used more than a few times in a game (eg. Clone player with no advantageous Attack cards).

* Vets get to play an advanced game of CE, rather than the less fun "one power each" version. Let's get off the baby food and have something more substantial!

* Even when playing the standard game, n00bs miss out how their powers work. The game is *very* forgiving it a player mis-plays their power, since it's the player interaction, not the powers, which are the most important part of the game.

* Not revealing your power at the right time can confuse veteran opponents. If you accidentally discard your Attack 30, your opponent will conclude you're not the Clone. Then, when you draw an Attack 20, you use it twice to gain your last bases.

* The key part of the game is knowing when to invite allies. This strategy, not the powers, is how you win the game.

*****

Some random hand manipulation suggestions...

* If you have a crappy hand, play a Negotiate against someone who (you guess) has a good hand. If you take Consolation, hope to get some good cards. If you make a deal *offer to give away ALL your cards*. You get a new hand of (hopefully) better cards, and your opponent gets more cards to "protect" his good cards from Consolation.

* Ally with the defense, especially if the expansion set Rewards deck is in play. In the short term, it can be painful, especially if the other (n00bs) do nothing but ally with the offense. If more than one person catches onto this strategy, one of them will win the game.

* Ally with the offense! If the other players don't catch on that allying is better than being the offensive player, that's they're problem! (N00bs!N000000bs!) If you can win the game without needing to play cards from your hand, you've just won the game!

* Bluff. This trick only works once. Play like you have a really good card in your hand. I can never pull this off.

* Die a painful death. Sputter, play a weak Attack card, and essentially do nothing during your turn. Lose planets. In practice, however, most players don't lose their powers. In a one-power game, you don't even *use* your power all that often, so losing your power is overrated -- especially if players keep inviting others when they're the offensive player!

* Play with flares. The more you play a flare, the more others will want it. Even if the flare isn't all THAT good. I've noticed that one flare can make a crappy hand into a useful one. Once you get a good flare, do your best to get more cards to prevent losing it from Consolation. Alternately, make it more likely that your opponent will get the flare with Consolation, so you can draw a new hand -- which hopefully will have another flare.

I played this only once, at a board game cafe, but something went wrong.  I can't quite place what it was; there was a mood of uncertainty at the table, and I remember having the idea that we might be playing incorrectly.  Whatever it was, it resulted in nobody at the table seeming to be really invested in the game, and I suspect that this is a game which can fall flat if players are not playing with enthusiasm and a real desire to win.

Now, years later, I am increasingly eager to play the game again.  I've been thinking about it, and reading about it, and at this point I am ready to purchase the game without needing to play it again first, despite that lukewarm-at-best first experience.  I love the idea of the huge number of variable powers, the engagement that arises when everything is driven by player interaction, and I feel that this is a game which can pack a great experience into a fairly short time.

RATING: 9
If you give CE a fighting chance, you might see that there's a good degree of skill involved in cajoling and backstabbing your way to the top. Underneath all the crazy powers and card interactions, CE is an asymmetric negotiation game that rewards skillful resource management and clever tabletalk.

There's a good deal of luck present, but I don't think an unhealthy amount given the light-hearted nature of the game.

That all being said, CE will falter in a group that doesn't buy into it. It's not a game for everyone, and it can potentially drag into tedium due to the hugely varied play times.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Personally, I hate it, and feel it’s a very dated design. You have too little agency and too little information, with the random encounter locations, blind bids of randomly drawn cards, tedious open-ended negotiations, and wildly unbalanced special abilities.  The special abilities are the most interesting part of the game, but unless you’re playing with a variant, you just randomly get one at the start of the game and that’s it; they’re an interesting feature bolted on top of a rotten framework.

Honestly, that’s what makes it so frustrating, that there is a kernel of an awesome idea in this heartbreaker, and then everything around it is terrible. I do thank it for giving us its cousin Dune, with more empowering mechanics and well-tuned set of powerful special abilities, and for inspiring both Magic the Gathering and the modern school of asymmetric-faction dudes-on-a-map games at which Eric Lang excels, but I have no desire to play their dusty ancestor.

RATING: 8.5
Entertaining way to spend some time, but definately a four or five player game (though there is a passable 2-player variant which our FLGS owner showed us). 

It's probably best seen as a type of 'poker'. You may not win every hand, but with clever bluffs, misdirection, and table-talk you can up your win-rate a lot. I think this game's got a lot more depth than most people think - with the limited amount of knowledge held by the players, and some clever deductions, this can become a very intense game.

Worth owning due to the fact that it's a real classic, for the 50s/60s 'Sci-Fi'ness. The game itself is just a bonus.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Visual Appeal: (5)
Everything looks great. The art on each alien card is unique and really adds a good flavor. Plastic spaceships are brilliant rather than some drab tokens.

Component Quality: (5)
The spaceships are a good size and stack-able! Cards are a nice durable finish and the larger alien race cards allow them to be read at a distance on the table. If I could find one ease-of-use gripe it would be that the colony counter is easily jostled around on a busy table. A slider or dial would have been neater.

Theme: (4)
This is essentially a negotiation game in space. Alien powers and technology cards affect different parts of the game often allowing you to break rules. I imagine that humans meeting real aliens in a game of interstellar thermonuclear war would also yield cries of, "you can do what? Aw, no fair!" Followed by us humans gambling our way to victory Kobayashi Maru-style.

Learning: (4)
I learned from another player first and didn't read the rule book until my 3rd play or so. The game is fairly easy to teach and there are some modular rules (like tech cards or yellow/red aliens) that can be removed to reduce complexity. The rule book is clear enough and gives scenario examples. Learning the odds of certain cards coming up in the deck takes experience.

Gameplay: (3)
It is more a result of the players than the game, but the game definitely encourages dastardly dealings. I like the fact that the game can have some swing to it. Everyone has different abilities and it behooves you to learn who you can team up with (or against) to increase your odds of coming out on top. The biggest thing I don't like is how certain aliens or actions will paint a target on your head and make it very difficult to succeed.

Overall Fun: (4)
With the right group this game can be a blast. Some people I've played with had a problem with the randomness, but I feel that it is a very human element of the game. With enough charm and guile, you can talk people into doing things that benefit you.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
3-8p

RATING: 9.7
Currently, Cosmic Enounter is one ofmy favorite group games. This is a very unbalanced game, and you know that going in.  For that reason, it creates some of the best interactions, and chaos you can see in a game today.  The goal is simple: You are an alien race who is trying to colonize on 5 planets that are not yours.  Every alien also has a powerful abillity which will aid them on there adventure.  With crazy cards, powers, alliances, betrayal you are sure to have a unique game everytime.

RATING: 8.5
A tremendously fun game that's fast paced and very easy to learn with almost no downtime; the individual players are often involved during other players' turns, plus your turn tends to come back around pretty quickly.  Two thumbs up!

UPDATE: 

Usually I integrate additions to my comments into the main body of the text, but with Cosmic I'm going to make an exception to show how my thoughts on this game have evolved.  The top paragraph was written when I hadn't even had Cosmic for a month and was rating it at an 8.5.  Pretty solid rating, huh?  Not high enough.  With over 40 plays racked up in under a year, I can definitively say that I never get tired of this game - with fifty different aliens to play, every single game is a fresh and unique experience.  SO AWESOME.  I won't play with fewer than four players anymore (I have other games that work better for three), but with four or five, I'm always happy to see it hit the table.  I love dazzling new players with how amazing it is!  Can't wait for the first expansion to come out as I'm looking forward to six player Cosmic...

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Cosmic Encounter is a gaudy space-themed negotiation-style game that grows on you. It has a fairly basic set of game mechanics which on their own are not particularly exciting. Basically, draw a card that tells you to attack another player; attack or negotiate with that player; occupy that player's colony or be rebuffed--rinse and repeat. The ultimate goal of the game is to occupy five opposing players' colonies before they do.

The heart of this game is 1) variable race powers an 2) negotiation. There are 50 completely different powers, some possibly game-breaking and others of a more ordinary nature. They add an extra flavour to the game. The Loser power turns a defeat into a win, the Vaccuum drags opposing ships down with it when defeated, the Warrior gets stronger with each battle, the Observer protects allied ships from dying in case of a defeat. Each power has its benefits and calls for a different playing style.

The most important part of Cosmic Encounter is the negotiation. Players will need to call allies and will also need to know when it is better not to. They will need to form alliances that are trusting, yet temporary. Most games that I have played end up with many players on the verge of victory, with only the one player who was struggling at the start to come from behind and win as everyone was too busy stopping each other from taking the last colony.

Cosmic Encounter may seem gaudy, a little oddly-themed with mechanics that might seem odd and outdated, but the actual metagame is what makes it infinitely replayable.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
First time I played, I didn't like it. It wasn't fun, felt outdated, and I felt generally meh about it...

However, I feel like I was in a very "Euro" mode when I gave it the initial shot.  Once you embrace the chaos (Like you do for RoboRally) then you are going to have a blast. Realize that negotiation and bluffing and trash-talking is a part about it.

Great fun. Love the different powers, and this game is the KING of variable player powers.

But, I have to admit, I still expect something more out of this game.  I suppose I expected it to be a 9 or 10 in my book, but its just not quite there. It certainly feels a little dated.  

Also, the game really depends on the players. If they get into the game, then it will be fun. However, if the players have to make the game fun, is the game itself really that good? I don't know.  Either way, I do enjoy the game. I was expecting to be blown away, and I wasn't, but it's still very enjoyable.

UPDATE: This game leaves me a bit disappointed. I suppose I'm just asking too much of this game - I keep expect it to be one of the best games ever.

UPDATE: Everything just clicked for me.  It took like 4-5 plays (embarrassing, I know) but all the sudden I completely got the game.  I knew the chaos, but not the negotiation just game up to match.  It could have been that we played it right after a game of The Resistance, which really set us in the right mood.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Astounding that an elegant forward-thinking design like this came out in the 70s. The simple system is set up nicely for negotiating and backstabbing, then gets out of the way for the alien powers and cards to take over and tear it down.

I don't like negotiation much, and the theme doesn't grab me, but it's interesting to see the interplay of cards/abilities and the frantic cooperation of players to bash the leader and try to balance the game. No two games ever play the same, despite how much you think you know the cards, and I like to see how hilariously broken the game can get each time. Doing broken things and inviting others to use their broken things on you trumps winning sometimes.

[-]Once-in-a-while/month game though, I feel pretty satiated after each play.[/-] Understand the game more now, and each play varies so differently from the next that there's no point not to repeat-play. Very strong contender for the 60-to-150-minute range 4/5/6/7er game.

[hr]

Perfectly tuned for large groups: Random encounters and alliances keep everybody engaged at all times (and solves the > 4-player interaction by adjacency problem)), while shared wins and random encounters take kingmaking out of your hands.

On the attraction side, alien powers and flares and their combinations introduce a huge variety in each game and always provide something new to think of. Need to adapt and think on your feet, which is also necessitated by the randomness and constant change.

Still forward-thinking by today's standards and more like a gift from the future than a relic from the past. Example: random encounters sound totally taboo ("it's totally random who I attack??"), but it solves large-player-count issues by deftly near-eliminating kingmaking and removing the constraints of adjacency, and just means you need a plan for [I]everybody[/I], not just wounded Joe. Another example: the totally unique concept of a shared victory sounds like kissing your sister, but really, it speeds up the endgame (and hence mitigates leader-bashing and kingmaking) by allowing you to continue pursuing winning solutions that coincide with those of others; I deem it [i]socially irresponsible[/i] to delay a likely shared victory to pursue your solo win!

(I can be socially irresponsible sometimes though.)

5+4

[color=gray][b]Favorite 5-player Med-length - Runner-up[/b][/color]
g{[b]Favorite 6-player Med-length[/b]}g (with an expansion to add 6th player, preferably Cosmic Incursion)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
My signature game from the time when people still played games for the sake of playing them. CE is utterly chaotic, which means you just take your surfboard, ride the waves and hope it all kinda works out. It also means you can get away by stupid things. CE is about negotiations, but the brilliant thing is that the game tells you who to attack, so no alliance lasts more than one turn - which means a lot of social groupthink is neutralised. CE also allows bluffing (with negotiation cards). And last but not least - when you sum it all up, CE is primarily about having a fun ride, 

It's the funky game. 

I also have the Cosmic Incursion expansion. Haven't played enough to see the full potential of the reward deck, but seems that its mere existence influences the incentives to helf the defence (which is good). Mostly I can play CE with 6 now. I doubt I'll be getting another expansion though - CI is a good one.

I must be missing something or we just had a screwy game where my opponents got all of the high cards and I never saw one above a 10. I felt like I had no control over my destiny and going through the motions of allying and so forth was just an illusion of control for just a basically random exercise.

The overall theme appealed to me, and I like the idea of forced confrontations, negotiations, and shifting alliances. Hopefully it will get cleared up for me with another session. The FF edition sure looks pretty and I'd like an excuse to covet it.

Most recent play 4-25-09 at Net Lake with Corey, Michael, and Garrett.

RATING: 8.5
Cosmic Encounter scratches that diplomacy itch, while being shorter than Diplomacy, and more interesting than Risk.

The game is random due to random hands of cards and the Cosmic Deck determining the target of attack, but it has more player interaction than Risk because attackers and defenders are using allies constantly.

Due to the design of the game, there are no real long-standing alliances followed by a sudden betrayal. But the positive side is that the combat is up-front and center immediately. While games can still take an hour or longer, there will always be something going on that affects you.

RATING: N/A

Now that isn't exactly fair since it is a negotiation game, trying to convince others to ally with you.  This feels like 90% of the game.  The problem is more often than not allying with someone doesn't actually affect the outcome.  Also, the powers in the game are crazy and unbalanced.  

Add all this together with the fact that the game is too long for what it is.  I would rather just play a short game of Resistance if I want to play a pure social game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
[2014-02-08]
Nem gondoltam volna, hogy a Munckinnek volt előzménye, pedig úgy tűnik igen. A Cosmic Encounter egy az egyben Munckin csak sci-fi világba ültetve. Abban más a játék, hogy itt egymás bolygóit támadják a játékosok, de azt, hogy éppen a soron levő játékos kiét, az szerencsével dől le, de legalább nem nyílt a konfliktus. A két fél bármelyik további játékost hívhatja segítségül, akik további űrhajókkal szállnak be a támadásba vagy védésbe a két aktív fél csatahajói mellé. Ezután egy-egy kártyát játszik ki a két fél, ami befolyásolhatja a csatában levő űrhajók számát vagy bármilyen egyéb dolgot tehet. Ezután összehasonlítják az űrhajók számát. Ha támadók nyernek, megvethetik a lábukat az ellenfél bolygóján, ha védő, akkor a támadók visszavonulnak. A játékban öt idegen bolygó megszállásával lehet nyerni. Ennyi a játék. A változatosságot a renget fajta kártya adja és a minden játékos számára adott fajkártya. Ezek a fajkártyák a mi játékunkban eléggé kiegyenlítettnek tűntek, de mégsem ez döntött a játékossorrendről a végén. Szerintem túl egyértelmű, hogy mindig a támadó mellé kell állni, amíg az nem esélyes a végső győzelemre, hisz így mi is csak nyerünk ha őt segítjük. Elképzelhető, hogy egy játékos sorra sem kerül és a játék vége, az ilyet nagyon nem szeretem. Cserében a játék tényleg nem hosszú. A szerencse szerepe óriási, hisz az, hogy kit támadnak kártyahúzással dől el. Nem az én stílusom a játék, de a Munckinnál jobban tetszett a kicsit kötöttebb szabályai miatt.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
[b]Best 4 Player Game Award[/b]

[i]Hall of Famer. No Two Games are Alike![/i]

[b]100+ Logged Plays Award[/b]

In the words of Peter Olotka: This game is for smart people with a sense of humor. That isn't a diss to those who don't like it (well, only in an indirect passive-aggressive sort of way) but it means anyone of any gaming background (or non gaming background) can enjoy it if they have those two qualities. This is the often overlooked gateway game.

This game's so good to me, and so polarizing with others, that I can often get an accurate feel for how compatible a gaming partner I am with someone based on their opinion of this game alone

Cosmic Encounter refuses to be classified as a game that is loved by a certain type of person. I've had equal success with it as a gateway game, with hardcore gamers, and in some cases even the oddball pure-Euro gamer. It's interesting, it's well designed, and it's the holy grail of variety. There's a lot of game that comes from the "board", but there's also a large social element and "playing the players." It is designed so that everyone can feel involved at all times (if they want to be) -- and "downtime" in the usual sense of the word is meaningless because of it.

Every game plays differently. Every, single, one... that means that this is literally THE game I'd choose to take in one of those "if you were stranded on a desert island..." questions. Really, really, really strong replay value here. Some people have been playing it for decades...

I can understand it not being for everyone, but this is often a game that is misunderstood -- things that irritate some people actually seem to me like brilliant and careful design decisions.

Things like the fact that you (normally) cannot choose who you want to attack or the fact that multiple people can share a victory seem to irritate some people, but the random attacks and shifting alliances are essentially checks and balances (some of the only ones the game has) to open up the design space to create some truly awesome alien powers that would have been broken otherwise. And shared wins are what stop the game from becoming a drawn-out and degenerate "bash the leader" fest every single time -- if you can't beat em, join em! Now lets play again.

It's a good trade-off, because Cosmic Encounter is the most fun, unapologeticly asymmetric game that I know of. This design simply wouldn't work without the elements it does have. That makes it a perfect design.

And you know what else? It really, really does test your mettle at dealing with unforseen situations and manipulating your unforseen fates and fortunes as they come. We have seen as many consistent winners in our plays of this as we have in other FFA games of more obvious skill. Despite all of the chaos, almost every single game I lose, I walk away thinking about what I could have done to win. I feel like I have achieved a level of expertise in this game, but after 50+ plays I'm still learning every single time.

I don't think that that's an accident, either -- I firmly believe that this game was well crafted and play tested with specific intentions and goals. That's the difference between a chaotic game like Cosmic Encounter and one like Fluxx. One is my most love game, and one is my most hated.

That's not to say that Cosmic Encounter is not a chaotic and unpredictable game that rewards luck of the draw. Because it certainly is. But no matter what its detractors will tell you, it rewards knowledge, negotiation, creativity, risk-analysis, and careful planning more

That's not to say that the game is always fair -- it purposefully and proudly trades "fair" for interesting, hilarious, and dynamic. Those qualities are already enough to make a game worth playing, even if just for the fun of it -- the fact that in addition, yes, there is a game of skill here too, is what makes this the best game of all time.

I'm not sure there exists a multiplayer game that would suit me more than this. But it's an exciting (and scary) thought...

[hr]

[b]2 player[/b]: Not an officially supported mode, but actually works with dual alien powers and no destiny deck. Ban any aliens that are ally dependent and therefore useless (Parasite, Sapient, Observer, etc.)
[b]3 player:[/b] Compared to higher player counts, more about hand management and power usage and less about diplomacy and negotiation. Fast!
[b]4 player:[/b] Flexible - can occasionally be an epic game of intrigue, but is more often a fast 30-45 minute knife fight in a dark alley
[b]5 player:[/b] More interesting power interactions usually happen once you hit 5.
[b]6 player[/b]: Heavy on diplomacy and "playing the table." Really need to set yourself up for the win.
[b]7 player:[/b] 6 player, but bigger. Can be really epic. Lots of diplomacy. "Offense only" aliens should probably be avoided as a pick, unless they are very powerful. 
[b]8 player:[/b] Like 7 player but bigger.

[b]Expansions:[/b] Cosmic Incursion is fantastic, both its aliens and rewards deck. Cosmic Conflict aliens are great. Hazard deck is good, but there is one card in it I think is too Fluxx-like (temporal anomaly) which makes me not always want to use Hazards. Cosmic Alliance is hit and miss, but it has a few unforgettable aliens. Cosmic Storm is weak. Cosmic Dominion is maybe the best expansion, but is really for seasoned players so start with Incursion.

(5 Design + 5 Enjoyment)

RATING: 4
I confess that I still don't quite understand this game.  The negotiation aspect feels prescriptive - either you're giving away a home planet, or you're trying to sell the swill left in your hand.  Combat also feels random - don't expect to win with less than a 20.  Winning seems largely based on negotiation skill, but I feel like there's not enough complexity to vary your bargaining chips, much less acquire anything of worth.  I do like the racial abilities and the corresponding superpower cards a lot.  Playing in teams seems to give this game playability in absence of negotiation tools.

* Good player interaction.

* Multiple people can win together.
* Game design and play is somewhat open to adding personalized game variations.
CONS:
* Too often did the "wait what happens here?" scenario rear its ugly head.

* Lopsided alien card strengths.
* Game too often depends on luck of getting good cards.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
More than any other game I know, you need the right group. But with the right group, it's fantastic. I love the alliances, backstabbing, and asymmetry. Cosmic is chaotic, sure, but it's a game that produces lots of "Remember when..." moments. 

Almost everyone should try it, though not everyone will like it. It's for those who are in it for the group experience more than anything else, people who can let go a little, who can ride in the passenger seat without worrying about the destination. That's not to diminish the skill involved. Good players win often. But the route to victory is never the same. Aliens in play, cards in hand, and the players at the table determine the best course. Some players delight in finding a way to chart and navigate that course. Others don't care to. It's difficult to predict with confidence which category any given person will fall into.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A little too Ameritrash for my taste, but still totally fun. The diverse alien "powers" are an amazingly cool concept that totally makes the game. Cosmic was in its prime as a game when I was about 3 years old, so I am unable to feel nostalgic about it the way others might.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
It's a dynamic and swift game. Although I'm not enamored with it on the first try, I think I'll like it more after more plays. I think the main feature of this game is the random attack, which is a good feature. Random attack makes players switch alliance back and forth, creating a very interactive social experience, much like that of coup reformation. At first, the game appeared it might be a long game. But the 5 colonies wining condition is quiet easy to fulfill, making the game short and sweet. This game also has high replay value, as is true for social interaction games. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
What's great about this game is how simple the basic mechanics are but how much depth and variety it can still have.  One of my biggest turn-ons with a game is variety and re-playability (which typically go hand-in-hand), the more the better.  Usually variety makes games a lot more complicated though and the majority of my game group is more on the casual side and turned off by overly-complicated games.  The rules and mechanics for Cosmic Encounter are pretty simple though.  I think I spent the shortest amount of time ever explaining this game to four other new players before we got started.  Also, the theme is great and the world seems fully fleshed.

Where the depth comes in is mostly with the alien powers and also with various card effects (flash and artifacts in particular) and how they interact.  Everything seems explained pretty well on the cards too so we had little downtime from just trying to understand ability and card interactions.

A friend of mine described this as chaotic.  He is absolutely right.  Once the cards and racial abilities started flying it was mayhem and I loved every second of it.  I love chaotic, wild games as long as there is a way for me to wrap my head around and corral it to my benefit.  The same friend also accused this game as being so chaotic that there was very little opportunity for even tactical decision making.  This I think he was wrong about.

Yes, the game can be random and flash cards in particular can throw a monkey-wrench in the best laid plans but when your racial ability and cards are used intelligently and you've observed the player turns closely enough I saw a lot of opportunities for decisions that really played the system.

In fact the player who said this did something by accident that if he had meant to do it would have been an excellent move (it was still an excellent move actually, albeit accidental).  We had been fast enemies during the beginning of the game and when his turn next rolled around he asked me to be an offensive ally saying "let's let bygones be bygones".  He committed one ship to the fight (which counted as 4 since he was the Macron) and I threw 4 in there as well thinking our strength of 8 against the defense's strength of 4 had it won easy.  The defense played a low power attack and I KNEW the offense had a high-enough power attack to win the battle...and he played a negotiate.  Losing only one ship in the attack and sending four of mine to the warp.  He didn't realize that I would commit 4 ships in what I thought was a sure win and more-over didn't even think about how playing a Negotiate would lose me all those ships.  It was still a blow to me that if on purpose would have been great tactical gaming based on observation and playing the game mechanics in an unusual way to your own favor.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10

Compare to it the old Swedish version are really poor, both in production and in content. This is a game (this version) that I am going to play many, many times in the future, I hope.

RATING: 10
Cosmic Encounter is one of my tens, but it's funny because I don't even like it that much.  It earns its ranking because I am always willing to play it and that has not changed for three years.  There is just so much wacky bullshit here that the game is always entertaining, if not necessarily fun or worth playing.  Not exactly sure how to describe it.  All I can say is it gets a 10 by BGG rankings, but it's not my favorite game or even one of them.

EDIT: It's still inexplicable why I like this game so much, but I'd say it's no longer true that it's not one of my favorite games. Cosmic Dominion truly helped elevate this game into my top ten. I still think I should hate it, but what can a man do?

EDIT 2: This is now my favorite game. It played its way into my heart and I couldn't imagine a game collection without it. Good job, you rotten rat bastard of a game. Good job.

RATING: 7.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Cosmic Encounter is hilarious and fun.  All the different alien races and cards can make the game unbalanced, but who cares, just band together with your friends.  Most of the powers and cards have specific times they can be used anyway, so even if someone does seem overpowered, it is typically limited.

Overall it is just a wonderful 45  minutes to spend with buddies.  It isn't that strategic compared to the modern Euro game, but it doesn't try to be.  It is a timeless classic.

One note is that some people may feel this game is too mean spirited, but a lot of the meanness is mandatory and the rest is just funny instead of mean.  Played with strangers could be dicey, but could also serve to break the ice with laughter.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
The simple mechanic makes this game very playable. There's a lot of depth added by the large variety of different aliens available to play with, each with their own unique skill. This in turn provides a great deal of replay value to the game due to the huge variety of ways each race potentially interacts with each other. Virtually every game plays quite differently from previous ones and a successful tactical approach to a certain game may not work in future games.

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Rated '6' after initial rating, 2012. FFG version.

[EDIT Feb 2014] Played this again and it remains a strange mismatch of 'godawful lot of cool player powers' versus 'mediocre gameplay'. 

Enjoyable, but not a brilliant game. Revised rating to 6.8 as we did enjoy the game.

[EDIT Sep 2014] Hah. Revised again upwards to 7.5, after we've discovered we had been playing a critical phase wrong all these times: we first asked any offensive allies, had them answer and only then asked defensive allies. Now we discovered that you only do the invitation, but not the acceptance until both parties have had their chance to invite. This is a small, but crucial difference and it suddenly makes the gameplay much more exciting. Especially if you have races in play that key off refused alliances (Grudge) or succesfull defenses (Tic-tock) or failed Offense (Spiff). 

This makes the game system go from 'ok, bit boring, resolve' to 'tense, tense, resolve'.

Still, flares do seem a bit overpowered, player races seem not all balanced but these are typically things that have to grow on you (i.e. can be negated by 'experienced player balance'). So I will not be surprised if the rating will be revised upwards ever still with more replays.

[NOV 2016] Rated revised yet again upwards by one half. Has become a staple game of our yearly game-weekend, always getting at least one play which is enjoyed by all. Keeps being fresh and I keep getting my ass handed to myself on a plate. Ah well, maybe that is the appeal (to finally gang up on that unbeatable guy with all the game knowledge) :D

Luckily, I can have that and enjoy the wild ride in the face of unsurmountable odds. :)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I like the game after one play. It's really unforgiving; one player was basically out of the game for half of the time since he made some bad decisions.
It tends to take a while to play especially first few games, since you've got to read and focus on multiple cards at a time. It feels a bit slow and we tend to stop using powers and some of the cards because we get bored of reading all the aspects, but it's a fun game. I definitely want to play it at least a couple more times.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
The game is an absolute blast. It plays differently every time, and I find it relatively easy to teach to a new group. It's a game even non-gamers can play. Perhaps one of the best party games I've ever tried short of Apples to Apples.

For hardcore gamers, there is a ton of strategy tucked under the accessible upper crust. The game plays quickly, involves a lot of cajoling, lying and laughing and has gorgeous artwork.

The one criticism I have of the game is that the ending often feels anti-climactic. Someone just gains a fifth colony, usually with little fanfare or bombast. The game is too fun and has too much chaotic bombast to just end like that, without any sense of penultimate chaos or struggle.

The best feature is most likely the move-able planets, warp and hyperspace gate that replace any sort of board. It adapts nicely to any table space you may have.

Dave Bailey + all expansions (Alliance, Conflict, and Incursion)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Italy
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
Let's forget that this is game about alien races taking over planets in other alien systems, forget the intense negotiation, and the bluffing, and the cool alien superpowers, and the fact that you can win jointly, or go for the glory all yourself if you choose, forget all that, because the one thing you need to know is that the game is infinitely repayable.  Each game you will pick a new alien race, there are hundreds each with their own special powers, some with their own special decks,you will never have the same combination of races in any game, so every game is inherently different.  This game is so very fun, it's engaging, has tense bluffing and cool powers.  The one thing about the game is that it can take half and hour or two and half depending on how you play how lucky you are, risks you take etc.  So you can't really say "let's have a quick game," because there really is no telling how long the game take.  I love playing with new cool powers each time, I love the bluffing, I love that you can decide how you win, the game is great and I'll never say no to it.

RATING: 10
I owned the AH version and fell in love with the game despite the AH version being a neutered version. The FFG is an incredible offering and definitely feels like the definitive version.

On CE itself, this is the king of negotiation games, and the best chaotic game out there. There is plenty of decisions to be made, but that doesn't mean there isn't some luckiness that creeps in. 

However, how you play your cards and your power(s) and interact with the other players will mean much more than the cards you draw. That is the mark of a great game.

RATING: 5
Having some difficulties with this game.  There is no reason not to invite everyone but those ahead of you or perhaps tied with you in victory.  Thus only the final winning attack really matters, and I've seen games end even before my first turn because of this.

Typically it is often the entire table against one defender, making the actual encounter almost meaningless.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Finally got around to playing this (something I've wanted to do for years now.)  It's mechanically simpler than I was expecting and seems to benefit from having a larger group (although I can imagine 6 or 7 players would really increase the downtime.)  It's interesting and I found myself really drawn to the sheer number of  alien races (50 or so with awesome artwork), which adds a fair bit of replayability.  We played with 2 races each making for interesting mechanic combinations that seemed to add a fair bit to the game.  Of course, because of this nature, it could result in the game being wildly unbalanced, should players clue in alliances should compensate.  

The stacking plastic UFOs are pretty cool as well and the overall production value is as high as I would expect from any Fantasy Flight product.  At its core it's a chaotic hand management game (very luck driven), where it seems pertinent to utilize your worst cards effectively.  This is where I found the game would shine, in its devious backstabbing, negotiation or use of flares and powers to help compensate for these cards (who doesn't enjoy a little player interaction and bluffing.)  This leads to the games true nature, the players interactions.  This means that the group you play with is key to your enjoyment of this game, negotiation, diplomacy, betrayal and the ability to analyze your powers strategically are pivotal traits in your group.  .
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
I bought this game because I heard it had good replay value, wasn't too long and could accommodate a large amount of players.

Needless to say, I wasn't disappointed at all, and am now hooked to the game. I'm constantly trying to get my friends to play with me, and I've been having at least one session of Cosmic every week with my friends ever since I bought it. It's easy to lose track of time when playing it, and often we'll keep playing much longer than we probably should. After one game is done, we'll say to each other "Come on, man, just one more game..."

It rarely ever ends with just one.

RATING: 5
I tried this game twice. The first time, it was with only three people and the guy explaining the rules did a poor job. Also, it was an older, worse version of the game. It was boring. The second time was also with only three people and the guy who owned it was a super fan (we played his original Eon copy). We also played with multiple alien powers that changed every turn. It was terrible.
After a lot of reflection, I realized that it wasn't Cosmic Encounter that was the problem. I got this as a gift, and I'm excited to try it with four or more people who aren't going to spread on a thick layer of unconscionable house-rules.

Update - Recent play of this game has proved my suspicion correct: it is a lot of fun with the proper approach. The game can still sometimes be frustrating and a little too complex, but the negotiation and deal-making is great.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Really like this game after I started to get a handle on how to play it properly. The number of different alien powers is incredible (50 in the base game, lots more with expansions) and they completely change how you approach the game each time.

Update: I've found that the amount of chaos can really put off some people, particularly those who prefer more strategic games, but the game is great with the right group. It's basically about using the alien powers and cards to keep your opponents from scoring that last point, while allying and saving your cards for the right time to score the final point yourself. The game seems best with about four players, as with more players it can go on for too long and have too much downtime if you don't have a power that be used while allying.

[b]Player Count Verdict: 5[/b]
If everybody knows the game well, it's fine to play with 6. But for practicality with any new players, 5 is best. You still get a good mix of aliens and alliances and big battles, but with a faster play time than with 6. At lower player counts just play something else.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
My first three plays of CE were a huge disappointment. I found zero strategy and long-term strategy planning is what usually gets me excited about a game. After I played it about three times, I tried to give up my desired for strategy and just play it for what it is, a cut-throat, random, back-stabbing game. Since then I've grown to appreciate it more and have had more fun with my sessions of Cosmic Encounter.

My trade interest is low at this point, but would still consider intriguing trade offers.

1/8/12 -- NOT FOR TRADE anymore! I don't usually love games with tons of chaos. But CE does it well. I really like the interesting combos that happen based on diplomacy and tricky card play. The slogan of the game it "A Game of Infinite Possibilities". It lives up to this name because I don't remember any of my games feeling even close to the same. Further, crazy things happen every time I play. 

If you go into this game with the right attitude, you will enjoy it. And that's exactly what happened last weekend. After playing it late one night during the holiday. My family couldn't wait to play it again the next day! Success!
[COLOR=#FFFFFF]TAGS: thematic, components, 8 players, negotiation, intrigue, alliances, backstabbing, sci-fi, space, variable player powers, aliens, conflict, battles, hand management, FFG, square box[/COLOR]
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Being that I'm pretty wary of games that call for negotiation and potential backstabbing, I liked how the game basically chooses your opponents. This helps cut down either being picked on, or (if you're like me) worrying about who I might annoy or offend by attacking them.

The alien powers add nice variability and the game was surprisingly short. I can see how this game could create some very memorable moments. At heart, I think this is almost a party game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Played at BGGCon. Loved it. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This isn't so much a game as it is an engine driving interaction. A few weeks ago, my group played the gamiest of eurogames. It took three hours and none of us said a word the entire time, except for rules clarifications. I don't remember anything about that game. And then we pulled out Cosmic Encounter for a post-intensity cool down, and the contrast was incredible. We were talking, joking, laughing, and we all had a great time.

It's not the fleshiest of games, and it's not even the best at what it does (I prefer the Resistance as a social game), but if you've got it around it's always worth a play.

RATING: 9

draw from a deck to see who you have to attack, the first player with 5 colonies on foreign players wins.
