=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
I've liked this less with each play instead of more, which probably isn't a good sign.

I feel like the game is extremely chaotic, almost to the point where openly trying not to win is almost a viable strategy...I can see the fascinating part of that but it generally is not what I am looking for in games.

It's nearly impossible to have any real plans, as there is always some power or card just around the corner that will render those plans useless.

The tactical negotiations are fairly pointless in my eyes, building long-term alliances is simply a pipe-dream that will rarely if ever work out due to the randomness of encounters and the basic human nature of doing what is best for yourself.  You can beg and plead for people to join your side but unless some players are complete rubes, your cajoling will not change minds.

At the end of the day the player who gets the best cards, flies under the radar the best and ultimately gets to take a turn with a great hand and 4 colonies already in play will get the win...or worse multiple players will just dog pile a victory.

I get that people appreciate the game for the experience and the humorous stories that might emerge -- but I find that just as often the game is aggravating and a little bland.

On the plus side it plays in about an hour so I don't mind giving it a go, but I'd pretty much always prefer something else.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8

RATING: 4
Only 1 play, but seemed kind of pointless back and forth by the end. It's hard to be engaged when it's so affected by random card draws. Negotiation aspect is ok, but there are so many games that do it better. If everyone isn't invested in the game play then the game can go off the rails pretty easy. There are just too many negatives to waste time on this game, when there are so many games to do what this game does better. I was reading the comments of users who rate this game highly and there were many that apologized for the poor design and the uninspired game play. It kind of tells me that this game is kind of overrated.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3.5
First Impression:

A chaotic negotiation game with a space theme.

High replayability thanks to the various aliens.

Too random and pointless for me. I like negotiations/battles where something is at stake, but here nothing is at stake and every battle is the same boring and repeated process as before. This forces alliances to form either for a few more cards, or to simply bash the leader. Of course certain talented players will find a way to make this game work better, thanks to their "diplomatic" skills and imagination, but for me this game doesn't encourage any meaningfull negotiations.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10

RATING: 9
A downright solid game. Easy to learn, easy to set up. Out of all the 'Galactic Domination' themed games, board or otherwise, this is the best I've seen.

The elements of gameplay between conquest/negotiation are well balanced- and it's the only stab-your-neighbor in the back game with a cooperative win condition that doesn't feel like being cheated.

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Disappointing. I had high hopes given all of the praise for this classic, but after trying the new Fantasy Flight edition, I don't see what all the fuss is about. If I want to play a fairly random battle game with variable player powers, I'll stick with Dune. I know Cosmic Encounter has the advantage of being much quicker, but I found the sheer randomness of the cards in Cosmic Encounter to be more offensive than the already extremely random distribution of potentially very powerful cards in Dune. The decision-making in the combat seems highly outweighed by the potentially high-numbered cards. The variable player powers are interesting and I'm sure far ahead of their time when first conceived, but experiencing them for the first time in 2009 make it harder to appreciate their original genius, given all of the advances in the science during the intervening years. I've been enjoying a lot of Fantasy Flight games lately like Descent: Journeys in the Dark, Battlestar Galactica, A Game of Thrones, and War of the Ring, but this offering fell flat for me.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

I was hyped to try CE and it didn't disappoint. It has a great balance of silliness and fun, paired with strategy and decision making. The interactions are great, and with so many alien powers the species reveal moment can be terrifying and hilarious.

RATING: 8.5
CE is the game I like the most in 2011 (of the ones I first played in that year). I like the different races, the asymmetric powers, the table (trash) talk, the interactions (and sometimes then "take that" card throwing) among players.

The game sure is not for everyone (shy people my suffer) and there is somewhat the "bash the leader", though is more like "avoid calling the leader to the party", as the Destiny deck avoid some of bashing.

Overall, a great game (for me)!

My review (in portuguese) is [url=http://boardgamegeek.com/article/8398700#8398700]here[/url].

RATING: 7.2
I was pretty excited to play this game as it seemed the alien powers are very cool.  For me, it is a mediocre game as I tend not to like 'gang up on the one is winning' type of game.  It sucks in games sometimes as the person who is winning it is as easy as the other team members not letting you win as to how the game is played.  Although, it is still a good game and fun, I didn't care for the battles much either as they were just overly in favor of either winning or losing, no dice, no gotcha's much.  A great social game though and trying to get allies to help or help defend.  I do enjoy the game, just not as much as some of my others.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Most folks either love or hate this game. The haters generally don't like the fact that some races can seem overpowered. "Runaway leader syndrome" can be combated by recognizing it early and ganging up.

The potential for bluffing, negotiation, backstabbing, etc. make this game really interesting. Add in the variable powers attributed to each player, and it becomes a very different game each time you play.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Finally got to play this edition, much fun! Cosmic players are saying this is a great edition with lots of necessary stuff, and there is expected to be an expansion to produce a complete set FINALLY.  It seems like a different game than other editions I've played, but it's probably just the very different bits that cause my mind to forget the previous experience. I really like this game and want to play more.

I've come to the conclusion that the fun in this game is the broken rules and the squabbling over what takes priority.  As long as you play with people who don't argue about fiddly rules and you have fun, which is what gaming is all about! Cosmic Encounter is rapidly becoming one of my favorites. And, now with 3 expansions (edit: 4 expansion), it is getting closer and closer to completeness!

RATING: 6.5
Played the Mayfair version on numerous occasions, and like this version better: The artwork is better, timing issues are non-existent, it allows for managing the complexity level of the game depending on the experience of the players, it has 50(!) alien races to ensure replayability and the rules seem to cater for every situation you can possibly think of. Played the game three times the first time it hit the table, so I guess I am not the only one liking it. In terms of gameplay, it is a unique title to have in your collection.
UPDATE: Even though I had a lot of fun with this game in the past, it fell completely flat with the last two groups I played it with. I do not expect it to get any tablespace anymore, so I traded it away.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
My new go-to board game. It's grown on me immensely over the last few years. A simple, flexible core system of bluffing and negotiation with just enough randomness and variation to lead to endlessly interesting game states. It's easy to teach, plays quickly, and is never, ever boring. This is the game I bring out when I play with people who love the negotiation aspect of Catan, and afterwards every single one has declared Cosmic Encounter their favourite game and purchased it for themselves.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Just like any sci-fi themed board game, the potential audience is rather limited within my gaming circle. Female casual gamers just really shy away from high fantasy and sci-fi themes. Moreover, backstabbing games that have high amounts of conflict tend to limit the audience even more. As such, Cosmic Encounter is a game that I would love to play, but would never end up buying a copy.

This classic game really have withstood the onslaught of modern game design. It holds up quite well and is fun to play with the right group. There is plenty of wheeling and dealing and I absolutely enjoy the interaction. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10

RATING: N/A
I finally got the opportunity to play this last night. Eh... somewhat underwhelming considering all I'd heard. As others have noted, there seems to be too much chaos to allow for much actual strategy. Also, the numerous special cards, powers, exceptions, etc. are all fodder for rules lawyering that slow everything down.

I don't know... I'd play it again, though I'm not eager to do so. But I'll hold off of rating it just yet.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Munchkin for Gamers.

A game of gang up on the leader, kingmaking, and arbitrary winners.  Someone will near victory, players will burn cards trying to stop that player from winning, allowing most (or all) other players to catch up.  The game then continues until one player has the right card or player power to pull off a win and everyone else has run out of cosmic and card zaps.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3

RATING: 8.5
Game is really wonderful for fielding a lot of players at the same time while never being boring since every move involves every player.  There's a mind-boggling amount of variability through aliens to every match that you'll never play the same game twice.

As with all games that rely on heavy player involvement, the game can fall a little flat if you're playing with a lot of quiet, un-confrontational players.  If you get a great group of boisterous personalities though, all the pleading and conniving and under-handed deals, it's can just be amazing fun.

RATING: N/A
Each player is the leader of an alien race. The object of the game is to establish colonies in other players' planetary systems. On a player's turn, he or she encounters another player on a planet, and both sides are able to invite allies to try and tip the encounter in their favor.

3-5 (best 5)

Bluffing, negotiation, hand management, partnership

RATING: 8
Oct 2016-Like poker but with Aliens that break the rules! Normally I don't like so much luck but once I learned to treat it like poker but different every time and with some negotiation and persuasion elements I learned to love this game. Its replay-ability is endless and lots of memorable moments are bound to come up every time you bring it out for a few plays.

This game really rewards repeat play with experienced players as at first glance, most new players (myself included) don't appreciate all the subtleties such as, it isn't always good to invite allies if they might benefit from helping you rather than vice versa.

RATING: 3
+ Some interesting mechanics
+ Cool special abilities
+ Good art and components

-/? Too complex for what it offers (you can fix it removing some cards)
-/? Very long for what it is (you can fix it playing shorter game, maybe even better with 3 planets)

- So much randomness in such a long game (card values range from 8 to 40 (!fourty!))
- Taking last colony feels almost like taking last level in Munchkin (that's always a good sign, right?)
- Theme pasted on, it could easily be villages or islands or infected organisms with viruses or some other things instead of planets and colonies
- Cards look boring
- May cause anger and whining
- The game shows the worst in the players
- Not everybody can negotiate, for such players game is not fun

RATING: 4
I really despise this game in all its incarnations.  It's chaotic, luck-driven groupthink.  I hear this get called a negotiation game sometimes, which makes my skin crawl.  I love negotiation games, but this game is not one of them.  This is a thinly-veiled excuse to form and hold grudges, and doesn't hold any real strategy to it.  It's one of the best examples of 'everybody stop Joe because he's really close to winning oh crap now we have to stop Nora too and oh look now we can't stop Mark and he just won.'  Somehow the BGG hivemind recognizes and hates this in [gameid=1927], but Cosmic gets a free pass.  Whiskey Tango Foxtrot?

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
In Cosmic Encounter, each player is the leader of an alien race. The object of the game is to establish colonies in other players' planetary systems. Players take turns trying to establish colonies. The winner(s) are the first player(s) to have five colonies on any planets outside his or her home system. A player does not need to have colonies in all of the systems, just colonies on five planets outside his or her home system. These colonies may all be in one system or scattered over multiple systems. The players must use force, cunning, and diplomacy to ensure their victory.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
FFG
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Cosmic Encounter is, at it's core, a pretty dry game. It's hard to see the appeal by simply looking over the rules or watching a video review. Even when one considers all of the crazy alien power interactions, it just doesn't look all that entertaining. Well, looks can be deceiving, because it is wildly fun. The only problem with finding that fun is that everyone needs to be somewhat experienced for it to work. Gameplay is eighty percent negotiation and diplomacy, so it is very easy for someone with a strong or easy-to-use alien power to steamroll to an easy victory. Cosmic Encounter demands that the whole table work together to stop anyone from gaining too much momentum, so if the player's aren't all savvy enough to play defensively, the game is extremely unsatisfying.

It reminds me of Robo Rally a little bit. In the right crowd, it's one of the best games ever designed. In the wrong one, it's an unmitigated disaster waiting to happen.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8

RATING: 7.5
A cult classic, this is a game of wild swings in cosmic fortunes. Each player plays an alien race with a special power and must colonize 5 other worlds to win. Players attack each other, with the main attacker/defender optionally offering alliances to others. There are also other cards that can give special powers or hurt others. It is a unique Ameritrash game.

RATING: 8
In the depths of space, the alien races of the Cosmos vie with each other for control of the universe.  Players choose from dozens of alien races, each with its own unique power to further its efforts to build an empire that spans the galaxy. A classic game of alien politics. In Cosmic Encounter, each player is the leader of an alien race. The object of the game is to establish colonies in other players' planetary systems. Players take turns trying to establish colonies. The players must use force, cunning, and diplomacy to ensure their victory.

I had a really good time with this game, but I was lucky to play it with the right people. Your experience with Cosmic Encounter will depend on your gaming group and may be vastly different. 

The only downside is that it takes a while to explain all the rules - it's a simple game, but it's kind of tricky to learn.

There is deception, backstabbing, chance, manipulation, and excitement all inside of this box.  Its social, encourages constant table talk from all players, and I really enjoy it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
[i]Cosmic Encounter[/i] stands out, for me at least, as one of the best experiences in gaming. It is a game that thrives on constant player-interaction and rampant table-talk as you wheel and deal your way to galactic conquest. It is a social game that can't always be won by brute force and instead requires players to consider their moves (and allies) carefully.

Hand-management, circumstantially-appropriate card play, bluffing and scrutiny of other players all play a huge role in the game and will be your tools to victory. The fact that each player has a unique Alien Power that changes the game in some way and the fact that 50 such Alien Powers come with the base game means that the options and replayability are limitless. No two games will be identical.

I cannot praise this game highly enough. It has a simple core of mechanics that are quick and easy to teach, endless variety thanks to the Alien Powers and is a game in which all players are constantly involved.

I can't call [i]Cosmic Encounter[/i] anything other than what it is: the best, most interesting, most exciting, most memorable and most [b][u]fun[/u][/b] board game I've ever played.

If someone said I could only play one board game for the rest of my life, it would be [i]Cosmic Encounter[/i], without question.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7

It's not a game for everyone, or WITH anyone.
But with the right crowd, it's a blast.

I love Cosmic Encounter. There's something about the chaos, the bluffing and the constant switching of alliances that make this game really interesting to me. RATING: 7
Review Date: May 2017

Disclaimers for context:I play with all the expansions added 

Positives: Simple to learn. No 2 games the same. The depth of play and alien races are incredible. Very aggressive gamestyle (might be a negative for you)

Negatives:  Some aliens are too bizarre and are hard to understand for new players. Very aggressive gamestyle (might be a positive for you)

Conclusion: Crazy and unpredictable. Social and the epitome of in your face gaming. If you have 4 or 5 players and want to get random and aggressive, cosmic is for you.

Score 8 if you can handle the knocks!

RATING: 10
I don't know what it is about this game but I obsessed over it half a year before I ever even played it. 

There's something about this game that really connects with me. The combination of theme, tone, game play and aesthetics make for a very rewarding experience.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
My all-time favorite game. Cosmic Encounter plays like a social game, but offers surprising strategic depth when played with experienced CE gamers. I always feel like I have chance in CE, regardless of my alien, but the general wackiness of the powers, flares, and the card draw prevents me (and I suspect others as well) from feeling 'too' invested in winning. This makes the game feel refreshing and fun, despite the fact that I'm constantly thinking through alien power combinations and my choices.

The only downside to CE is that it can be difficult to teach. My wife looks at the wall of text on her Alien Sheet and just shuts down. I didn't have this problem with my first game group, but it's proving to be a challenge with my second.

Still, 10 from me.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
Great game, if you like to talk. If not, you'll probably not like it.

One of the very best boardgames I've ever played - though to be fair that's still a number less than 50. No game is ever the same, always some new interesting way to make things happen, something new to react to and something to plot.

It does require at least 4 players to be enjoyable, but makes up for it by basically including every player in every round, so usualy you do not feel like you have nothing to do if you scale the game to include more players (with expansions it allows for up to 8). 5 or 6 is probably the golden number.

Highly entertaining in every aspect. Though I can see how some people might get hung up by the rules not always being clear cut.

RATING: 10
If you like games with different powers for different players, then this is the game for you. There are tons of aliens to choose from and the replayability is very high. 

This is just fun to play, where you attack other players to try to establish five colonies on their planets. The attacker/defender have the possibility to invite the other players to support them.

Cosmic Encounter is a hand management card game where you have to know when to play your best cards. Sometimes you will be lucky and have great cards, other times your cards sucks. You have to make the best of it, it is as simple as that.

My gaming group loves this one!

RATING: 4

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Cosmic Encounter is the game that made me think about the question: what makes a game good? The mechanics? The interactions with other players? The amount of laughter it can produce? The satisfaction when you see your well-thought out strategy come into motion? This game made me separate games into two different categories: games that give me a 'silent satisfaction', and I want to let my brain burn on a big strategic puzzle ('euro's', mostly) and games that give me memorable, awesome experiences that me and my friends will still talk about after some time has passed (Shadows over Camelot, party games). Cosmic Encounters falls into the second category, and is mechanically most definitely not the best game around (basically, your turn comes down on playing a card against your opponent), but when looking at the experiences it provides, there's no other game I've ever played that can beat it. That awesome moment when you play your Attack 40 to win your 5th planet while none of the other players can do something about it is AWESOME (talking from experience. Twice.). Therefore, it's a game that I most likely won't turn down when you ask me to play it. Awesomeness in a box: that's Cosmic Encounter. I 'only' give it a 7,5 because, as I said, mechanically it's not the best game around: the aliens are inbalanced (1 Mobius Tubes and Masochist is screwed), there are some ruling issues (some interactions between cards and aliens are just not explained), it's highly group-dependant and you never know how long the game is gonna take: it could be within half an hour up to over 2 hours. Also, a bad first game definitely turns off people. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
2-5 player space combat game. Players use their variable powers to invade others' planets and establish colonies. Like Munchkin, but not boring.

RATING: 9.5
It's a classic but it holds up so well no matter how much time has passed. The social combat system works great. The incredible amount of replayability and amazing interactions between races make this a true stand out game for me.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
"A game of infinite possibilities" certainly rings true here. I love any game where 3+ players can get involved in a counter war: "I zap your flare - I zap your zap - I zap the zap that zapped his zap!".

My wife thinks this one brings out the testosterone with all the dealing and fighting and she'd rather avoid it. I guess she's right that it can become something of a bear pit.

+ Cosmic Incursion

< June 2015
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
There is nothing about this game I do not like. Playing with three is fun, but to be utilised to its maximum fun-playing potential four or five is a prerequisite. The game playing dynamic does not allow for players to wimp out when it is their turn, so one is always aware of how tactically demanding this science fiction adventure makes one measure up their options.

RATING: 7
I had to decrease my rating of this game on the basis that we got a few games that were not that fun to experience due to bad Alien combinations. Because of that my group is less eager to play the game again.
Otherwise, great party game with no downtime. Really cool mechanisms, cool social interaction, cool aliens and cards. Its only weakness is its target audience. Not everybody feels confortable playing a negociation game like CE. Also, card hoarding wins games. A few aliens are not fun at all to play. Other than that an amazing and unique game. It really requires 6 players to really shine, though, which I find hard to achieve nowadays. I don't give it a higher rating on the basis that a small % of the games will inevitably be broken, because of some combo emerging that kills the game completely or makes it very unfair.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Best mix of party-type gaming with tactical gaming.  
You will laugh and laugh and laugh at the inter-player politics, but you'll often find yourself thinking about how you can make an encounter work to your advantage.  The FF version has so much character in its presentation that you almost role-play the alien species you are given.
Also, a HUGE bonus to this game is that there is NO down time.  Even with 6 players (i haven't played with more, but i don't see it being any different) everyone was talking, interacting, and even intently watching (when they might not even have any stakes in the current encounter).  No one ever had their phone out, or left the room.  We all were playing ALL the time.
I've played with only new groups (new to this game, that is) of people, and, while some were a bit lost during the first round of the game, all of them enjoyed it and wanted to play a second game immediately after finishing their first.  There is a reason why this game has been around for so long.  It's a fantastic design that is hard to beat.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Fun game with a great balance of group negotiation, strategy, luck, and backstabbing. It's almost always a hit when it comes out, and the number and alien variations and expansions make it infinitely replayable.

RATING: 9
Good update of the classic. Nothing changed rulewise, but production values are in good shape although a bit overpriced. This one gives you those all warming cosmic grooves.

update: summer 2010, game has been nicknamed by one of my friends and I concur: it's no more cosmic encounter, its FUCKING AWESOMENESS!

RATING: N/A
Hmm. This is a bit of a headscratcher. Cosmic was a personal grail game for a while--it kept cropping up as the no. 1 game on places like Sit Down & Shut Up and Rock Paper Shotgun, but was out of stock locally everywhere for a couple of months. When I finally got hold of it I was sure it would be a big hit... yet nobody I've played it with (about eight people, in three different groups) has been especially taken with it. 

I still have hope that it will grow on us, though. The same way Wiz-War did. The trouble is, we now have plenty of other games to play, so Cosmic doesn't come out often enough to get a chance to shine. I went ahead and picked up the expansions regardless, out of possibly misplaced optimism...

RATING: 7
I friggin' love Cosmic. We've played this a lot, usually with 5-6 people but sometimes as many as 8 (since Cosmic Alliance). It's relatively simple, somewhat fast to play and extremely replayable what with the humongous stack of Aliens to pick from. Usually people want to go again as soon as it's over. I think my only problem with the game is more of an issue with the players because even though I've repeatedly told them that inviting to attack and defend is supposed to be a considered decision, everyone still basically auto-invites everyone every time which leads to somewhat dumb games sometimes. Oh well, still adore Cosmic.

RATING: 3
Cosmic encounter is another one of those games that does well when there is a healthy level of negotiation going on. You need to get 5 colonies set up, but the cards make it so that you’re going to have a really hard time doing so unless you’re exploiting your race’s power properly and working well with the table. It felt like the game got very stagnant as soon as someone hit 4 colonies, but I’m not sure if we were playing with all the correct rules. I would play this again just to explore the different strategies offered by the various races.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
It is incredible easy to learn, bridges different types of players and is - pure and simple - fun to play.

What really makes a difference to so many games out there:

- there is no "downtime" during other players turns.
- it is fairly short, but still long enough to "matter".
- you can always turn the game around and win.
- it is very interactive.

RATING: 7.5
Bluffing, calculating, guessing and overall lot of fun to play. Rules of the game change each time. There is no downtime between turns, since you can always be asked to participate in combat as an ally. Some negative points for the bookkeeping when you have a lot of flares or artefacts (cards with lot of text on it) and being dealt a powerful alien on whom everyone gangs up. This leads to a certain amount of kingmaker problems. 

It's still a recommendation for every game collection since it's easy to setup, teach, play and interactive. It has it's memorable moments and also has a great variety.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
A classic that never gets old, even after hundreds of play.

Caveat to "always want to play"--with the right group. While this is true for most games, this is one of the most finicky. Players who strongly prefer low-lucky high-strategy games will be put off by the random draws and power imbalances among aliens. Players who can't stand take-that mechanics, which I'm not a huge fan of myself, might be put off by it. 

Personally, it works because the take-that isn't too strong, most of the luck you can mitigate with smart hand management and by being a smooth negotiator. I suggest throwing small amounts of money ($1-5 per player) each game, with the winner(s) splitting the pot to maximize end-game shenanigans if you think your group can handle that without bad blood. The game is quite good without that addition, but in my experience lends itself toward shared victories.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Seems like a good game but the random attacks really seem to detract,  I am thinking of trying a game without the destiny deck to see how it plays.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
It's a classic, but....
And the sheer number of races means you'll never see the same game twice.  Ever.
However, there isn't as much actual 'game' here as I'd like. It essentially boils down to 'draw a card, attack that player'. The game comes from exactly how you should attack, what card to play, should you make a deal etc, but I would prefer it if it had a touch more depth.
